Section Title: HISTORICAL AND CURRENT MARKET AND INDUSTRY DATA
Subsubsection Text: It is difficult to obtain precise industry and market information in our industry. Historical and current market data used throughout this offering memorandum were obtained from internal company analyses and surveys, consultants’ reports and industry publications. In drafting this offering memorandum, GlobalData 2017, in particular, was used. Our market share data included in this offering memorandum is calculated using a numerator of our 2017 volumes with a denominator of the data from GlobalData 2017 which presents the relevant market as of December 31, 2016. We believe this adjustment is necessary to give effect to the incremental production volumes from our acquisitions completed in 2017, whereas we do not believe there were other significant changes in respect of overall industry volumes in 2017. Industry surveys and publications generally state that the information contained therein has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but the accuracy and completeness of information contained therein is not guaranteed. We therefore assume no liability for and offer no guarantee of the accuracy of the data from studies and third-party sources contained in this offering memorandum or for the accuracy of data on which our estimates are based. In particular, market studies and analyses are frequently based on information and assumptions that may not be accurate or technically correct, and their methodology is by nature forward-looking and speculative. Similarly, internal company analyses and surveys, while believed by us to be reliable, have not been verified by any independent sources, and neither we nor any of the Initial Purchasers makes any representation as xx ----- to the accuracy of such information. While we are not aware of any misstatements regarding any industry or similar data presented herein, such data involve risks and uncertainties and are subject to change based on various factors, including those discussed under the ‘‘Risk Factors’’ section in this offering memorandum. xxi -----

----- In 2017, we sold approximately 11,042 million liters of soft drinks. On a standalone basis, Refresco sold 7,104 million liters of soft drinks and had a gross profit margin per liter of 14.0 euro cents and Cott TB sold approximately 3,938 million liters for the year ended December 31, 2017. Our Pro Forma Synergies Adjusted EBITDA was A392.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2017. See ‘‘—Summary Pro Forma _and Other Adjusted Financial Information—Pro Forma Synergies Adjusted EBITDA.’’ Our_ _pro forma_ consolidated revenue was A3,718.9 million. Refresco’s consolidated revenue was A2,268.8 million and Cott TB’s carve-out revenue was $1,637.1 million, in each case, for the year ended December 31, 2017. Revenue, however, may not be a meaningful indicator of the development of our business as changes in revenue are largely driven by fluctuations in input prices that are passed on to customers.

We are the world’s largest independent bottler of retailer brands soft drinks by volume and a leading contract manufacturer of soft drinks by volume for A-brands with leadership positions across all of our activities and geographies. Approximately 70% of our business is retailer brands and approximately 30% is contract manufacturing. We also manufacture and sell specialty soft drink products on a small scale under our own brands. We have operations in Europe and North America, with a manufacturing network of 59 production facilities operating 270 production lines across 12 countries. Our European operations are in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany, France, Italy, the UK, Spain, Finland and Poland. Our North American operations are in the United States, Canada and Mexico. We manufacture a broad portfolio of products for our retailer brands and contract manufacturing customers. Our portfolio comprises carbonated soft drinks (‘‘CSDs’’), bottled water, fruit and vegetable juices, sports and energy drinks, still drinks, including ready-to-drink tea (‘‘RTD tea’’), and dilutables. We offer our products in a wide range of packaging sizes and types. Given our position as a leading bottler of soft drinks in key markets, we believe we have a large impact not only on our customers but also on our employees and the environment. As such, we have a group-wide approach to corporate social responsibility and quality management which we implement across our business units. Our three-pillar approach focuses on workplace safety, sustainability and maintaining the highest food quality standards while creating healthier products. Our sustainability initiatives include creating sustainable packaging solutions, reduction of water use and energy consumption, improving the sustainability of our supply chain and maximizing our use of green transport.

Subsubsection Title: Clear scale benefits from being the world’s largest independent bottler
Subsubsection Text: We are the world’s largest independent bottler of retailer brands soft drinks by volume and a leading contract manufacturer for A-brands by volume in Europe and North America with leadership positions across all of our activities and geographies. Approximately 70% of our business is retailer brands and 30% is contract manufacturing. We are approximately 4.1 times larger than our next largest competitor (excluding pureplay water players) in the Addressable Soft Drinks Market based on our reported volume for 2017 and competitors’ volume according to GlobalData, 2017. Our manufacturing network comprises 59 production facilities operating 270 production lines across 12 countries through which we are well-positioned to serve local markets. As such, we benefit from significant economies of scale. We sustain competitive margins through managing both procurement and operating expenses, including the optimization of our plants and streamlining of overhead costs. We are also able to leverage our platform and scale in negotiations with customers and suppliers, which we believe gives us clear scale benefits that our smaller competitors cannot match. Our global platform gives us an advantage because we can service our customers across all key product categories in Europe and North America. We are differentiated from our competitors through our pan-European footprint. In our key European markets, we have a sizeable leading market share according to management estimates. We also have a national presence in the United States. Furthermore, we are licensed by a majority of A-brands to produce their products, which gives us a key strategic advantage as compared to other contract manufacturers. Our global manufacturing footprint provides co-proximity to our customers, enabling us to minimize distribution expenses while also reducing the impact of our business activities on the environment. This proximity and flexibility differentiates us from our competitors and enables us to develop exclusive and long-lasting relationships with our customers. Our size contributes to economies of scale in production costs and distribution, and our production platform and mix of retailer brands and contract manufacturing volumes enable us to continuously optimize our efficiency and capacity utilization. Our size also affords us greater market intelligence capabilities that lead to improved service levels, innovation and flexibility. As a result of our scale, we also benefit from a distinct purchasing edge as compared to our competitors. We believe that this gives us a crucial advantage in an industry where purchasing costs account for a large proportion of sales. Given the highly consolidated supplier base for key raw materials, we benefit from competitive input pricing and preferential supply and payment terms, particularly in comparison with our smaller competitors. This scale benefit is further amplified by our coordinated approach to procurement. Additionally, to ensure we have alternatives when needed, we are continuously looking to broaden our supplier base for the most important raw and packaging materials, such as through sourcing from smaller suppliers or replacing with alternative products. In addition, we have dedicated experts with extensive market knowledge for each key raw materials category.

Subsubsection Title: Leadership positions in attractive and growing markets
Subsubsection Text: We have leadership positions in Europe and North America. In Europe, we are the number one player by volume in retailer brands with approximately 18% market share of the European Soft Drinks Market, were approximately 2.8 times larger than our next largest competitor (excluding pureplay water players) based on our reported volume for 2017 and competitors’ volume according to GlobalData, 2017. In addition, we 2 ----- also have a leading market position in European contract manufacturing. In the U.S., the market is highly fragmented and we are the only player with operations across the country among more than 250 smaller players that are generally focused on limited regions or categories. Approximately one-third of our volume is sold in North America, with the U.S. being the largest single market globally with an annual consumption of approximately 114 billion liters and the highest consumption per capita in the world as of December 31, 2016. In the U.S., consumption per capita is approximately 381 liters per year on average, whereas consumption per capita is approximately 206 liters per year in Western Europe, approximately 169 liters per year in Latin America, approximately 70 liters per year in China and approximately 42 liters per year in the rest of Asia. From 2016 to 2021, volume in the North American Soft Drinks Market, is expected to increase at a rate of 1.4% per year. Between 2011 and 2016, volume grew at approximately 1.0% per year according to GlobalData, 2017. The European Soft Drinks Market is the second largest market globally with an annual consumption of 102 billion liters. Volumes are expected to increase by 0.7% per year from 2016 to 2021, compared to 0.2% per year from 2011 to 2016. Our largest market within Europe in terms of volume is the UK, where volume growth has been relatively flat between 2011 and 2016 but is expected to grow at a forecasted CAGR of 0.8% from 2016 to 2021 according to GlobalData, 2017. Furthermore, the UK is expected to contribute 13% to the European Soft Drinks Market’s volume by 2021 according to GlobalData, 2017. We expect that contract manufacturing will be the key growth driver for us in the short-term with strong underlying structural drivers supporting long-term growth. We are the largest contract manufacturing player in both the European Soft Drinks Market and the North American Soft Drinks Market, with our contract manufacturing operations generating approximately 30% of our combined volume in 2017. We have also entered into contract manufacturing of water and mineral water, which we believe provides us with an additional opportunity for growth. Historically, contract manufacturing volumes have grown slightly faster than expected due to increased outsourcing. A-brands have increasingly focused on asset-light strategies and look to outsource non-core bottling processes. Further, the market has evolved to a point where a large number of small brands and independent manufacturers are creating successful brands (e.g. Arizona, Monster), which generally lack bottling capabilities and outsource the bottling and fill function. The proliferation of multiple brands and packaging varieties, such as 250ml cans, has encouraged large bottlers to outsource, especially for small volume, to bottlers with greater production flexibility. The industry has also seen a trend of volume shifting away from CSD to juices and still drinks, which are typically lower volume products and are therefore more likely to be outsourced. Additionally, high-growth functional beverages, such as enhanced waters and iced teas, that require greater sophistication in the beverages production process. The production process for these categories chiefly uses aseptic PET (‘‘A-PET’’) filling technology in Europe and hot-fill technology in the U.S., requiring high capital investment and expertise to properly operate, and as a result are often outsourced. We expect these trends to continue driving growth going forward.

Subsubsection Title: Unique business model, focusing on leadership in retailer brands and contract manufacturing, providing structural competitive advantages
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have a unique business model as the result of the combination of our retailer brands business, where we manufacture for European and North American retailers and discounters, our contract manufacturing business, where we manufacture for brand owners, and our geographic reach and scale. This combination provides us with several structural competitive advantages. Our business model positions us to take advantage of growth trends in the European Soft Drinks Market and North American Soft Drinks Market as both the retailer brands and contract manufacturing segments are expected to grow between 2017 and 2021. In addition, our focus on retailer brands and contract manufacturing means that, other than for specialty regional drink products, we have limited competition with A-brands, which provides us with an advantage when competing for outsourced branded volumes as compared to the manufacturing and bottling subsidiaries of large A-brand owners that are direct competitors. This is beneficial because the long-term nature of contract manufacturing contracts adds resilience, stability and predictability to our business. A-brand owners are outsourcing the manufacturing of their new and lower volume products because of the increased production complexity as a result of product and packaging diversification. We are able to manufacture these volumes using our optimized plant/line specialization, and reduce overall complexity and switch-over costs as these volumes are relatively large in comparison to our retailer brands product portfolio. Our global platform gives us an advantage because we can service 3 ----- our customers across all key product categories in Europe and North America and are differentiated from our competitors through our pan-European footprint and our national presence in the United States.

Subsubsection Title: Well-balanced and diversified portfolio across products, geographies and categories
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have a well-balanced portfolio with exposure across a range of geographies across the spectrum of product and packaging materials. Our extensive and flexible manufacturing network allows us to manufacture a wide array of products in a variety of packaging in the geographies where we are active. The chart below shows our 2017 volumes by geography and by product type:
We believe that the following strengths characterize our business and will help us realize our strategic goals and reinforce our competitive position:

Subsubsection Title: Diversified customer base with long-standing relationships in both Europe and the United States
Subsubsection Text: We have a broad portfolio of ‘‘must-have’’ retail customers and A-brands (including Walmart, Lidl, Aldi, Monster, PepsiCo and Arizona), which has been further strengthened by tapping into the rapid expansion strategy of discounters in the U.S. and growing our contract manufacturing exposure. The Cott TB Acquisition provides meaningful diversification to our customer base, reducing dependency on single accounts as well as consolidating A-brand customers. In 2017, on a standalone basis Refresco’s top 10 customers accounted for 58% of its volumes and Cott TB’s top 10 customers accounted for 66% of its volumes. Together, our top 10 customers accounted for 49% of our total combined volumes in 2017. We have longstanding relationships with our customers. Refresco has maintained relationships with 19 of its top 20 customers for over 15 years, which we believe is a testament to the high quality of our products and service. Further, Cott TB has maintained a strong relationship with Walmart for more than 20 years and, following the Cott TB Acquisition, it is now one of our largest customers. We build and maintain these relationships through customer integration, coordinating with our customers in areas such as supply chain (to minimize freight costs and reduce working capital requirements), new product development and packaging designs, market expertize (trends and opportunities) and customer service. The high level of customer integration coupled with our ability to provide a full range of soft drinks products and packaging increases our current and future customers’ dependence on our services, thus leading to long-lasting relationships. We believe that the complementary geographic locations of Cott TB will allow us to consolidate our customer relationships internationally, thus reinforcing partnerships and increasing customer reliance on our business, and thereby reducing the likelihood of potential account losses. Moreover, we will now be able to offer access to a global network, combining Refresco’s strong European capabilities and Cott TB’s strength in North America and the UK. We also believe that this combination will afford us the opportunity to grow alongside our existing European customers, Aldi and Lidl, as they expand in the U.S. We therefore believe that we are well-positioned to strengthen our relationships with our current customers, from both a geographic and product perspective and also to develop relationships with new customers, thus achieving additional utilization from our existing footprint.

Subsubsection Title: Track record of synergy realization from acquisitions is evidence of the success of the continuing consolidation strategy
Subsubsection Text: Following a series of over 20 acquisitions since 1999, we have transformed from a small, local juice bottler into a leading soft drinks manufacturer in Europe and North America. We are currently the number one retailer brands bottler and a leading contract manufacturer across Europe and North America by volume. As we evolved in scale, we gained greater awareness of achievable procurement and footprint optimization synergy opportunities throughout our business. One example is our combination with Gerber Emig, which demonstrated our extremely successful approach to consolidation. We were able to realize synergies from the transaction well ahead of our plan, mainly as a result of faster and higher than expected realization of procurement synergies. Our acquisition of Cott TB similarly offers a substantial synergy potential, particularly through scale benefits. Based on our strong track record of integrating acquisitions and realizing synergies, we expect to generate A34 million of savings through price harmonization and volume bundling, which we believe can be realized relatively quickly. We also believe we can achieve A22 million of operational synergies by optimizing footprint and operational efficiencies through the transfer of lines and manufacturing footprint rationalization. Lastly, we have targeted A6.8 million of achievable overhead synergies through headcount and office space lease reductions as we integrate and streamline our combined operation. Altogether, we anticipate total run-rate synergies of A62.8 million in the first three years following our consolidation, representing 4.3% of Cott TB’s 2017 revenue. See ‘‘Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations— _We may fail to realize the business growth opportunities, margin benefits and other synergies anticipated from, or may incur unanticipated costs or be exposed to unexpected liabilities associated with or resulting from the Cott TB Acquisition.’’_ 5 ----- We have a strong track record in delivering or exceeding our synergies expectation, and on average have historically achieved synergies of approximately 3.5% to 5.0%. We believe we have the capability to replicate our previous successes and intend to continue taking a proactive approach towards consolidation, with Cott TB and any future acquisitions.

Subsubsection Title: Differentiated innovation capabilities support uniqueness of customer proposition and cost leadership
Subsubsection Text: We believe we are able to differentiate ourselves from our competitors by focusing on innovation as we closely follow industry trends that shape end-consumer demand. For instance, we are currently leading the development of A-PET lines in Europe, which we believe will replace more traditional packaging types in the near future, as growth of complex functional beverages continues. A-PET technology is ideal for complex functional beverages because it improves shelf-life and allows for non-refrigerated transportation and storage, while still providing superior taste and vitamin content. We are also continually looking to optimize our product and packaging offerings in collaboration with our customers. In addition, our broad manufacturing platform enables us to respond and quickly adapt to changing customer needs. We also believe our innovation capabilities provide a competitive advantage in tenders as we are able to proactively propose alternative specifications to improve recipes and minimize costs, such as, for instance, through alternative sourcing or packaging solutions. Our track record and abilities in this respect are widely recognized by our customers, which we believe further allows us to continue to strengthen our customers’ confidence in our capabilities. Finally, unlike our smaller competitors, we believe the combination of our scale and industrial expertize permits sizeable investments when required, thus developing quick routes to market and increasing volumes across our platform.

Subsubsection Title: Committed and experienced management team widely recognized in the industry supported by committed Sponsors
Subsubsection Text: We have a decentralized organization consisting of empowered business units that ensure quality service for local customers. These business units report into two divisions: Refresco Europe and Refresco North America. A relatively small central team manages strategy, procurement, finance, M&A, legal and communication. The central team achieves economies of scale and provides the local organizations with the framework and tools to run our business as optimally as possible. The local organizations are close to their customers and responsive to customer needs while maintaining Group standards and deploying our best practices. These business units are led by highly experienced and professional management teams that meet regularly to ensure operating consistency across the Group. The Executive Board is supported by a best-in-class management team including CEO Hans Roelofs, CFO Aart Duijzer and COO Europe Vincent Delozi`ere with the addition of, following his expected appointment in May 2018, COO North America Brad Goist. Hans joined Refresco in 2007 as CEO and prior to this was CEO of Dumeco, a private label meat producer and processor. Hans is a graduate of Wageningen University and started his career at Nutreco, rising to Managing Director of the Agri-Food Business. Aart joined Refresco in 2000 as CFO and is one of the founders of the company. He previously worked as Finance Director of the Continental European division of Hazlewood Foods Plc and started his career at KPMG and is a graduate of Erasmus University in Rotterdam. He is also a postgraduate chartered accountant. Vincent joined Refresco in 2002 when Refresco acquired D´elifruits. Vincent has fulfilled several managerial and commercial positions within the Group including his latest position as Group Managing Director reporting into the Executive Board. He is a graduate of Institut Sup´erieur d’Agriculture, Lille and holds a MBA from EMLYON business school. Brad joined Refresco in 2018 when Refresco acquired Cott TB. Brad held the position of President of North America at Cott TB at time of the acquisition. Prior roles include roles at the Kellogg Company of which he was a Senior Vice President prior joining Cott TB. He graduated for his MBA at the Ohio State University. PAI and BCI have worked actively together on acquiring Refresco since 2014 and have developed deep insight into our business and our key markets. They submitted a firm bid for the acquisition of Refresco in 2015, before we chose to publicly list our shares. In addition, PAI is a committed sponsor with strong expertise and an outstanding track record in the Food & Consumer sector with 19 standout buyouts in the sector since 2000, including the investments in Froneri, Labeyrie, Panzani and Yoplait. We believe that the market knowledge and leadership capabilities of our management team, combined with our Equity Investors’ track records of accomplishments, will enable us to continue to successfully implement our strategy. 6 -----

21APR201820314551 We are particularly strong in the juice category and in the Benelux region and also have identified growth opportunities in water, a category in which we are currently underrepresented by market share. We believe that our focus on balancing our product portfolio has helped us to limit our exposure to CSD and juice categories in 2017 to 32% and 20%, respectively. Simultaneously, we are enhancing our presence in fast growing categories, such as energy drinks (7% of our volume as of December 31, 2017), RTD Tea (11% of our volume as of December 31, 2017) and water (19% of our volume as of December 31, 2017) through better access to technologies and scale advantages. Our broad array of product and packaging offerings, geographic diversification and the combination of retailer brands and contract manufacturing, add stability and sustainability to our business and allows us to adapt to potential future changes in the industry and the markets in which we operate. We also expect to be able to leverage our new platform to expand our product offering and access new clients. The below chart shows our production capabilities across our countries and regions: |Col1|Benelux|Germany|UK|France|Iberia|Italy|Finland|Poland|US|Canada|Mexico| |---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---| |Cans PET Aseptic PET Carton Glass Bag in a box CSD NCSD|||||||||||| _Hot fill_ 20APR201820465395 4 ----- Furthermore, our diverse offering improves our competitive position for both retailer brands and contract manufacturing volume tenders. A-brand owners often look for contract manufacturers that have sufficient scale and geographic scope and to provide the production flexibility to meet their requirements in multiple markets. Retailer brands customers stand to gain by reducing sourcing complexity and costs by working with the same manufacturer across various regions and packaging types.

Subsubsection Title: Capture organic growth in both retailer brands and contract manufacturing
Subsubsection Text: Above-market organic growth in retailer brands:_ We aim to consolidate our leadership positions by achieving growth rates that are slightly higher than the retailer brands soft drinks market volume growth. In order to achieve this, we have identified three key focus areas. First, we will seek to drive growth by completing our portfolio across products and packaging types. Second, we aim to further grow the market share of our retailer brands business, with a particular focus on discounters. Third, we expect a high level of innovation and new product development to contribute to retailer brands volume growth. Growth in sports and energy drinks and RTD tea is also a priority. Contract manufacturing expansion with existing and new customers:_ We aim to increase our contract manufacturing business both in the near- and long-term. The contract manufacturing segment is large, resilient and growing, with significant contract opportunities available to scale players. Branded players are increasingly focused on an ‘‘asset-light’’ strategy given lower returns on manufacturing investment than in core marketing activities, leading them to increasingly favor outsourcing of additional volume. We have a well-developed contract manufacturing business with an unmatched track record with A-brands, while Cott TB offers a platform to further develop the contract manufacturing opportunity in the U.S. Branded players are increasingly looking for manufacturing players able to serve them throughout the footprint and we believe we are uniquely positioned to service customers across multiple categories and geographies.

We plan to continue to execute our ‘‘buy-and-build’’ strategy by making selective investments and acquisitions. Our management believes in the added value of acquisitive growth and maintains a clear framework in order to evaluate the attractiveness of individual opportunities, both in existing and adjacent markets. We have a strong track record of consolidating the industry across Europe and the U.S., as evidenced by the acquisitions of DIS and Whitlock in 2016 and Cott TB in 2018. Over the last 17 years, we have acquired over 20 companies and have demonstrated excellent capabilities to extract synergies. We believe there are a number of tangible value-creating opportunities to further consolidate existing markets, in both Europe and North America, and expand into new adjacent markets. However, we maintain a prudent approach in assessing any investment decision using the following criteria to assess potential targets: (i) the possibility to exploit operational synergy potential; (ii) the extent to which the target’s business complements our product and packaging offering; and (iii) whether acquiring the target would reinforce our leading local position. Our framework sets out specific factors to consider when evaluating a potential acquisition, such as synergy potential and reinforcement of leading local positions, and priority areas for acquisitions in terms of region, product, packaging and channel that align with our overall strategic objectives.

We continually strive for operational excellence in order to improve our cost base. Examples of this include investments in fully automated and higher-speed production lines, and specific targets for reducing energy, waste and water usage with increased recycling rates. Further, additional operational improvement opportunities have been identified in procurement, plant network optimization and Overall Equipment Effectiveness (‘‘OEE’’). The identified procurement categories are grouped in three main areas: raw materials (e.g. orange, carbohydrates, apple), packaging (e.g. cans, liquid paper board, PET) and indirect spend (e.g. transport and warehousing, technical goods and services, utilities and waste). Furthermore, while we have a solid industrial network, we continue to see optimization potential in our asset base which is somewhat fragmented. We expect that optimizing our network and improving its effectiveness could lead to substantial annual savings, consisting primarily of network restructuring, OEE improvements, footprint rationalization and operational synergies. 7 -----

Subsubsection Title: Focus on full synergy extraction resulting from our acquisition of Cott TB
Subsubsection Text: Our acquisition of Cott TB provides significant and tangible value creation opportunities. Our ambition is to achieve run-rate synergies of A62.8 million in the first three years after the transaction, which represents 4.3% of Cott TB’s 2017 revenue. These synergies were identified by management with assistance from third-party due diligence providers. There are three categories of synergies: procurement, operations and overhead, each respectively representing 2.3%, 1.5% and 0.5% of Cott TB’s 2017 revenue. Procurement synergies are expected to amount to 54% of the total synergies, or A34.0 million, and are anticipated to be generated through price harmonization and volume bundling, which we expect to realize relatively quickly. Operational synergies are estimated to account for 35% of the total synergies, representing A22.0 million, and are expected to come principally from transfer of lines and plant closures. Finally, the remaining 11% of synergies are anticipated to come from overhead synergies, reaching A6.8 million and are anticipated to be achieved through headcount and office space lease reductions. We expect the phasing of synergies to have a ramp-up schedule of 30/60/95/100% from 2018 until 2021, and will require the incurrence of implementation and investment costs to achieve. No commercial (dis)-synergies are anticipated. Implementation and investment costs are assumed to be approximately 94% of run-rate synergies, split over three years as follows:

We have built a scalable platform through the successful integration of multiple acquisitions. Together with our historical focus on profitable growth, we believe this has resulted in a competitive position combining scale and profitability above other players. We aim to continue to leverage our platform, drive profitable growth and improve our operational excellence.

We have historically been prudent in our communication of synergies. Statements concerning our synergies and related implementation and investment costs are based on our Equity Investors’ and management’s current belief, as to the outcome and timing of future events. We caution you that forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and are based on numerous assumptions and that our actual synergies and related implementation and investment costs may differ materially from the forward-looking statements included here. You should read the information set forth herein in conjunction with ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations—We _may fail to realize the business growth opportunities, margin benefits and other synergies anticipated from, or may incur unanticipated costs or be exposed to unexpected liabilities associated with or resulting from the Cott TB Acquisition.’’_

_The Tender Offer_ On October 3, 2017, after several previous approaches, the Equity Investors approached Refresco’s Boards with a revised proposal of a recommended public offer (the ‘‘Tender Offer’’) of A19.75 per Refresco Share in cash (cum dividend). On October 18, 2017, Refresco entered into detailed negotiations with the Equity Investors. Refresco’s Boards received extensive financial and legal advice and gave careful consideration to the strategic, financial and social aspects and consequences of the proposed transaction. Following various meetings and negotiations, the consideration offered by the Equity Investors was increased to A20.00 per Refresco Share (cum dividend) (the ‘‘Offer Price’’) representing an aggregate consideration of approximately A1,623 million assuming the acquisition of 100% of the Refresco Shares. On October 24, 2017, Sunshine Investments B.V. and Refresco Group N.V. entered into a merger protocol (the ‘‘Merger Protocol’’), which set forth the principal terms and condition of the Acquisition and the Tender Offer. In addition, irrevocable undertakings with certain major shareholders of Refresco to tender all shares held by them in Refresco were agreed. On January 22, 2018, the AFM approved the tender offer memorandum setting out the key terms of the Tender Offer. On January 23, 2018, Sunshine Investments B.V. launched the Tender Offer, subject to certain conditions. 8 ----- Refresco’s extraordinary general meeting of shareholders (the ‘‘EGM’’) was held on March 5, 2018. At the EGM, the shareholders approved: (i) the amendment of the Articles of Association of Refresco to allow the company to be converted from a public limited liability company (naamloze vennootschap) to a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) following the de-listing of Refresco; and (ii) the appointment of the new members of the Supervisory Board and the discharge of the resigning members of the Supervisory Board (as further described in ‘‘Management’’). When the initial acceptance period expired on March 19, 2018 (the ‘‘Acceptance Closing Date’’), 97.4% of the Refresco Shares had been tendered, and consequently the minimum acceptance level, as well as the other conditions to the Tender Offer, were satisfied. On March 29, 2018, the initial settlement of the Tender Offer occurred, and Sunshine Investments B.V. acquired 97.4% of the Refresco Shares. On April 3, 2018, the post-acceptance period expired with 2.0% of the Refresco Shares having been tendered. On April 9, 2018 (the ‘‘Post-Acceptance Settlement Date’’), the settlement of the post-acceptance period tenders occurred and Sunshine Investments B.V. acquired 2.0% of the Refresco Shares. In aggregate, Sunshine Investments B.V. acquired 99.4% of the Refresco Shares. On March 29, 2018, Refresco repaid its outstanding syndicated term loan facility in an aggregate principal amount of A1,831.4 million (equivalent) using proceeds from the Term Loan B Facility. However, A24.7 million of existing debt of Refresco comprised of the Mortgage Loan and finance leases as of December 31, 2017 was not refinanced as part of the Transactions. _De-Listing and Squeeze-Out_ On March 26, 2018, Sunshine Investments B.V. commenced the process of de-listing Refresco from Euronext Amsterdam. Euronext Amsterdam has confirmed that it has given its consent to the de-listing request. De-listing will take place on April 26, 2018 and the last day that the Refresco Shares can be traded on Euronext will therefore be April 25, 2018. The conversion to a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) (the ‘‘Conversion’’) is expected to occur shortly following the de-listing. Following the Conversion, Sunshine Investments B.V. intends to commence a compulsory acquisition procedure in accordance with article 2:92a or 2:201a of the Dutch civil code (Burgerlijk Wetboek) (the ‘‘DCC’’) or the takeover buy-out procedure in accordance with article 2:359c of the DCC to buy out the shareholders who have not tendered their Refresco Shares under the Tender Offer (the ‘‘Squeeze-Out’’). A Squeeze-Out typically takes three to six months to complete, but it would take longer in the event that shareholders file objections. Following the Squeeze-Out, we expect that Sunshine Investments B.V. will own 100% of the Refresco Shares. _Post-Squeeze-Out Mergers_ Following the completion of the Squeeze-Out, we expect to merge Refresco Holding B.V. into Refresco Group N.V., which will have been converted into a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap _met beperkte aansprakelijkheid). We then expect to merge Refresco Group N.V. into Sunshine_ Investments B.V. Please see ‘‘—Summary Corporate and Financing Structure’’ for further information on our expected structure following (a) the completion of the Squeeze-Out and (b) following the Post-Squeeze-Out Mergers. _Sources and Uses for the Acquisition_ The funding sources for the Acquisition, the repayment of the syndicated term loan facility that was borrowed in connection with the Cott TB Acquisition and the payment of related fees and expenses consist of the following: - equity contributions from the Equity Investors in the form of equity and quasi-equity (including common and preferred equity instruments and deeply subordinated shareholder loans) totaling an amount of approximately A982.8 million (the ‘‘Equity Contribution’’), the proceeds of which have been contributed to Sunshine Investments B.V. through the Issuer and intermediate holding companies (see ‘‘—Summary Corporate and Financing Structure’’); - drawings by Sunshine Investments B.V. under the Term Loan B Facility in an aggregate amount of A1,958.5 million (equivalent); 9 ----- - drawings by Sunshine Investments B.V. under the Revolving Credit Facility in an aggregate amount of approximately A90.0 million; - drawings by the Issuer under the Bridge Facility in an aggregate amount of A445.0 million, the proceeds of which have been on-lent to Sunshine Investments B.V. and which will be refinanced with the proceeds from the Offering (see ‘‘—The Refinancing’’); and - cash on hand in an aggregate amount of approximately A46.7 million. The notional sources and uses necessary to consummate the Acquisition, repay Refresco’s syndicated term loan facility and pay related fees and expenses are shown in the table below. The funding sources described above and the sources and uses in the table below show the acquisition of 100% of the Refresco Shares, which we expect to occur following the Squeeze-Out. Actual amounts may vary from the notional amounts presented here based on a variety of factors, including differences from our estimate of fees and expenses.

In connection with the Acquisition, the Issuer entered into the Bridge Facility Agreement that provides for the A445.0 million Bridge Facility, which was drawn by the Issuer and on-lent to Sunshine Investments B.V. on March 28, 2018. Sunshine Investments B.V. used the proceeds from such intercompany loan, the Equity Contributions from the Equity Investors and drawings under the Term Loan B Facility, to finance its acquisition of the Refresco Shares pursuant to the Tender Offer and to pay certain costs and expenses in connection therewith as described above in ‘‘—The Acquisition.’’ The proceeds from the Offering will be used together with cash on hand at the Issuer to refinance amounts that were incurred under the Bridge Facility and to pay the costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Offering as described in ‘‘—Use of Proceeds of the Offering.’’ 10 -----

The proceeds of the Offering will be used to refinance amounts drawn under the Bridge Facility. The Term Loan B Facility includes a euro-denominated tranche in an initial principal amount of A1,217 million, a U.S. dollar-denominated tranche in an initial principal amount of $620 million and a British pound-tranche in an initial principal amount of £200 million. The Senior Credit Facilities Agreement also provides for the Revolving Credit Facility in an amount of A200 million and an uncommitted incremental facility. As of the date of this offering memorandum, the Term Loan B Facility has been drawn in full and the Revolving Credit Facility has been drawn in an amount of A90.0 million in connection with Acquisition. (4) Represents cash of Refresco Group N.V. that was used to pay a portion of the transaction costs and other payments in connection with the Acquisition. As of the date of this offering memorandum, Sunshine Investments B.V. holds 99.4% of the Refresco Shares. Additional fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Refinancing are not included. See ‘‘—Use of Proceeds of the Offering.’’

Subsection Title: Use of Proceeds of the Offering
Subsubsection Text: We estimate that the gross proceeds of the Offering will be A445.0 million. The Issuer will use the proceeds from the Offering to refinance amounts that were incurred under the Bridge Facility and to pay the costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Offering. See ‘‘—The Refinancing.’’ The estimated sources and uses necessary to consummate the Refinancing are shown in the table below. Actual amounts may vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including the gross proceeds from the Notes offered hereby, accrued interest on the Bridge Facility and differences to our estimates of fees and expenses. Any changes in these amounts may be reflected as an increase or decrease, as applicable, in the amount of cash. This table should be read in conjunction with ‘‘Capitalization.’’

(1) Represents the gross proceeds of the Offering assuming an issue price at par. (2) Refinancing costs include estimated fees and expenses associated with the Refinancing, excluding accrued interest on the Bridge Facility. These fees and costs have been estimated as of the date of this offering memorandum and are subject to change. Other expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions other than the Refinancing were paid by the Issuer, Sunshine Investments B.V. and Refresco and are excluded from this presentation. See ‘‘—The Transactions—Sources and Uses for the _Acquisition.’’_

All of the equity of the Issuer is held by Sunshine Holding B.V., a wholly owned subsidiary of Sunshine Top B.V., which is a wholly owned subsidiary of Sunshine Equity B.V., which is in turn beneficially owned by intermediate holding companies controlled by our Equity Investors. Our Equity Investors are PAI Partners (‘‘PAI’’) and British Columbia Investment Management Corporation (‘‘BCI’’). We expect our principal shareholders to also include Management Participants by the end of the second quarter of 2018. See ‘‘Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Equity Investment by Management Participants.’’ PAI Partners is a major European private equity firm and is the largest private equity investor headquartered in Paris, with additional offices in London, Madrid, Munich, Milan, Luxembourg, New York and Stockholm. PAI Partners manages and advises private equity funds representing approximately A12.3 billion. Since 1994, PAI has invested c.A10 billion in 65 buyout transactions in 11 countries, representing close to A50 billion in transaction value, and has returned A17 billion of cash proceeds, representing a 2.6x gross MoC and 30% gross IRR on realized investments. PAI has a strong and consistent investment track record and in March 2018, PAI closed its largest fund (PAI Europe VII) with commitments of A5.1 billion. PAI is a committed sponsor with strong expertise and an outstanding track record in the Food & Consumer sector with 19 standout buyouts in the sector since 2000, including the investments in Froneri, Labeyrie, Panzani and Yoplait. BCI is one of Canada’s largest institutional investors within the global capital markets with C$135.5 billion of managed net assets. BCI is based in Victoria, British Columbia and is a long-term investor that invests in all major asset classes including private equity. BCI’s clients include public sector pension plans, public trusts, and insurance funds. BCI’s Private Equity team invests globally in both fund and direct investments, with the majority of exposure in North America, Europe and Asia. Its primary focus sectors include healthcare, industrials, business services, financial services, telecommunications, media & technology and consumer retail. The team is currently comprised of 20 investment professionals and has C$7.8 billion in assets under management. Selected private equity investments of BCI include Pilot Freight Services and Hayfin.

The Issuer was formed to facilitate the Transactions and is a private company with limited liability (besloten _vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) incorporated in and existing under the laws of the_ Netherlands, having its official seat in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, with its registered office at Prins Bernhardplein 200, 1097 JB Amsterdam, the Netherlands, and registered with the trade register of the Dutch Chamber of Commerce under number 69882967. 11 -----

On January 30, 2018, Refresco acquired Cott Corporation’s North America (including the U.S. and Canadian businesses), United Kingdom and Mexico business units and its RCI finished goods export business but excluding RCI’s other businesses, the Columbus facility and Aimia (‘‘Cott TB’’ or the ‘‘Cott Traditional Business’’) pursuant to an acquisition agreement dated July 25, 2017 between Refresco Group N.V. and Cott Corporation. The purchase price of $1,259.9 million was financed by a syndicated term loan facility, which was refinanced as a part of the Acquisition. See ‘‘—The Transactions—The _Acquisition—Sources and Uses for the Acquisition.’’ Refresco also closed deal-contingent U.S. dollar-_ denominated hedges for a total amount of $750 million to hedge the U.S. dollar cash out flow relating the transaction. The integration of the two companies in North America commenced after closing. In the UK, we were able to begin integrating Cott TB’s UK operations into our business following the acceptance by the Competition and Markets Authority of the sale of the Nelson A-PET facility to Sunmagic Juice. The Nelson A-PET facility accounted for 10 million liters of Cott TB’s volume of 3,937.9 million liters in the financial year 2017. The Cott TB Acquisition was completed to address expected retailer brands market growth in the U.S. driven by the expansion of discounters, expanding footprint of online retailers and macro factors. We believe that the acquisition of the Cott Traditional Business is a unique transaction for Refresco and that our customers will benefit from access to an enhanced network combining our strong European capabilities and Cott TB’s strength in North America. We are particularly enthusiastic about the opportunity to further develop our business for retail customers in North America. Refresco nearly doubled the size of its business through the Cott TB Acquisition gaining approximately 4,400 new colleagues and 29 manufacturing sites in North America and the UK and enabling it to provide retailers and A-brands with greater access to reliable supply chain solutions in key beverage markets. Cott TB is well established in this segment with more than 85% of its bottling activities being for leading retailers in the U.S. and the UK. In terms of contract manufacturing, Cott TB’s rapidly growing share of this market further strengthens our prominent position as an independent bottling partner for A-brands on both continents. Combining this strong market position with Refresco’s knowledge, experience and best practices across Europe will provide us a solid platform on which to support further growth. Please refer to ‘‘Presentation of Financial Information,’’ ‘‘—Summary Historical Combined Carve-out _Financial Information and Other Financial and Operating Data of Cott TB,’’ ‘‘Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Cott TB’’ and the Cott TB Carve-out Financial_ Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum for further information on the Cott Traditional Business. _Share Purchase Agreement_ On July 24, 2017, Refresco Group N.V. and Cott Corporation entered into a Share Purchase Agreement (‘‘SPA’’) governing the sale of Cott TB to Refresco. Under the SPA, the parties have agreed that within a specified period following the closing date of the Cott TB Acquisition, Refresco will calculate the post-closing adjustments and deliver them to Cott Corporation, so that Cott Corporation can adjust the estimated consideration accordingly. Cott Corporation then has 45 days after the delivery of the post-closing adjustments to either accept or object to them. If Cott Corporation fails to reject Refresco’s post-closing adjustments, they will become binding. If Cott Corporation objects, the parties will attempt to negotiate an agreement, and if they cannot reach agreement, either party can submit the matter to a specified third party to reach a final and binding determination on the matter. Cott Corporation has provided Refresco with customary representations and warranties relating to, among other things, Cott Corporation’s organization and conduct, authority to enter into the agreement, and title to relevant equity interests, assets and liabilities and tax matters. Following the closing date, Cott Corporation has agreed to indemnify Refresco from any damages arising from, among other things: (i) any breach of or inaccuracy in a representation or warranty of Cott TB or of Cott Corporation, (ii) any breach of or failure to perform by Cott Corporation under any of its covenants, (iii) any transaction expenses, company indebtedness or post-closing adjustments. If any indemnifying party fails to pay an indemnified party any due amount within an agreed period of notice from the 12 ----- indemnified party, the indemnifying party will reimburse the indemnified party for all reasonable costs incurred in connection with the collection of such amount.

We have begun the first phase of construction on new manufacturing site and warehouse in Le Quesnoy, France. This plant will replace our current plant in Le Quesnoy, France used for carton production and will house the carton production facilities as well as two new A-PET lines, which we are building in connection with a long-term contract with an A-brand. Production is scheduled to begin in approximately 24 months. We expect to invest approximately A43.6 million for this facility in 2018, which amount will be funded partially through third-party financing and operating leases.
We believe that volume and Adjusted EBITDA are developing in line with expectations and that our implementation of expected synergies is progressing as planned. 13 -----

(the ‘‘Proceeds Loan’’), any other intercompany receivables owed to the Issuer by Sunshine Investments B.V. and the Issuer’s material bank accounts located in the Netherlands. See ‘‘Summary—The Offering—Collateral.’’ The Notes will be effectively subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the Issuer and its subsidiaries that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes or the Note Guarantees or that is secured on a first-ranking basis over property and assets that secure the Notes or the Note Guarantees on a second-ranking basis (including obligations under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations), to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness. (6) The Notes will be guaranteed by Sunshine Investments B.V. on the Issue Date. As of the date of this offering memorandum, Sunshine Investments B.V. owns approximately 99.4% of the Refresco Shares. We expect Sunshine Investments B.V. will own 100% of the Refresco Shares following the Squeeze-Out. See ‘‘The Transactions.’’ All subsidiaries of Sunshine Investments B.V. are 100% owned by members of the Group except for Refresco Deutschland Holding GmbH in Germany in which the Group holds a 90% interest, Northeast Retailer Brands LLC in the U.S. in which the Group holds a 51% interest, Entsorgungs GmbH in Germany in which the Group holds a 40% interest and Genprobio Srl in Italy in which the Group holds a 20% interest. Following the completion of the Squeeze-Out, Refresco Holding B.V. is expected to merge into Refresco Group N.V. (which will have already been converted into a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid)). Refresco Group N.V. will subsequently merge into Sunshine Investments B.V. (collectively, the ‘‘Post-Squeeze-Out Mergers’’). (7) In connection with the Acquisition, Sunshine Investments B.V. entered into the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement. The Senior Credit Facilities Agreement provides for facilities in the form of (a) the Term Loan B Facility in an amount of A1,958.5 million (equivalent) based on an EUR/USD exchange rate of A1.00/$1.20 and a EUR/GBP exchange rate of A1.00/£0.89 as of December 31, 2017, (b) the committed Revolving Credit Facility in an amount of up to A200 million and (c) uncommitted ancillary facilities. All of the Guarantors and the Issuer will guarantee the Senior Credit Facilities on a senior basis and such guarantees will rank senior to the Note Guarantors of each Guarantor and pari passu with the Notes. The Senior Credit Facilities will be secured by the Shared Collateral on a firstranking basis as of the Issue Date. See ‘‘Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Credit _Facilities Agreement.’’ As of the date of this offering memorandum, the Term Loan B Facility has been_ drawn in full and the Revolving Credit Facility has been drawn in an amount of A90.0 million. (8) On the Completion Date, Sunshine Investments B.V. contributed A1,817.5 million of the proceeds of the Term Loan B Facility to Refresco in order to repay Refresco’s syndicated term loan facility borrowed in connection with the Cott TB Transaction. A24.7 million of existing debt as of December 31, 2017 comprised of the Mortgage Loan, other loans and finance leases will remain outstanding following the Issue Date. (9) Refresco Group N.V. is currently listed on Euronext Amsterdam. We have filed a de-listing request with Euronext Amsterdam and we intend to subsequently convert Refresco into a private limited liability company. Euronext Amsterdam has given its consent to the de-listing request. De-listing will take place on April 26, 2018 and the last day that the Refresco Shares can be traded on Euronext will therefore be April 25, 2018. (10) Subject to certain adjustments and the agreed security principles in the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement will require Sunshine Investments B.V. to ensure that its subsidiaries that are members of the restricted group under the Senior Credit Facilities that generate at least 80% of ‘‘Consolidated EBITDA’’ (as defined in the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement) are guarantors under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement: (i) on the date which is 120 days after the date on which Refresco Group N.V. has been converted into a private limited liability company (the ‘‘Control Date’’); and (ii) the date when the annual financial statements are required to be delivered to the agent under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement. We anticipate that following the accession of the guarantors to the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Notes will be guaranteed by either (a) Refresco Benelux B.V., 16 ----- Refresco Americas B.V., Gerber Emig Group Limited, Refresco Beverages UK Limited, Refresco Holding B.V., Refresco Europe B.V., Refresco Canada Inc., Refresco Beverages US Inc. (formerly Cott Beverages Inc.), Cliffstar LLC, DIS B.V. and Cott Beverages Limited, or (b) such other combination of Restricted Subsidiaries of the Issuer as provide a guarantee of the Senior Credit Facilities on or prior to the date falling 120 days after the Control Date (the ‘‘Post-Control Date Guarantors’’ and, together with Sunshine Investments B.V., the ‘‘Guarantors’’). Only our subsidiaries that are required to provide a guarantee under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, will be Post-Control Date Guarantors. Certain of our subsidiaries in Italy and France that may provide a guarantee of the Senior Credit Facilities will not provide a Note Guarantee. In addition, none of our subsidiaries in Germany or Mexico will provide a Note Guarantee. Each Note Guarantee will be a senior subordinated obligation of the relevant Guarantor. The Note Guarantees will be subordinated in right of payment to any existing and future senior indebtedness of that Guarantor (including obligations under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations). The Notes will be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the Issuer’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Notes, including their obligations to trade creditors. For the year ended December 31, 2017, the Issuer and the Post-Control Date Guarantors (as listed in clause (a) of the definition in the ‘‘Description of the Notes’’) accounted for 65.4% of our _pro forma Adjusted EBITDA. (11) OKIL Holding 2 B.V. has acquired 10% of the shares of Refresco Deutschland Holding GmbH from Refresco Europe B.V. for consideration of A15.6 million. Refresco Deutschland Holding GmbH has deferred OKIL Holding 2 B.V.’s obligation to pay consideration for the transaction. See ‘‘Certain _Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Minority Owner of Refresco Deutschland Holding GmbH.’’_ 17 -----

Subsection Title: Ranking of the Notes and the Note
Subsubsection Text: Guarantees . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will: - be general senior obligations of the Issuer; - rank _pari passu in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s existing and future obligations that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes; - rank senior in right of payment to subordinated indebtedness of the Issuer; 18 ----- - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the Issuer and its subsidiaries that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Notes or that is secured on a first-priority basis over property and assets that secure the Notes on a second-priority basis (including, in each case, obligations under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations), to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such obligation or indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of the Issuer that do not guarantee the Notes, including their obligations to trade creditors. Each Note Guarantee will: - be a senior subordinated obligation of the relevant Guarantor; - be subordinated in right of payment to any existing and future senior indebtedness of that Guarantor (including obligations under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations); - rank _pari passu in right of payment with all existing and future senior subordinated indebtedness of that Guarantor; and - rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future indebtedness of that Guarantor that is subordinated in right of payment to its Note Guarantee. Collateral . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain perfection requirements, the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be secured on the Issue Date: - on a first-ranking basis, by security over the shares in the capital of the Issuer held by Sunshine Holding B.V. and security over all intercompany receivables owed to Sunshine Holding B.V. by the Issuer, including the shareholder loan of A100.0 million made to the Issuer by its direct parent on March 28, 2018 (the ‘‘First-Ranking Collateral’’); and - on a second-ranking basis, by security over the shares in the capital of Sunshine Investments B.V. held by the Issuer, the Proceeds Loan any other intercompany receivables owed to the Issuer by Sunshine Investments B.V. and the Issuer’s material bank accounts located in the Netherlands (the ‘‘Shared Collateral’’). The Shared Collateral also secures or will secure the Senior Credit Facilities and certain hedging obligations on a firstranking basis. The First-Ranking Collateral, the Shared Collateral and any and all other assets from time to time in which a security interest has been or will be granted pursuant to any security document to secure the obligations under the Indenture, the Notes and/or any Note Guarantee are collectively referred to as the ‘‘Collateral.’’ 19 ----- The security interests may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. For more information on the security interests granted, see ‘‘Description of the Notes—Security’’ and for more information on potential limitations to the security interests, see ‘‘Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Security Interests _and Any Note Guarantees’’ and ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and the Notes.’’_ The security interests over the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our _Indebtedness and the Notes—There are circumstances other than the repayment or discharge of the Notes under which a Note Guarantee or the Collateral securing the Notes will be released automatically without your consent or the Trustee or the Security Agent obtaining your further consent,’’ ‘‘Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement,’’ ‘‘Description of the Notes—Administration of Security and Enforcement of Liens—Release of Liens.’’_ Use of Proceeds . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Issuer will use the proceeds from the Offering, together with cash on hand, to refinance amounts drawn under the Bridge Facility and to pay the costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Offering. See ‘‘The Transactions—The _Refinancing’’ and ‘‘Use of Proceeds.’’_ Optional Redemption . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes at any time on or after, 2021 at the redemption prices as described under ‘‘Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.’’ At any time prior to, 2021, the Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption plus a ‘‘make-whole’’ premium, as described under ‘‘Description of the _Notes—Optional Redemption.’’_ At any time prior to, 2021, the Issuer may on one or more occasions redeem up to 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any Additional Notes) using the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to % of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption; provided that at least 60% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any Additional Notes) remains outstanding after the redemption. Additional Amounts . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Any payments made by the Issuer or any Guarantor with respect to the Notes will be made without withholding or deduction for taxes in any taxing jurisdiction unless required by law. If we are required by law to withhold or deduct for taxes of a relevant tax jurisdiction with respect to a payment to the holders of the Notes, we will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by the holders of the Notes after the withholding is not less than the amount that they would have received in the absence of the withholding, subject to certain exceptions. See ‘‘Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes.’’ Redemption for Taxation Reasons . . .** In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may redeem the Notes, as applicable, in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. See ‘‘Description of _the Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.’’_ 20 ----- Change of Control . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control, the Issuer will be required to make an offer to purchase the outstanding the Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of purchase. The definitions used in respect of a change of control expressly permit a third party to obtain control of the Issuer in a transaction which is a Specified Change of Control Event without any obligation to make an offer. See ‘‘Description of the _Notes—Change of Control.’’_ Tender Offers . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** In connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes. See ‘‘Description of the Notes— _Optional Redemption—General.’’_ Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture will limit, among other things, the ability of the Issuer and its Restricted Subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends on, redeem or repurchase the Issuer’s equity; - make investments; - prepay or redeem subordinated debt; - create or incur certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of subsidiaries to pay dividends or other payments to the Issuer; - transfer, lease or sell certain assets; - merge or consolidate with other entities; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and - impair the Security Interests in the Collateral. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if and for as long as the Notes achieve and maintain investment-grade ratings. See ‘‘Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of _Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status.’’_ Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See ‘‘Description _of_ _the_ _Notes—Certain _Covenants.’’_

Considerations . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** For a discussion of certain U.S. federal income tax considerations of an investment in the Notes, see ‘‘Certain Tax _Considerations—Certain_ _U.S._ _Federal_ _Income_ _Tax Considerations.’’ You should consult your own tax advisor to_ determine the U.S. federal, state, local and other tax consequences of an investment in the Notes. 21 ----- Original Issue Discount . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes may be issued with original issue discount (‘‘OID’’) for U.S. federal income tax purposes. In such event, U.S. holders (as defined under ‘‘Tax Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal _Income Tax Considerations—Original Issue Discount’’) generally_ will be required to include such OID in gross income (as ordinary income) on an annual basis under a constant yield accrual method regardless of their regular method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. As a result, U.S. holders will generally include any OID in income in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such income. See ‘‘Tax _Considerations—Certain_ _U.S._ _Federal_ _Income_ _Tax Considerations—Original Issue Discount.’’_ Transfer Restrictions . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes and the Note Guarantees have not been registered under the U.S. Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and will not be so registered. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See ‘‘Notice to _Investors.’’ Holders of the Notes will not have the benefit of any_ exchange or registration rights. Risk Factors . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. You should consider carefully all the information in this offering memorandum and, in particular, you should evaluate the specific risk factors set forth in the ‘‘Risk Factors’’ section of this offering memorandum before making a decision whether to invest in the Notes. No Established Market for the Notes .** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no established trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have informed us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market-making at any time without notice. Accordingly, there is no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the Notes. Listing . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the ‘‘Exchange’’). There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. Governing Law . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture and the Notes will be governed by the laws of the State of New York. The Intercreditor Agreement and the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement are governed by English law. The security documents are or will be governed by the applicable law of the jurisdiction under which the security interests are granted. Trustee . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Deutsche Trustee Company Limited. Security Agent . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Co¨operatieve Rabobank U.A. Paying Agent . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch. Registrar and Transfer Agent . . . . . .** Deutsche Bank Luxembourg S.A. Listing Agent . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Ogier Corporate Finance Limited. 22 -----

_The following summary of the Offering contains basic information about the Notes. It is not intended to be complete and it is subject to important limitations and exceptions. For a more complete description of the terms of the Notes, including certain definitions of terms used in this summary, see ‘‘Description of Certain Financing Arrangements’’ and ‘‘Description of the Notes.’’_ Issuer . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Sunshine Mid B.V. Notes Offered . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** A445,000,000 % Senior Notes due 2026. Issue Date . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** On or about . Issue Price . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** %. Maturity Date . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .**, 2026. Interest Rate . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** % per annum. Interest Payment Dates . . . . . . . . . . .** Interest is payable on the Notes, as applicable, semi-annually in arrears on May 15 and November 15 of each year, beginning on November 15, 2018. Interest on the Notes will accrue from the Issue Date. Form and Denomination . . . . . . . . . .** Each Note will have a minimum denomination of A100,000 and integral multiples of A1,000 in excess thereof maintained in book-entry form. Notes in denominations of less than A100,000 will not be available. Guarantors . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis: - on the Issue Date, by Sunshine Investments B.V.; and - subject to the Agreed Security Principles, no later than 120 days after the Control Date, by each of the Post-Control Date Guarantors. The obligations of each Guarantor will be limited as described under ‘‘Description of the Notes—The Note Guarantees.’’ Each Note Guarantee will be subject to certain contractual and legal limitations. See ‘‘Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the _Security Interests and any Note Guarantees.’’ Each Note_ Guarantee will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, including certain payment blockage, standstill and turnover provisions. See ‘‘Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.’’ Each Note Guarantee_ will be subject to release under certain circumstances. See ‘‘Description _of_ _the_ _Notes—The_ _Note_ _Guarantees—Note _Guarantee Release.’’_ For the year ended December 31, 2017, the Issuer and the Post-Control Date Guarantors (as listed in clause (a) of the definition thereof) accounted for 65.4% of our _pro forma Adjusted EBITDA.

Subsubsection Text: The following tables set forth summary historical consolidated financial information of Refresco Group N.V. as of and for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2016 and 2017, as well as certain other financial and operating data of Refresco. Refresco’s financial data has been extracted from the Refresco Financial Statements, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS and Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code and audited by Refresco’s independent auditor, EY, as set forth in its independent auditor’s reports included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. These historical results are not necessarily indicative of future results. In addition, certain non-GAAP financial measures are presented below that are not required by or presented in accordance with IFRS and should not be considered in insolation from or as substitutes for Refresco’s historical financial information. Non-GAAP financial measures should not be considered to be an alternative to any measure of liquidity or performance derived in accordance with IFRS.
