Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL COMBINED CARVE-OUT FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER FINANCIAL AND OPERATING DATA OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: SUMMARY PRO FORMA AND OTHER ADJUSTED FINANCIAL INFORMATION Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: The unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated balance sheet of the Issuer as of December 31, 2017, is based on and derived from (i) the audited consolidated balance sheet of Refresco as of December 31, 2017, prepared in accordance with IFRS, as adopted by the European Union (the ‘‘Refresco 2017 Balance Sheet’’); (ii) the audited combined carve-out balance sheet of Cott TB as of December 31, 2017, prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP (the ‘‘Cott TB 2017 Carve-Out Balance Sheet’’); (iii) unaudited condensed balance sheet information of Sunshine Investments B.V. as of December 31, 2017 prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP; and (iv) unaudited condensed balance sheet information of the Issuer as of as of December 31, 2017, prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. The unaudited _pro forma condensed consolidated income statement of the Issuer for the year ended December 31, 2017 is based on and derived from (i) the audited consolidated income statement of Refresco for the year ended December 31, 2017, prepared in accordance with IFRS, as adopted by the European Union (the ‘‘Refresco 2017 Income Statement’’); (ii) the audited combined carve-out income statement of Cott TB for the year ended December 31, 2017, prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP (the ‘‘Cott TB 2017 Carve-Out Income Statement’’); (iii) unaudited condensed income statement information of Sunshine Investments B.V. for the year ended December 31, 2017, prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP; and (iv) unaudited condensed income statement information of the Issuer for the year ended December 31, 2017, prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. For purposes of preparing the unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated financial information, certain adjustments have been made to the bases mentioned above (the ‘‘unaudited pro forma adjustments’’). The unaudited _pro forma adjustments are based on currently available financial information and certain assumptions that we believe are reasonable. The unaudited _pro forma condensed consolidated financial information gives effect to_ _pro forma adjustments that are directly attributable to the transactions described in the preceding paragraph and it does not reflect anticipated opereating efficiencies, cost savings or other synergies that may be achieved from the same transactions. The unaudited _pro forma condensed consolidated financial information is presented solely for informational purposes and is not intended to represent or be indicative of the consolidated income statements or financial position had the Transactions been completed as of the dates and for the periods 30 ----- presented, nor is it necessarily indicative of future results. The Unaudited _Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information should be read in conjunction with ‘‘Use of Proceeds,’’ ‘‘Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Refresco,’’ ‘‘Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Cott TB,’’ ‘‘The Transactions,’’_ and the Refresco Financial Statements and related notes and the Cott TB Financial Statements and related notes, in each case, included elsewhere in the offering memorandum. The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information does not reflect any changes in the business of Refresco or Cott TB or any other changes arising from the Transactions since December 31, 2017. Rounding adjustments have been made in calculating some of the pro forma financial information included herein. Figures shown as totals in some tables and elsewhere may not be exact arithmetic aggregations of the figures that precede them.

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL COMBINED CARVE-OUT FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER FINANCIAL AND OPERATING DATA OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: SUMMARY PRO FORMA AND OTHER ADJUSTED FINANCIAL INFORMATION Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information
Subsubsection Title: Accounting for the Acquisition and the Cott TB Acquisition
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer, through Sunshine Investments B.V., its wholly owned subsidiary, acquired 99.378% of the Refresco Shares as of April 9, 2018, for cash consideration of A1,613 million and expects to acquire the remaining Refresco Shares for cash consideration of approximately A10 million pursuant to the Squeeze-Out as described in ‘‘The Transactions—The Acqusition—The Squeeze-Out. On January 30, 2018, Refresco acquired Cott TB for a purchase price of $1,259.9 million. The Cott TB Acquisition and the Acquisition will be accounted for by the Issuer under IFRS, as adopted by the European Union, using the acquisition method as defined by IFRS 3 Business Combinations (‘‘IFRS 3’’). Under IFRS 3, assets acquired and liabilities assumed are recorded at their respective fair value on the date of acquisition and the consideration transferred is allocated to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed separately from goodwill. As of the date of this offering memorandum, the unaudited _pro forma condensed consolidated financial information presented in this offering memorandum is based_ on a preliminary allocation of the consideration transferred to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed, based on the historical carrying amounts of such assets and liabilities included in the Refresco Financial Statements and the Cott TB Financial Statements, in each case, as of and for the year ended December 31, 2017. The valuation studies necessary to finalize the fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed and the related allocation of the consideration transferred have not been completed. Therefore, the difference between (a) the total expected consideration transferred and (b) the net carrying amounts of the identifiable assets acquired and the liabilities assumed by Refresco on the completion date of the Cott TB Acquisition and by the Issuer the Completion Date, respectively, has been fully allocated to goodwill in the unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated balance sheet. A final determination of fair value on the date of acquisition of the assets acquired and the liabilities assumed may differ significantly from the amounts reflected in the Issuer’s unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated balance sheet included herein and, among other things, could result in a material change in our amortization and depreciation expense relating to identifiable assets acquired. Management believes that significant changes in the amount of goodwill recognized in relation to the Acquisition and/or the Cott TB Acquisition may arise due to the final dtermination of the purchase price allocation. 31 -----

Subsubsection Text: The unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated financial information has been prepared for illustrative purposes only to give effect to the following transactions: - the sale of 10% of the shares of Refresco Deutschland Holding GmbH by Refresco Europe B.V. to OKIL 2 Holdings B.V. in exchange for consideration of A15.6 million (see ‘‘Certain Relationships and _Related Party Transactions—Minority Ownership of Refresco Deutschland Holding GmbH’’);_ - the Cott TB Acquisition and the Acquisition (defined as the acquisition by Sunshine Investments B.V. of 97.4% of the shares of Refresco Group N.V. on March 29, 2018, and its subsequent acquisition of additional shares on April 9, 2018, which increased Sunshine Investments B.V.’s ownership stake in Refresco Group N.V.’s share capital to 99.378%); - the refinancing on the Completion Date of Refresco’s syndicated term loan facility outstanding as of December 31, 2017 with proceeds of the Term Loan B Facility and the refinancing with proceeds of such syndicated term loan facility or repayment by Cott Corporation of Cott TB’s indebtedness outstanding as of December 31, 2017 on January 30, 2018 as part of the Cott TB Acquisition; - the financing of the Acquisition with proceeds of the Equity Contribution, the Bridge Facility and the Senior Credit Facilities, in each case, as described in further detail in ‘‘The Transactions—The _Acquisition;’’_ - the Refinancing; and - the payment of costs, fees and expenses related to the foregoing; as if these transactions had occurred on January 1, 2017 for purposes of the income statement and as if these transactions had occured on December 31, 2017 for purposes of the balance sheet.

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL COMBINED CARVE-OUT FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER FINANCIAL AND OPERATING DATA OF COTT TB
SUMMARY HISTORICAL COMBINED CARVE-OUT FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER FINANCIAL AND OPERATING DATA OF COTT TB
Subsubsection Text: (a) Reflects adjustments related to (i) unusually high production volumes in 2017, which generated additional logistics and storage costs of approximately A2 million, (ii) one-off costs of approximately A4 million relating to operational inefficiencies and start-up costs incurred as a result of the implementation of new A-PET lines in the UK and Benelux in the second and third quarters of 2017 and (iii) one-off costs of approximately A3 million incurred as the result of delays in the transfer of lines and related volumes to other production facilities following the closures of a plant in Poland and a plant in Benelux. (b) Reflects management’s estimates of incremental EBITDA that would have been generated in the year ended December 31, 2017 in the event that the weather in the third quarter of 2017 had been consistent with historical temperature and precipitation levels. In the third quarter of 2017, Europe experienced unusually low temperature and high rain in summer 2017 compared to the five-year historical average. Refresco’s Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2017, as further adjusted to include the operation and weather adjustments described in these footnotes (a) and (b), amounts to A227.9 million. (c) Our ambition is to achieve run-rate synergies of A62.8 million in the first three years after the transaction, which represents 4.3% of Cott TB’s 2017 revenue. The adjustment of A43.7 million reflects management’s and the Equity Investors’ estimates of the total potential forward-looking run-rate synergies that could be realized in the first 18 months as a result of the Cott TB Acquisition based on due diligence estimates. These synergies are described in further detail below: (i) Relates to integration and streamlining of our combined organization, which will be achieved through headcount and office space lease reductions. (ii) Relates to the realization of certain operating efficiencies, which will primarily be achieved through the transfer of production lines and plant closures. (iii) Relates to raw materials and packaging procurement cost savings which are expected to be generated through price harmonization and volume bundling. 34 -----

Subsubsection Text: The following tables set forth summary historical combined carve-out financial information of Cott TB as of and for the years ended January 2, 2016 (‘‘financial year ended 2015’’), December 31, 2016 (‘‘financial year ended 2016’’) and December 30, 2017 (‘‘financial year ended 2017’’), as well as certain other financial and operating data of Cott TB. The convenience translations of the financial information of Cott TB for the financial year ended December 31, 2017 into euro have been prepared using the average rate of $1.129/A1.00 for income statement and cash flow statement items and the rate as of December 31, 2017 of $1.198/A1.00 for the balance sheet items. Cott TB’s financial data has been extracted from the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements, which have been derived from Cott Corporation’s historical accounting records and the historical cost basis of the assets and liabilities of the Canadian CSD business and the following legal entities comprising the Cott Traditional Business: Cott Beverages Inc., Cliffstar LLC, Cott Vending Inc., Cott IP Holdings Corp., Pri-Pak Inc. (for the financial year ended 2017), Interim BCB, LLC, Northeast Retailer Brands LLC, Cott Beverages Limited, Cott Developments Limited, Cooke Bros Holdings Limited, Cooke Bros (Tattenhall) Limited, Mr. Freeze (Europe) Limited, Calypso Soft Drinks Limited, Tip Top Soft Drinks Limited, Cott Ventures Limited, TT Calco Limited, Jay Juice Limited, Cott Nelson (Holdings) Limited, Cott (Nelson) Limited, Cott Private Label Limited, Mexico Bottling Services, S.A. de C.V., Servicios Gerenciales de Mexico, S.A. de C.V., Cott Embotelladores de Mexico, S.A. de C.V., Cott Maquinaria y Equipo, S.A. de C.V. and Cott Retail Brands Netherlands B.V. The Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP and have been audited by Cott Corporation’s independent auditors, PwC, as set forth in its audit report included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. These historical results are not necessarily indicative of future results. Certain of these entities have been renamed following December 31, 2017. In addition, certain non-GAAP financial measures are presented below that are not required by or presented in accordance with IFRS or U.S. GAAP and should not be considered in insolation from or as substitutes for Cott TB’s historical financial information. See ‘‘Presentation of Financial Information—Other Financial Measures.’’ Prospective investors should read the summary financial information and other data below in conjunction with, and the summary financial information and other data below is qualified in its entirety by reference to, ‘‘Presentation of Financial Information,’’ ‘‘Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition _and Results of Operations of Cott TB’’ and the Cott TB Carve-Out Financial Statements, including the notes_ thereto, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. 26 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Demand for our products may be significantly adversely affected by changes in customer and end-consumer preferences.
Subsubsection Text: Customer requirements and end-consumer demand in respect of our products are subject to change. Although we believe the flexibility of our manufacturing capabilities is one of our core strengths, our customers may demand changes to our product mix to which we may not be readily able to adapt in a timely manner or at all. Such changes could include a shift from one product category to another or changes to packaging sizes or types. There can be no assurance that we can successfully adapt our production sites or lines to meet our customers’ requirements. In addition, end-consumers are seeking increased variety in their drinks, and there is a growing concern among the public regarding the ingredients in soft drinks products, the attributes of those ingredients, and health and wellness issues generally. End-consumer interest in or concerns regarding nutrition, health and lifestyle changes in general, and legislative changes might result in a decrease in end-consumer demand for soft drinks with sugar and artificial ingredients, and could conversely increase end-consumer demand for products associated with health and wellness such as water, teas and juices not made from concentrates. For example, France and Finland have introduced taxes on sugar-sweetened drinks and similar measures are being considered in other places, including other EU member states. If such taxes were to be broadly introduced it could shift consumer demand away from CSDs and other sugar-sweetened drinks. A shift in product categories could result in lower margins which could potentially lead to the need for investments in new production lines. In particular, a shift away from products such as carbonated drinks, sugar-sweetened drinks, artificially sweetened drinks and caffeinated drinks, which represented over a third of our volumes in 2017, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. End-consumer preferences could also change due to a variety of other factors, including a downturn in the economy, aging of the general population, changes in social trends, the real or perceived impact that the manufacturing of our products has on the environment, changes in end-consumer demographics, changes in travel, vacation or leisure activity patterns, or negative publicity resulting from regulatory action or litigation against companies in our industry. See ‘‘—Our results depend on general economic conditions and _could be affected by deterioration in the economic conditions of our markets.’’ Any of these changes may_ reduce end-consumer demand for soft drinks in general and, consequently, customer demand for our products, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. There can be no assurance that we can adapt to meet our customers’ requirements or develop innovative products that respond to end-consumer trends. Our failure to adapt or develop could put us at a competitive disadvantage in the marketplace and our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects could be adversely affected. 36 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We may fail to realize the business growth opportunities, margin benefits and other synergies anticipated from, or may incur unanticipated costs or be exposed to unexpected liabilities associated with or resulting from the Cott TB Acquisition.
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the consideration for Cott TB was justified in part by the margin benefits, cost savings, business growth opportunities and other synergies that we expect to achieve through our acquisition of Cott TB. However, these expected margin benefits, cost savings, business growth opportunities and other synergies may not develop, may be materially lower than estimated or may require significant unanticipated costs. In addition, other assumptions upon which we determined the consideration may prove to be incorrect. We may also face challenges with the following: - redeploying or reducing resources in different areas of operations to improve efficiency; - analyzing or implementing measures relating to purchase synergies; - the diversion of management attention from on-going business concerns; - addressing possible differences between our business culture, processes, controls, procedures and systems and those of Cott TB; - difficulties related to the integration of departments, information technology systems and accounting systems; - difficulties in conforming Cott TB’s accounting, book and records, internal accounting controls and procedures and policies to ours; - retaining employees who may be vital to the integration of Cott TB or to the future prospects of the combined business; - retaining the loyalty and business of the Cott TB customers; - unforeseen legal, regulatory, contractual or other issues; and - unanticipated costs and expenses associated with any undisclosed or potential liabilities. Additionally, we may need to increase staff, such as hiring additional staff in our corporate team, to accommodate the current size of the Group. Under any of these circumstances, the margin benefits, cost savings, business growth opportunities and other synergies we anticipate as a result of the acquisition may not be achieved as expected, or at all, or may be delayed materially. To the extent that we incur higher integration costs, including higher than budgeted implementation and investment costs, or achieve lower margin benefits than expected, our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects may suffer.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We may fail to acquire other businesses or to realize expected synergies relating to the integration of future acquisitions.
Subsubsection Text: We have a growth strategy that is partly based on future acquisitions. The success of this strategy with respect to acquisitions, such as the acquisition of Cott TB, depends on our ability to identify suitable targets, conduct appropriate due diligence, negotiate transactions on favorable terms and ultimately complete such transactions and integrate acquired businesses into our group within a reasonable timeframe and achieve anticipated synergies and benefits In addition, we may not complete future acquisitions at all, or not on the terms as contemplated, due to antitrust or competition constraints or for other reasons. For example, the purchase price demanded for a future acquisition, or the costs relating to such acquisition (including in connection with required remedies to address antitrust or competition constraints), may turn out to be higher than is justified. We may not achieve the integration of future acquisitions as expeditiously as expected or the related synergies may not be realized. The potential difficulties of integrating the operations of acquired businesses include, among others: - diversion of a significant amount of management’s attention; - analyzing or implementing measures relating to purchase synergies; - difficulty obtaining regulatory approvals and lack of experience in operating in new geographical markets; 37 ----- - assumption of and exposure to unknown or contingent liabilities of acquired businesses; - failure to smoothly implement our business plan for the combined businesses; - unanticipated issues in integrating manufacturing, logistics and other systems; - possible inconsistencies in standards and controls between the acquired business and our structure; - failure to retain key customers, suppliers or employees; and - other unanticipated issues, expenses and liabilities. If we acquire fewer other businesses than our competitors, or are less successful in the integration of acquired businesses than our competitors, then those competitors may grow more quickly than us or could realize synergies that we do not realize, or realize to a lesser extent, which they may be able to partially pass along to customers. This would create downward price pressure, forcing us to follow suit, or potentially lose revenue. If any of the foregoing were to occur, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We may experience fluctuations in the prices of raw materials and packaging materials, which may be difficult to pass on to our customers.
Subsubsection Text: The prices of raw materials and packaging materials are driven by market supply and demand, and may therefore fluctuate due to factors beyond our control, including, for example, weather conditions, transport costs and governmental controls, such as import or export taxes. Customers in our contract manufacturing business generally source their own raw materials and so our exposure to price fluctuations primarily impacts our retailer brands business, consisting of 70% of our volume as of December 31, 2017. While we aim to purchase sufficient raw materials and packaging materials to meet our estimated sales volumes, these estimates may prove inaccurate, particularly as many customers do not commit to fixed volumes. See ‘‘—Our business depends on a significant supply of raw materials and packaging materials from a limited _number of third-party suppliers.’’ If we achieve higher than expected sales volumes, we may need to_ purchase additional raw materials and packaging materials at prevailing market prices. In addition, we are also exposed to fluctuations in the prices of commodities, such as electricity, natural gas and other energy sources and for which there are no long-term pricing commitments or arrangements which could have an effect on our operating costs. Further, our operations are dependent on local water supplies and any decrease in availability or increase in prices of water could also have an effect on our operating costs. If our raw materials or packaging materials costs or other operating costs increase, it may not be possible to pass these costs on to customers through price adjustments or in a timely manner or at all. In general, input price fluctuations can only be passed on to our customers at the renewal of the relevant contracts. Additionally, any price increases that we pass along to customers could reduce demand for our products. The inability to fully or partially pass on these price increases to our customers, or to pass on such increases in a timely manner, or a fall in sales volumes due to price increases, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our business depends on a significant supply of raw materials and packaging materials from a limited number of third-party suppliers.
Subsubsection Text: Our manufacture of products, particularly our retailer brands business, is highly dependent on an adequate supply of certain raw materials, including sugar and sugar-related products, fruit juices and concentrates, as well as packaging materials, including LBP, aluminum cans and PET, most of which are only available from a limited number of suppliers. For the supply of raw materials and packaging materials, we estimate the volume of supplies needed based on sales contracts with our customers. Our estimate of the supplies required may not be accurate and there may be a mismatch between the estimated and actual volumes sold, resulting in an increase or decrease in demand for raw materials and packaging materials. Although we attempt to ensure that sufficient raw materials and packaging materials are in stock, a number of factors may cause a shortage of materials available to meet the demand from our customers. Although we have adopted a policy to enter into forward purchase contracts for most raw materials and packaging materials up to 12 months in advance to cover sales positions with our customers, the limited number of suppliers for these materials undermines our negotiating position. As such, there can be no assurance that such measures will be effective. In addition, this matching policy does not extend to all materials (PET for instance is only partly covered) nor to all situations (small contracts for example are not always covered). Further, we can only purchase certain raw materials, such as sugar, during the harvest season. 38 ----- The failure of suppliers to meet our needs could occur for many reasons, including fires, natural disasters, weather, manufacturing problems, disease, crop failure, strikes, transportation interruption, government regulation, political instability and terrorism. A failure of supply could also occur due to our suppliers’ financial difficulties. The loss of any one of such suppliers could lead to a disruption in our supply chain, which could reduce the utilization rates of our manufacturing sites and deliveries to customers, and in turn have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Further, our reputation could be jeopardized by a failure to maintain high ethical, social and environmental standards for our activities, including human rights related challenges in our supply chains. While we require our suppliers to comply with local legislation, to sign our Supplier Code of Conduct and to be able to demonstrate compliance with our Supplier Code of Conduct upon request, compliance by our third-party suppliers is outside of our control. Any such non-compliance with local legislation or our Supplier Code of Conduct could harm our business and/or our reputation. If suppliers are unable to meet any of our requirements, we could suffer substantial price increases and changing suppliers could require long lead times, which could impact our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Inconsistent quality or contamination of our products, or products that are similar to or in the same categories as our products could harm the integrity of, or customer support for, our products and adversely affect the sales of those customers’ brands.
Subsubsection Text: Maintaining our corporate image and reputation as a high-quality manufacturer of soft drinks is critical to our success. Adverse publicity, whether or not justified, may tarnish our reputation and cause customers to choose products offered by our competitors. If we fail to maintain high-quality standards for our products, or fail to maintain high ethical, social and environmental standards for all of our operations and activities, including human rights related challenges in our supply chain, our reputation be jeopardized, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. The success of our products depends upon the positive image that our customers and the end-customers have of those products. A lack of consistency in the quality of, or contamination of our products, whether occurring accidentally or through deliberate third-party action, or a perceived issue with the quality of our products, could harm the integrity of, sales of or customer or end-customer support for, those products or brands and could adversely affect the brands’ sales. Further, a lack of consistency in the quality of or contamination of products similar to our products or in the same categories as our products could, by association, harm the integrity of, or customer support for, our products, and/or our customers’ brands, could adversely affect our sales. The amount of any costs, including fines or damages payments, that we might incur in respect of any liability or perceived liability for contaminants in raw materials or mislabeling of raw materials used in, or defects in the blending or bottling process of our products, could substantially exceed our insurance coverage. We may voluntarily or be required to recall or withhold from sale, products in the event of contamination or damage. See ‘‘—Risks Relating to Legislative, Regulatory and Tax Matters—If our products do not comply _with the legal, regulatory or customer requirements, we may have to recall our products.’’ In the event of_ litigation, a significant adverse product liability judgment or a widespread product recall may negatively impact the reputation of the affected products or our Group for a period of time depending on product availability, competitive reaction and customer and end-consumer attitudes. See ‘‘—Risks Relating to _Legislative, Regulatory and Tax Matters—We may be affected by litigation, including product liability claims.’’_ Even if a product liability claim is unsuccessful or is not fully pursued, resulting negative publicity could adversely affect our reputation and image, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our operating results may be adversely affected by disruption to our production and storage facilities.
Subsubsection Text: Operations, and inventory of raw materials, packaging materials and finished products, at production sites and warehouses could be adversely affected by extraordinary events, including fire, explosion, release of high-temperature steam or water, structural collapse, chemical spill, mechanical failure, extended or extraordinary maintenance, road construction or closures of primary access routes, flood, windstorm or other severe weather conditions, directives from government agencies, power interruptions or other catastrophic damage. Any prolonged interruption at any main production site could reduce production capacity and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations. The contingency measures which we have in place to mitigate such risks may prove to be insufficient or 39 ----- ineffective. Disaster recovery plans may not prevent business disruption, and reconstruction of any damaged facilities could require a significant amount of time and money. In addition, inventory of raw materials, packaging materials and finished products could be damaged or lost. Although we carry insurance to cover losses at production sites and interruptions in the business, such policies are subject to limitations such as deductibles and maximum liability amounts and, therefore, may not cover all losses, including loss of the business which customers may have placed with competitors as a result of such interruptions. We may also incur losses that are outside of the coverage of insurance policies. In the future, it may not be possible to obtain insurance coverage at current levels, or at all, and premiums may increase significantly on the coverage that is maintained. As a result, significant losses could occur if any of our production sites were damaged or ceased operation for any other reason. We are particularly dependent on ten sites: Bodegraven and Sittard in the Netherlands, Erftstadt in Germany, St. Alban and Marges in France, Bridgwater in the UK, Caslino al Piano in Italy, Ninove in Belgium and Wharton and Lakeland in the U.S. Together, these ten sites accounted for approximately 35% of our volume in 2017. If we face any significant disruption at any of these sites, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: A few key customers contribute a significant portion of our volume, and any reduction in volume from these customers could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.
Subsubsection Text: Although we have multiple contracts with each of our customers, a significant portion of our volume is concentrated with a relatively small number of customers. Our customers include several large national and regional food retailers in our key countries/regions for our retailer brands products as well as branded soft drinks companies with whom we contract to manufacture their products. Sales to Walmart, PepsiCo & Unilever and Aldi, our top three customers in 2017, accounted for approximately 28% of our volume. The volume derived from our top ten customers in 2017 accounted for approximately 49% of total volume. We expect continued consolidation among our customers and anticipate that sales of our products to a limited number of customers will continue to account for a high percentage of our volume. The loss of any customer or customers in the aggregate, that represent a significant portion of our volume, for example, following a routine periodic tender for such customers’ business or a material reduction in the amount of business that we undertake with any such customer or customers, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. Furthermore, we could be adversely affected if any significant customer reacts unfavorably to the pricing of our products, demands a longer payment term which might adversely affect our working capital or decides to de-emphasize or reduce their product offerings in the categories with which we supply them, either voluntarily or through a decrease in their sales. In addition, a material contract manufacturing customer may decide to take its production in-house. For example, in the past, sales to Coca-Cola decreased as a result of such production reallocation. We could lose all volumes generated through several contracts with the same customer in certain circumstances, if such as, for example, one of our customers is declared bankrupt. Any such event could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Many of our customers are large and sophisticated and have considerable buying power which could limit our potential for growth and profit.
Subsubsection Text: Many of our customers are large and sophisticated retailers and A-brand owners. As a result of their size and sophistication, large retailers and A-brand owners have significant buying power and can often apply pricing pressure on their suppliers by resisting price increases and operating with reduced inventories. Currently, retailers work together at both the national and international level to apply pricing pressure, and further integration at the regional level can further strengthen the buying power of the retailers. Additionally, retailers cooperate with other retailers in purchasing groups, which give them significant buying power. Our customers may also re-evaluate or refine their business practices from time to time and impose new or revised requirements upon their suppliers, including us. These business demands may relate to inventory practices, logistics, product specifications, sustainability or other aspects of the customersupplier relationship. Compliance with requirements imposed by our significant customers may be costly and could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. 40 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: The loss of members of senior management or key employees, the failure to attract and retain directors with appropriate qualifications, experience and business relationships, or an increase in personnel expenses could have a material adverse effect on our business.
Subsubsection Text: Human capital is key to our success. The performance of members of our Executive Board is critical to our success. We plan to continue to invest time and resources in developing and training senior management. Our long-term success also depends on our ability to recruit and retain capable senior management and key employees, many of whom have significant experience in the food and drinks industry and could be difficult to replace. Any failure to retain such persons could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Further, if we fail to adequately plan for the succession of senior management, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. In our industry, competition for suitably qualified senior management is strong and we expect the competition to intensify further. The loss of any member of senior management or any key employee, particularly to competitors, has in the past and may in the future result in the loss of customers or suppliers with whom such persons have had business relationships. In addition, if we were to lose a substantial number of employees, we would have to incur significant costs in identifying, hiring, training and retaining replacements for departing employees. From time to time, the food and drinks industry faces a shortage of suitably qualified personnel in certain regions. Such shortages have in the past limited, and may in the future limit, our ability to attract employees to operate and further grow our business. In addition, salaries and related benefits of our employees are among our most significant costs. As a result, wage, salary and related benefit increases, due to labor shortages, competition or other reasons, could have a significant impact on our operating profits, in particular if increased costs cannot be passed on to customers.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our operating results may be adversely affected by a breakdown, security or privacy breach of our information technology systems or a failure to develop those systems.
Subsubsection Text: We depend on key information systems to conduct our business, to provide information to management and to prepare financial reports. We rely on third-party providers, such as Fujitsu SAP, Cott TB Digital Data Center and ICM Data Center, for the majority of our key information systems and business processing services supporting our operations in several different countries. A system failure, therefore, could have serious consequences for our entire business. These systems and services are vulnerable to interruptions or other failures resulting from, among other things, natural disasters, terrorist attacks, software, equipment or telecommunications failures, processing errors, computer viruses, criminal hackers, other security issues or supplier defaults. Security, backup and disaster recovery measures may not be adequate or implemented properly to avoid such disruptions or failures. Despite our efforts to protect sensitive, confidential and personal data and information, unauthorized users could gain access to our systems through cyber-attacks and introduce backdoors or steal, use without authorization, destroy or sabotage such data. There is a growing trend of advanced persistent threats being launched by organized and coordinated groups against corporate networks to breach security for malicious purposes. Computer hackers may also be able to develop and deploy computer viruses, worms, and other malicious software programs that could attack our products and services or those of a third-party with whom we do business and exploit potential security vulnerabilities, create system disruptions or cause shutdowns or denials of service. Data may also be accessed or modified improperly as a result of employee or supplier error or malfeasance and third parties may attempt to fraudulently induce employees or customers into disclosing sensitive information such as user names, passwords or other information in order to gain access to our data, our customers’ data or our information technology systems. Any disruption or failure of these systems or services could cause substantial errors, processing inefficiencies, security and/or privacy breaches and the inability to use the systems or process transactions, loss of customers or other business disruptions, any of which could have a material adverse impact on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Exchange rate fluctuations could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.
Subsubsection Text: Our reporting currency is the euro. Our currency risk largely concerns positions and future purchase transactions in U.S. dollars due to the purchase of raw materials in U.S. dollars. Exchange rate fluctuations may have both transaction and translation effects. Transaction effects occur when we generate sales and incur expenses in currencies other than the euro, and are unable to match sales received in a foreign currency with costs in the same currency, which exposes our results of operations to currency exchange rate 41 ----- fluctuations. In addition to the U.S. dollar, we have also historically been subject to fluctuations of other currencies, including the British pound, the Canadian dollar, the Mexican peso and the Polish zloty. Currency translation effects occur when the financial statements of our consolidated subsidiaries are recorded in their respective local currency and converted into euros, whereby translation effects can diminish the impact of positive results or increase the impact of negative results recorded by such consolidated subsidiaries. In particular, we may observe a negative impact caused by translation effects when the euro is strong in comparison to the British pound or the U.S. dollar. In addition, an unfavorable movement in exchange rates may give us a competitive disadvantage with respect to our competitors from other currency regions and may lead to declines in orders. All of these factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. We have determined, based on a risk assessment, that some of these currency risks need to be hedged. Forward exchange contracts and options are used for this purpose. We use derivative financial instruments to hedge 80% to 100% of our cash flow denominated in foreign currency. Following the Cott TB Acquisition, we are in the process of covering our exposure from taking U.S. dollars out of our North American operations. For quantitative and qualitative disclosures of our financial exposure to market risks, please see note 3.1 to the Refresco Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2017 included elsewhere in the offering memorandum. To the extent that currency fluctuation risks are insufficiently hedged, such events could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We operate in a highly competitive industry and competitive pressures in the soft drinks market could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.
Subsubsection Text: We compete directly with other retailer brands manufacturers on the basis of quality, ability to deliver a diversified product mix, pricing and customer service. The retailer brands soft drinks market in which we are active is highly competitive and some of our competitors may have greater financial and other resources, lower costs, significant unutilized capacity or stronger customer relationships than we have. Certain retailer brands products, such as CSDs, also indirectly compete for retail shelf space with contract manufacturing products. An increase in the number of competitors in the retailer brands market may lead to a decrease of sales and prices, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. In our contract manufacturing business, we compete indirectly with soft drinks brand owners that either manufacture their own products or decide to take their production in-house. We also compete directly with other contract manufacturers on the basis of quality, ability to deliver a diversified product mix, pricing and customer service. The contract manufacturing soft drinks market is highly competitive and some of our competitors may have greater financial and other resources, lower cost bases, significant unutilized capacity or stronger customer relationships than ours. Contract manufacturing competitors could use their significant resources to develop new products with which we cannot easily compete. Our customers also could reduce their pricing to levels that we cannot match without adversely affecting our results of operations. It may also be possible for current or future competitors to develop new product manufacturing technologies or processes that would enable them to offer products at a cost or quality that gives them a significant advantage over our products. We may not be able to continue to compete successfully against existing or future competitors. Contract manufacturing products also compete indirectly for retail shelf space with retailer brands products. We do not engage in marketing or advertising for our contract manufacturing products and do not have direct influence over shelf space decisions by retail customers. A-brand competitors have significant financial resources that are heavily invested in promotional programs, which may earn them greater shelf space relative to retailer brands products. If A-brand owners with which we compete increase the frequency of their promotional activities in our key regions/countries, our retailer brands customers may not allocate adequate shelf space for the products supplied by us and, as a result, we could experience a decline in sales volumes, be forced to reduce pricing, forgo price increases required to offset increased costs of raw materials or packaging materials, increase capital and other expenditures or lose market share, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. 42 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We may not remain cost competitive or fully realize the expected cost savings or operating efficiencies from our cost-savings initiatives.
Subsubsection Text: We have implemented, and may in the future implement, cost-savings initiatives to support the implementation of key strategic initiatives designed to achieve long-term sustainable growth. Additionally, we expect to close additional plants in the medium-term. We intend for these activities to maximize operating effectiveness and efficiency and to reduce costs. We cannot assure that we will achieve or sustain the targeted benefits under these programs or that the benefits, even if achieved, will be adequate to meet our long-term growth expectations. In addition, the implementation of key elements of these activities, such as employee job reductions and site closures, could have an adverse impact on our business, particularly in the near term. In addition, we face price pressures from competitors. Our inability to remain cost competitive could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our sales are subject to seasonal fluctuations in customer and end-consumer demand.
Subsubsection Text: Our sales are affected by weather, with sales typically being higher in the warmer and drier months from April to September and lower during the colder and wetter months of October to March. We also typically experience a period of higher sales around the Christmas/New Year holiday period. While these end-consumer buying patterns lead to a natural seasonality in our sales, unseasonable weather can also significantly affect our sales and profitability. For example, during prolonged periods of unseasonably hot weather, end-consumers tend to switch to products such as water and ready-to-drink teas that may have lower profit margins as well as require us to adjust our product mix in other ways. Consequently, our operating results can fluctuate. Any inability to adapt to customers’ requirements in terms of seasonality may affect our working capital resulting in loss of sales, oversupply and inventory costs which we may be unable to recover and thus could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We rely on third parties for transportation of our supplies and finished products, and any disruption in their services or increase in costs could adversely affect our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.
Subsubsection Text: Our business requires significant movement of raw materials, packaging materials and finished products by ground and sea transportation. We contract with third-party contractors for the transportation and delivery of most of our products, and such contractors operate beyond our direct control. Any delays in delivery or poor handling by distributors and third-party transport operators of our raw materials, packaging materials or finished products may affect sales or damage our reputation. Interruptions in the supply chain of raw materials or packaging materials to us or delivery of finished products to customers, and poor handling of materials or products in transit could interrupt our business, delay shipments to customers, cause losses, damage our reputation, and have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. Additionally, although the costs for inbound freight are mainly included in the price of supplies, this is not always the case for outbound freights. The costs for such outbound freights could increase, which could adversely affect our ability to supply our customers at current prices and meet customers’ demand for our products. As a result, we could experience a significant increase in operating costs, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We may be adversely impacted by work stoppages and other labor matters.
Subsubsection Text: While we strive to maintain good relationships with our employees and their unions, there can be no assurance that such relationships will continue to be amicable or that the business will not be affected by strikes, plant closings, further unionization efforts or other types of conflicts with labor unions or employees. For example, in January 2015, we experienced a strike at our plant in Bridgwater, UK. We are subject to collective bargaining agreements in almost every key country/region where we operate. We may be unable to renew collective bargaining agreements on satisfactory terms or at all. This could result in strikes or work stoppages, which could impair our ability to manufacture and distribute products and result in a substantial loss of sales. The terms of existing or renewed collective bargaining agreements could also significantly increase the costs or negatively affect our ability to increase operational efficiency. Furthermore, many of our customers and suppliers also have unionized workforces. Work stoppages or slow-downs experienced by customers or suppliers could result in lower demand for our products or a lack of supplies and, thus, slow-downs or closures of production facilities. In the event that either we, or one or 43 ----- more of our customers or suppliers experience a work stoppage, such work stoppage could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to protect our intellectual property rights.
Subsubsection Text: We own trademarks and domain names that are important to our business and competitive position. We cannot assure that third parties will not infringe on or misappropriate these rights by, for example, imitating our products, asserting rights in, or ownership of, our intellectual property rights or in trademarks or domain names that are similar to trademarks or domain names that we own. In addition, we may fail to discover infringement of our intellectual property, and/or any steps taken, or that will be taken by us, may not be sufficient to protect our intellectual property rights or prevent others from seeking to invalidate our intellectual property rights or block sales of our products by alleging a breach of their intellectual property rights. Applications we file in respect of new intellectual property rights may not be granted. Certain countries in which we operate may offer less stringent intellectual property protection than is available in Western Europe. If we are unable to protect our intellectual property rights against infringement or misappropriation, or if others assert rights in or seek to invalidate our intellectual property rights, this could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition and/or our ability to develop our business. End-consumers could confuse our value brand products with counterfeited and/or unauthorized brands. This could also have a material adverse effect on future sales by impairing our reputation and brand equity.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Potential future impairments of intangible assets could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial conditions and results of operation.
Subsubsection Text: Our goodwill is a significant asset. As at December 31, 2017, the book value of Refresco’s goodwill amounted to A523.4 million, while Refresco’s total intangible assets amounted to A540.4 million. We have also initially booked A2,242.3 million in goodwill in our pro forma financial information in connection with the Cott TB Acquisition and the Transactions, which will likely be reallocated once the purchase price accounting for the Cott TB Acquisition and the Acquisition has been finalized. As such the actual goodwill may differ significantly. See ‘‘Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information.’’ In accordance with IFRS and with Part 9 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code, we evaluate goodwill and indefinite life intangible assets for impairment annually, or earlier in the case of a triggering event. Goodwill impairment is indicated and indefinite life intangible assets are impaired when their carrying amount exceeds their estimated recoverable amount, which is the greater of their value in use and their fair value less cost to sell. A decrease in expected cash flows of the (group of) cash generating units, changes in market conditions, loss of key customers and a change in our imputed cost of capital may indicate potential impairment of recorded goodwill. Weakness in the global economy also may cause us to make impairment charges, which, depending on the amounts impaired, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information included in this offering memorandum is presented for illustrative purposes only and our actual financial condition and results of operations following the Transactions may differ materially.
Subsubsection Text: Prior to January 30, 2018, Refresco and Cott TB operated as separate companies and businesses, and up until March 29, 2018, Refresco and Cott TB were not owned by the Issuer and the Equity Investors. Accordingly, the operations of Refresco and Cott TB were not previously managed on a combined basis or under the ownership of the Equity Investors and had different capital structures than they have as a result of the Pro Forma Transactions. In order to illustrate the effect of the Pro Forma Transactions, we have presented in this offering memorandum the unaudited _pro forma condensed consolidated financial information. The unaudited _pro forma condensed consolidated financial information has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the Securities Act, the Prospectus Directive or any generally accepted accounting standards. The unaudited pro forma adjustments are based upon available information and certain assumptions that we believe to be reasonable and give effect to events that are directly attributable to the transactions described therein and are factually supportable, and for the purposes of income statement items, are deemed to have a continuing effect on the Issuer. The unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated financial information in this offering memorandum has not been audited or reviewed by any independent auditors. The unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated financial information is for informational purposes only and should not be considered indicative of actual 44 ----- results that would have been achieved had the Cott TB Acquisition, the Acquisition and the other Pro Forma Transactions been completed on the dates indicated and do not purport to indicate our future consolidated results of operations or financial position. The actual results may differ significantly from those reflected in the unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated financial information for a number of reasons, including, but not limited to, differences in assumptions used to prepare the unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated financial information. The unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated financial information also does not reflect future events that may occur after the Pro Forma Transactions, including the potential non-realization of synergies, including those synergies described in the presentation of Pro Forma Synergies Adjusted EBITDA, and the incurrence of implementation and investment costs related to realizing such synergies. The unaudited pro _forma condensed consolidated financial information also does not consider potential negative impacts of_ current market conditions on revenue or expenses. Such actual events may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: The Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum are not necessarily indicative of the historical results that would have been obtained if Cott TB had been a separate company during the periods presented or of the results that may be obtained in the future.
Subsubsection Text: This offering memorandum includes the audited combined carve-out financial statements of Cott TB as of and for the years ended December 30, 2017, December 31, 2016 and January 2, 2016, which have been derived from Cott Corporation’s historical accounting records and the historical cost basis of the assets and liabilities of the Canadian CSD business and certain legal entities comprising the Cott Traditional Business. See ‘‘Presentation of Financial Information—Financial Information—Cott TB.’’ The Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements include the assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses of the operations included in the Cott Traditional Business and are presented on a combined carve-out basis to include the historical results of operations, financial position, and cash flows applicable to the Cott Traditional Business. The asset, liabilities, revenues and expenses included in the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements represent only those that were sold to Refresco as well as certain allocated expenses as deemed appropriate by management of Cott Corporation as disclosed in the accompanying notes to the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements. As the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements have been prepared on a carve-out basis, they may not necessarily be indicative of the historical results that would have been obtained if the Cott Traditional Business had been a separate company during the periods presented or of the results that may be obtained in the future.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We may fail to make regular capital expenditures, investments and upgrades to conduct our business which could have a material adverse effect on our operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our production facilities require regular maintenance and investments. See also ‘‘—Risks Relating to _Legislative, Regulatory and Tax Matters-Our business and production facilities are subject to significant environmental regulations and failure to comply with such regulations, or any changes in such regulations, could result in interruptions in operations and increased costs.’’ Our production lines may have to be replaced_ and installing new production lines involves risks which may lead to a delay in starting production. Such a delay, or other events, such as higher than budgeted capital expenditures, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Changes in technology may affect our competitive position in the future.
Subsubsection Text: Production equipment, processes and logistical systems are important technologies in our business. We expect these technologies to play an increasingly important role in the processing and delivery of our products to customers in a cost-effective manner. Our ability to compete effectively in the future will, in part, be driven by our ability to efficiently maintain, update and change technology platforms as well as integrate new technologies into existing production lines. Failure to maintain appropriate standards of technology, the failure of technology to perform its intended purpose or the failure to adapt to new technologies may adversely affect our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our results depend on general economic conditions and could be affected by deterioration in the economic conditions of our markets.
Subsubsection Text: Historically, our income and results of operations have been influenced, and will continue to be influenced, by the general state of the European and wider economy. Demand for our products is directly related to 45 ----- the strength of the European and wider economy. Lower end-consumer spending may reduce volumes and affect revenue and profitability. The global economy generally went through sharp downturns during 2008 and 2009, influencing the demand for our products as end-consumers switched from higher-margin products to lower-margin products, for example from mineral water to tap water and from fruit juices to CSDs, although the retailer brands soft drinks market was generally less sensitive to an economic downturn than many other fast-moving consumer goods markets. In recent years, the global economy has improved. More favorable economic conditions have generally lead to increased prices generally, including for our key raw materials. There, however, can be no assurance that market conditions will not deteriorate again, which could cause demand in the soft drinks market to decline or remain at low levels for an extended period or cause the product mix demanded by end-consumers to change, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to risks in connection with our pension commitments.
Subsubsection Text: We provide defined benefit pension plans in Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, Italy and the UK. As of December 31, 2017, the present value of our defined benefit pension obligations amounted to A105.3 million. These existing obligations are financed predominantly through externally invested pension plan assets. As of December 31, 2017, our _pro forma employee benefits provisions amounted to A46.0 million. Our externally invested pension plan assets are funded through externally managed funds and insurance companies. While we generally prescribe the investment strategies applied by these funds, we do not determine their individual investment alternatives. The assets are invested in different asset classes including equity, fixed-income securities, real estate and other investment vehicles. The values attributable to the externally invested pension plan assets are subject to fluctuations in the capital markets that are beyond our influence. Unfavorable developments in the capital markets could result in a substantial coverage shortfall for these pension obligations, resulting in a significant increase in our net pension obligations. Any such increase in our net pension obligations could adversely affect our financial condition due to an increased additional outflow of funds to finance the pension obligations. Also, we are exposed to risks associated with longer life expectancy and interest rate changes in connection with our pension commitments as an interest rate decrease could have an adverse effect on our liabilities under these pension schemes. The occurrence of any of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our operations may be adversely affected by the potential withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union
Subsubsection Text: On June 23, 2016, the UK held an in-or-out referendum on its membership within the EU, the result of which favored the exit of the UK from the EU (‘‘Brexit’’). On March 29, 2017, the UK Government formally invoked Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, pursuant to which the UK and the EU will negotiate the terms of the UK’s departure and the UK’s future relationship with the EU. Depending on the terms of Brexit, economic conditions in the UK, the EU and global markets may be adversely affected by reduced growth and volatility. The headquarters of our Group are in Europe and we maintain a significant presence in various European markets through subsidiaries operating in these countries and sales made to customers in Europe. We also have a presence in the UK, which is our largest European market and it is part of our long-term strategy to grow our business in this market. Given the lack of precedent, it is unclear how the withdrawal of the UK from the EU will affect the UK’s access to the EU single market and other important financial and trade relationships and how it will affect us. The withdrawal could, among other outcomes, disrupt the free movement of goods, services, capital and people between the UK and the EU, undermine bilateral cooperation in key policy areas and significantly disrupt trade in the UK and the EU markets in which we operate. Although it is not possible to predict fully the effects of the withdrawal of the UK from the EU, the uncertainty before, during and after the period of negotiation could be destabilizing, have a negative economic impact and increase volatility in the markets, particularly in the Eurozone. Such instability, volatility and negative economic impact could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. 46 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legislative, Regulatory and Tax Matters
Subsubsection Title: Our business and production facilities are subject to significant environmental regulations and failure to comply with such regulations, or any changes in such regulations, could result in interruptions in operations and increased costs.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to a number of local, national, supranational and international environmental laws and other regulations relating to environmental control, fire safety, sanitation, and water consumption and treatment. See ‘‘Business—Quality Management.’’ Any change to these laws and regulations, including as a result of political, economic, or social events, may alter the regulatory environment in which we do business, and could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. We have incurred, and expect to continue to incur, operating costs to comply with such laws and regulations. In the past, we have incurred compliance costs in connection with changes in legislation relating to packaging and recycling laws, and changes in laws regulating air emissions, wastewater discharges, waste handling and recycling, and energy usage. Further, from time to time, we may not be in compliance with all aspects of such legislation in various jurisdictions. For instance, Cott TB and, we believe, other industry participants, are currently not in compliance with certain regulations under the Ontario Environmental Protection Act (‘‘OEPA’’), which are not currently being enforced by Ontario and provide that a minimum percentage of a bottler’s soft drink sales within specified areas in Ontario must be made in refillable containers. In the even that Ontario chooses to enforce the OEPA in the future, industry participants that are not in compliance with the regulations could be subject to monetary fines up to the amount of benefit realized as a result of the non-compliance, or in extreme cases, a prohibition of sales of soft drinks in non-refillable containers. We estimate that a de minimis amount of Cott TB’s sales in Canada would be affected. New or more stringent requirements may also be imposed on other aspects of our operations. We may also need to spend substantial amounts of money and other resources from time to time to construct or acquire new equipment, acquire or amend permits to authorize facility operations, modify, upgrade or replace existing and proposed equipment and clean up or decommission waste management facilities or production facilities. Furthermore, if the measures we implement to comply with these new laws and regulations are deemed insufficient by the competent authorities, compliance costs may significantly exceed current estimates. The presence of hazardous materials at our production sites may expose us to potential liabilities associated with the clean-up of contaminated soil and groundwater, and we could be liable for the costs of responding to and remediating any such release and the restoration of any natural resources damaged by such release, among other things. If we do not comply with applicable environmental requirements, regulatory agencies could seek to impose civil, administrative and/or criminal liabilities, as well as seek to suspend or curtail our operations. Under some circumstances, private parties could also seek to impose civil fines or penalties or monetary damages for violations of environmental laws, including those relating to property damage or personal injury. There can be no assurance that we will not become involved in future litigation or other proceedings or be held responsible in any such future litigation or proceedings relating to environmental matters, the costs of which could be material. Clean-up and remediation costs of the sites in which our facilities are located and related litigation could materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legislative, Regulatory and Tax Matters
Subsubsection Title: Our business and products are subject to significant food and safety regulations and failure to comply with such regulations, or any changes in such regulations, could result in interruptions in operations and increased costs.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to a number of local, national, supranational and international laws and other requirements relating to food and safety regulations. Any change to these laws and regulations, including as a result of political, economic, or social events, may alter the environment in which we do business, and could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. We have incurred, and expect to continue to incur, operating costs to comply with such laws and regulations. We may need to spend substantial amounts of money and other resources from time to time to construct or acquire new equipment, acquire or amend permits to authorize facility operations, and modify, upgrade or replace existing and proposed equipment and facilities. There can be no assurance that future laws, regulations and/or standards will not have a material adverse effect on us. In particular, changes: (i) to health and food safety laws and regulations could increase costs 47 ----- and may also have a material adverse effect on sales if, as a result, the public attitude towards our products is affected; (ii) to health and safety laws and regulations could increase costs (including costs in relation to complying with such laws and regulations) and it may not always be possible for us to pass such costs on to our customers; and (iii) in laws and regulations relating to manufacturing and bottling requirements, packaging and labeling requirements, licensing requirements, ingredients, advertising restrictions and standards and could adversely affect our cash flow, results of operations and financial position. In addition, the trend toward increased end-consumer focus on health and fitness, as well as public concerns about obesity, have in recent years led to the consideration by governments of new taxes on certain food and drinks products, including sugar-sweetened drinks. The EU member states have agreed that by 2020, the volume of so-called added sugar in the overall marketed volume of food should be 10% lower than it was in 2015, implying that higher sugar taxes could be used to achieve this goal. In the U.S., sugar taxes have been introduced in some cities, including Berkeley and San Francisco in California and Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. See ‘‘Industry Overview—The Off-Trade European Soft Drinks Market and _North American Soft Drinks Market—Key Trends.’’ Possible new taxes on sugar-sweetened or caffeinated_ drinks in the countries in which we operates may reduce demand for our products, which could affect our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legislative, Regulatory and Tax Matters
Subsubsection Title: If our products do not comply with the legal, regulatory or customer requirements, we may have to recall our products.
Subsubsection Text: Each of our products is subject to various legal, regulatory and customer requirements. Although we have procedures in place to ensure compliance with said requirements, there is a risk that these procedures are not complied with or turn out not to be appropriate. As a result of a compliance failure, we may have to recall our products which may result in substantial costs, and possibly claims and reputational damage. Any non-compliance with applicable requirements, whether or not resulting in a product recall, may negatively affect our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Legislative, Regulatory and Tax Matters
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to a variety of economic, legal, tax and other related risks due to the international nature of our business.
Subsubsection Text: We provide services through various subsidiaries in 12 different jurisdictions and do business in various countries. Accordingly, our business is subject to risks related to the differing legal, political, social, economic and financial conditions of many jurisdictions. Risks inherent in international operations include the following: - non-adherence of employees to our guidelines, code of conduct or misreporting of results; - difficulties obtaining permits and governmental approvals; - inadvertently providing services or undertaking activities in a jurisdiction without all of the requisite regulatory consents or required consents, exposing us to fines and sanctions; - exposure to different legal standards;
