Subsubsection Text: In the event that the Notes are redeemed early in accordance with ‘‘Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption’’ and depending on prevailing market conditions at the time, an investor who receives proceeds due to such an early redemption may not be able to reinvest such proceeds in a comparable security at an effective interest rate as high as that carried by the Notes. 63 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: Investors may not be able to recover in civil proceedings for U.S. securities law violations.
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer and certain Guarantors are organized or incorporated outside the United States (such Guarantors being ‘‘Non-U.S. Guarantors’’), and their business is substantially conducted outside the United States. The current directors of the Issuer are neither residents nor citizens of the United States. Although the Issuer and the Non-U.S. Guarantors will submit to the jurisdiction of certain New York courts in connection with any action under U.S. securities laws, you may be unable to effect service of process within the United States on the directors and executive officers of the Issuer and such Non-U.S. Guarantors. In addition, as substantially all of the assets of the Issuer and the Non-U.S. Guarantors and their subsidiaries and those of their directors and executive officers are located outside of the United States, you may be unable to enforce against them judgments obtained in U.S. courts. Moreover, the United States and the countries of incorporation of the Non-U.S. Guarantors are not parties to a treaty providing for the reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral awards rendered in civil and commercial matters. Accordingly, a judgment rendered by any U.S. federal or state court based on civil liability, whether or not predicated solely upon U.S. federal or state securities laws, would not directly be recognized or enforceable in the respective jurisdiction of the Non-U.S. Guarantor. For further information see ‘‘Service of Process and Enforcement of Judgments.’’

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: We may not have the ability to raise the funds necessary to finance an offer to repurchase the Notes upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control as required by the Indenture and the change of control provision contained in the Indenture may not necessarily afford you protection in the event of certain important corporate events and change of control events.
Subsubsection Text: Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a ‘‘Change of Control’’ under the Indenture, the Issuer would be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof on the date of purchase, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of purchase. If such an event were to occur, we cannot assure you that we would have sufficient funds to provide to the Issuer to pay the purchase price of the outstanding Notes or our other then-existing contractual obligations would allow us to provide such funds to the Issuer. A change of control may result in an event of default under, or acceleration or mandatory prepayment of, the Senior Credit Facilities and other indebtedness. The repurchase of the Notes pursuant to such an offer could cause a default under such indebtedness, even if the change of control itself does not. The ability of the Issuer to receive cash to allow it to pay cash to the holders of the Notes following the occurrence of a change of control may be limited by our then existing financial resources. Any failure by the Issuer to offer to purchase the Notes would constitute a default under the Indenture, which would, in turn, constitute a default under certain other indebtedness. See ‘‘Description of the Notes—Change of Control.’’ The change of control provisions contained in the Indenture may not necessarily give you sufficient protection in the event of certain important corporate events, including a reorganization, restructuring, merger or other similar transaction involving us that may adversely affect you, because such corporate events may not involve a shift in voting power or beneficial ownership or, even if they do, may not constitute a ‘‘Change of Control’’ as defined in the Indenture. Except as described under ‘‘Description of _the Notes—Change of Control,’’ the Indenture will not contain provisions that would require the Issuer to_ offer to repurchase or redeem the Notes in the event of a reorganization, restructuring, merger, recapitalization or similar transaction. The definition of ‘‘Change of Control’’ in the Indenture will include a disposition of all or substantially all of the assets of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries, taken as a whole, to any person. Although there is a limited body of case law interpreting the phrase ‘‘all or substantially all,’’ there is no precise established definition of the phrase under applicable law. Accordingly, in certain circumstances, there may be a degree of uncertainty as to whether a particular transaction would involve a disposition of ‘‘all or substantially all’’ of the assets of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries taken as a whole. As a result, it may be unclear as to whether a change of control has occurred and whether the Issuer is required to make an offer to repurchase the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time.
Subsubsection Text: One or more independent credit rating agencies have assigned and may in the future assign credit ratings to the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed herein and other factors that may affect the value of the Notes. A credit 64 ----- rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. No assurance can be given that a credit rating will remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of our financings and could adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: Certain covenants will be suspended if we receive investment grade ratings.
Subsubsection Text: The Indenture will provide that, if at any time following the Issue Date, the Notes issued under the Indenture receive two of any of the following investment grade ratings: BBB- or higher by S&P, Baa3 or higher by Moody’s or BBB- or higher by Fitch, and no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing, then beginning that day and continuing until such time as the Notes are no longer rated investment grade by either ratings agency, certain covenants will cease to be applicable to the Notes. See ‘‘Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment _Grade Status.’’_ At any time when these covenants are suspended, we will be able to, among other things, incur additional indebtedness, pay cash dividends and redeem subordinated indebtedness without restriction, each of which may conflict with the interests of holders of the Notes. There can be no assurance that the Notes will ever achieve an investment grade rating or that any such rating if achieved will be maintained.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: The Notes may not become or remain listed on the Exchange.
Subsubsection Text: Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange. However, there can be no assurance that the Notes will become or remain listed. If the Issuer cannot maintain the listing on the Exchange and the admission to dealing on the Official List thereof, or if it becomes unduly burdensome to make or maintain such listing, the Issuer may cease to make or maintain such listing on the Official List of the Exchange. Listing of any of the Notes on the Exchange does not imply that a public offering of any of the Notes in the Channel Islands has been authorized. Although no assurance is made as to the liquidity of the Notes as a result of listing on the Official List of the Exchange or another recognized listing exchange for comparable issuers, failure to be approved for listing or the delisting of the Notes from the Official List of the Exchange or another listing exchange may have an adverse effect on a holder’s ability to resell Notes in the secondary market.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: You may face foreign currency exchange risks or other tax consequences as a result of investing in the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be denominated and payable in euros. If you measure your investment returns by reference to a currency other than the euro, an investment in the Notes entails foreign exchange related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in the value of the euro relative to the currency by reference to which you measure your investment returns because of economic, political and other factors over which we have no control. Depreciation of the euro against the currency by reference to which you measure your investment returns could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you when the return on the Notes is translated into the currency by reference to which you measure your investment returns. There may be tax consequences for you as a result of any foreign exchange gains or losses from any investment in the Notes. See ‘‘Certain Tax _Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations’’ if you are a U.S. holder who measures_ your investment returns by reference to the U.S. dollar.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Indebtedness and the Notes
Subsubsection Title: The Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes may be issued with original issue discount (‘‘OID’’) for U.S. federal income tax purposes. If the Notes are issued with OID for U.S. federal income tax purposes, U.S. investors will generally be required to include amounts representing OID in their gross income as it accrues in advance of the receipt of cash payments attributable to such income using the constant yield method. See ‘‘Tax Considerations—Certain _U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations—Original Issue Discount.’’_ 65 -----

_An investment in the Notes is subject to a number of risks. Prospective investors should consider carefully the risks described below and the other information contained in this offering memorandum prior to making any investment decision with respect to the Notes. Each of the risks discussed below could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on the principal amount and interest which investors will receive in respect of the Notes. In addition, each of the risks discussed below could adversely affect the trading or the trading price of the Notes or the rights of investors under the Notes and, as a result, investors could lose some or all of their investment. Prospective investors should note that the risks described below may not be the only risks we face. We have described only those risks that we currently consider to be material and there may be additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us, or that we currently consider immaterial, that might also have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects. This offering memorandum also contains forward looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward looking statements as a result of various factors, including the risks described below and elsewhere in this offering memorandum. Unless otherwise stated or the context otherwise requires, in this section the terms ‘‘we,’’ ‘‘us,’’ and ‘‘our’’ refer to the Issuer and its subsidiaries after giving effect to the Transactions and the Cott TB Acquisition. See ‘‘The Transactions’’ and ‘‘Summary—Recent Developments—The Cott TB Acquisition.’’_

Subsection Title: Sources of Funds** **(E million)** **Uses of Funds** **(E million)
Subsubsection Text: Equity Contribution[(1)] . . . . . . . . . . . . . 982.8 Bridge Facility[(2)] . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 445.0 Refinancing of the syndicated term Term Loan B Facility (equivalent)[(3)] . . 1,958.5 loan facility[(5)] . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1,831.4 Revolving Credit Facility[(3)] . . . . . . . . . 90.0 Purchase price for Refresco Shares[(6)] . . 1,623.2 Cash on hand[(4)] . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 46.7 Transaction costs and other payments[(7)] 68.4

In connection with the Acquisition, the Issuer entered into the Bridge Facility Agreement that provides for the A445.0 million Bridge Facility, which was drawn by the Issuer and on-lent to Sunshine Investments B.V. on March 28, 2018. Sunshine Investments B.V. used the proceeds from such intercompany loan, the Equity Contributions from the Equity Investors and drawings under the Term Loan B Facility, to finance its acquisition of the Refresco Shares pursuant to the Tender Offer and to pay certain costs and expenses in connection therewith as described above in ‘‘—The Acquisition.’’ The proceeds from the Offering will be used together with cash on hand at the Issuer to refinance amounts that were incurred under the Bridge Facility and to pay the costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Offering as described in ‘‘Use of Proceeds.’’ 68 -----

(1) Represents the Equity Contribution made on March 29, 2018 to the Issuer. (2) The drawings under the Bridge Facility were used to fund the acquisition of a portion of the Refresco Shares on the Completion Date. The proceeds of the Offering will be used to refinance amounts drawn under the Bridge Facility. See ‘‘—The _Refinancing.’’_ (3) Represents the euro-equivalent amount of gross proceeds of the Term Loan B Facility based on an EUR/USD exchange rate of A1.00/$1.20 and a EUR/GBP exchange rate of A1.00/£0.89 as of December 31, 2017. The Term Loan B Facility includes a euro-denominated tranche in an initial principal amount of A1,217 million, a U.S. dollar-denominated tranche in an initial principal amount of $620 million and a British pound-tranche in an initial principal amount of £200 million. The Senior Credit Facilities Agreement also provides for the Revolving Credit Facility in an amount of A200 million and an uncommitted incremental facility. As of the date of this offering memorandum, the Term Loan B Facility has been drawn in full and the Revolving Credit Facility has been drawn in an amount of A90.0 million in connection with Acquisition. (4) Represents cash of Refresco Group N.V. that was used to pay a portion of the transaction costs and other payments in connection with the Acquisition. 67 ----- (5) Represents the aggregate principal amount of Refresco’s syndicated term loan facility that was refinanced in connection with the Acquisition based on an EUR/USD exchange rate of A1.00/$1.20 and a EUR/GBP exchange rate of A1.00/£0.89 as of December 31, 2017. A24.7 million of existing debt of Refresco as of December 31, 2017, comprised of the Mortgage Loan, other loans and finance leases, has not been refinanced as part of the Transactions. (6) Represents the aggregate purchase price for the 81,160,915 Refresco Shares at the Offer Price, which represents an acquisition of 100% of the Refresco Shares. As of the date of this offering memorandum, Sunshine Investments B.V. holds 99.4% of the Refresco Shares. (7) Represents estimated fees and expenses associated with the Transactions, including accrued interest and break costs under the syndicated term loan of Refresco, commitment, underwriting, arranging, placement, original issue discount, financial advisory, legal, accounting, ratings advisory and other transaction costs and professional fees. These fees and expenses have been estimated as of the date of this offering memorandum and are subject to change. Additional fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Refinancing are not included. See ‘‘Use of Proceeds.’’

As of the date of this offering memorandum, the Issuer indirectly acquired 99.4% of the Refresco Shares and expects to indirectly acquire 100.0% of the Refresco Shares following the Squeeze-Out. The Issuer is offering the Notes as part of the permanent financing arrangements for the Acquisition. The Issuer is indirectly beneficially owned and controlled by the Equity Investors.

Subsection Title: Sources of Funds** **(E million)** **Uses of Funds** **(E million)
Subsubsection Text: Notes offered hereby[(1)] . . . . . . . . . . . . 445.0 Repayment of Bridge Facility . . . . . . . 445.0 Cash on hand at the Issuer . . . . . . . . . 6.2 Refinancing costs[(2)] . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 6.2

(1) Represents the gross proceeds of the offering of the Notes. (2) Refinancing costs include estimated fees and expenses associated with the Refinancing, excluding accrued interest on the Bridge Facility. These fees and costs have been estimated as of the date of this offering memorandum and are subject to change. Other expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions other than the Refinancing were paid by the Issuer, Sunshine Investments B.V. and Refresco and are excluded from this presentation. See ‘‘The Transactions—Sources and Uses for the _Acquisition.’’_ 69 -----

We estimate that the gross proceeds of the Offering will be A445.0 million. The Issuer will use the proceeds from the Offering to refinance amounts that were incurred under the Bridge Facility in connection with the Acquisition and to pay the costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Offering. See ‘‘The _Transactions—The Refinancing.’’_ The estimated sources and uses necessary to consummate the Refinancing are shown in the table below. Actual amounts may vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including the gross proceeds from the Notes offered hereby and differences to our estimates of fees and expenses. Any changes in these amounts may be reflected as an increase or decrease, as applicable, in the amount of cash. This table should be read in conjunction with ‘‘Capitalization.’’

Section Title: SELECTED COMBINED CARVE-OUT FINANCIAL INFORMATION OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL INFORMATION Introduction
Subsubsection Text: The unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated financial information has been prepared for illustrative purposes only to give effect to the following transactions: - the sale of 10% of the shares of Refresco Deutschland Holding GmbH by Refresco Europe B.V. to OKIL 2 Holdings B.V. in exchange for consideration of A15.6 million (see ‘‘Certain Relationships and _Related Party Transactions—Minority Ownership of Refresco Deutschland Holding GmbH’’);_ - the Cott TB Acquisition and the Acquisition (defined as the acquisition by Sunshine Investments B.V. of 97.4% of the shares of Refresco Group N.V. on March 29, 2018, and its subsequent acquisition of additional shares on April 9, 2018, which increased Sunshine Investments B.V.’s ownership stake in Refresco Group N.V.’s share capital to 99.378%); - the refinancing on the Completion Date of Refresco’s syndicated term loan facility outstanding as of December 31, 2017 with proceeds of the Term Loan B Facility and the refinancing with proceeds of such syndicated term loan facility or repayment by Cott Corporation of Cott TB’s indebtedness outstanding as of December 31, 2017 on January 30, 2018 as part of the Cott TB Acquisition; - the financing of the Acquisition with proceeds of the Equity Contribution, the Bridge Facility and the Senior Credit Facilities, in each case, as described in further detail in ‘‘The Transactions—the _Acquisition;’’_ - the Refinancing; and - the payment of costs, fees and expenses related to the foregoing; as if these transactions (the ‘‘Pro Forma Transactions’’) had occurred on January 1, 2017 for purposes of the income statement and as if these transactions had occured on December 31, 2017 for purposes of the balance sheet.

Section Title: SELECTED COMBINED CARVE-OUT FINANCIAL INFORMATION OF COTT TB
Subsubsection Text: The unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated balance sheet of the Issuer as of December 31, 2017, is based on and derived from (i) the audited consolidated balance sheet of Refresco as of December 31, 2017, prepared in accordance with IFRS, as adopted by the European Union (the ‘‘Refresco 2017 Balance Sheet’’); (ii) the audited combined carve-out balance sheet of Cott TB as of December 30, 2017, prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP (the ‘‘Cott TB 2017 Carve-Out Balance Sheet’’); (iii) unaudited condensed balance sheet information of Sunshine Investments B.V. as of December 31, 2017 prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP; and (iv) unaudited condensed balance sheet information of the Issuer as of December 31, 2017, prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. The unaudited _pro forma condensed consolidated income statement of the Issuer for the year ended December 31, 2017 is based on and derived from (i) the audited consolidated income statement of Refresco for the year ended December 31, 2017, prepared in accordance with IFRS, as adopted by the European Union (the ‘‘Refresco 2017 Income Statement’’); (ii) the audited combined carve-out income statement of Cott TB for the year ended December 30, 2017, prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP (the ‘‘Cott TB 2017 Carve-Out Income Statement’’); (iii) unaudited condensed income statement information of Sunshine Investments B.V. for the year ended December 31, 2017, prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP; and (iv) unaudited condensed income statement information of the Issuer for the year ended December 31, 2017, prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. For purposes of preparing the unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated financial information, certain adjustments have been made on the basis mentioned above (the ‘‘unaudited pro forma adjustments’’). The unaudited _pro forma adjustments are based on currently available financial information and certain assumptions that we believe are reasonable. The unaudited _pro forma condensed consolidated financial information gives effect to_ _pro forma adjustments that are directly attributable to the Pro Forma Transactions and it does not reflect anticipated operating efficiencies, cost savings or other synergies that may be achieved from such transactions. 77 -----

Section Title: SELECTED COMBINED CARVE-OUT FINANCIAL INFORMATION OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL INFORMATION (Continued)
Subsubsection Title: Accounting for the Acquisition and the Cott TB Acquisition
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer, through Sunshine Investments B.V., its wholly owned subsidiary, acquired 99.378% of the Refresco Shares as of April 9, 2018, for cash consideration of A1,613 million and expects to acquire the remaining Refresco Shares for cash consideration of approximately A10 million pursuant to the Squeeze-Out as described in ‘‘The Transactions—The Acquisition—The Squeeze-Out. On January 30, 2018, Refresco acquired Cott TB for a purchase price of $1,259.9 million. The Cott TB Acquisition and the Acquisition will be accounted for by the Issuer under IFRS, as adopted by the European Union, using the acquisition method as defined by IFRS 3 Business Combinations (‘‘IFRS 3’’). Under IFRS 3, assets acquired and liabilities assumed are recorded at their respective fair value on the date of acquisition and the consideration transferred is allocated to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed separately from goodwill. As of the date of this offering memorandum, the unaudited _pro forma condensed consolidated financial information presented in this offering memorandum is based_ on a preliminary allocation of the consideration transferred to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed, based on the historical carrying amounts of such assets and liabilities included in the Refresco Financial Statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2017 and the Cott TB Financial Statements as of and for the year ended December 30, 2017. The valuation studies necessary to finalize the fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed and the related allocation of the consideration transferred have not been completed. Therefore, the difference between (a) the total expected consideration transferred and (b) the net carrying amounts of the identifiable assets acquired and the liabilities assumed by Refresco on the completion date of the Cott TB Acquisition and by the Issuer on the Completion Date, respectively, have been fully allocated to goodwill in the unaudited pro forma condensed consolidated balance sheet. A final determination of fair value on the date of acquisition of the assets acquired and the liabilities assumed may differ significantly from the amounts reflected in the Issuer’s unaudited _pro forma condensed consolidated balance sheet included herein and, among other things, could result in a material change in our amortization and depreciation expense relating to identifiable assets acquired. Management believes that significant changes in the amount of goodwill recognized in relation to the Acquisition and/or the Cott TB Acquisition may arise due to the final determination of the purchase price allocation. 78 -----

Subsection Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL INFORMATION (Continued)
Subsubsection Text: The unaudited _pro forma condensed consolidated financial information is presented solely for informational purposes and is not intended to represent or be indicative of the consolidated income statements or financial position had the Pro Forma Transactions been completed as of the dates and for the periods presented, nor is it necessarily indicative of future results. The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information should be read in conjunction with ‘‘Use of Proceeds,’’ ‘‘Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Refresco,’’ ‘‘Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Cott TB,’’ ‘‘The Transactions,’’_ and the Refresco Financial Statements and related notes and the Cott TB Financial Statements and related notes, in each case, included elsewhere in the offering memorandum. The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information does not reflect any changes in the business of Refresco or Cott TB or any other changes arising from the Transactions since December 31, 2017. Rounding adjustments have been made in calculating some of the pro forma financial information included herein. Figures shown as totals in some tables and elsewhere may not be exact arithmetic aggregations of the figures that precede them.

Subsubsection Text: (b) We have eliminated the $54.9 million interest expense associated with Cott TB’s indebtedness described in the preceding footnote and made a corresponding increase to Cott TB’s cash and cash equivalents, in order to show the interest costs after such refinancing. (c) Given that Refresco will account for the Cott TB Acquisition using the acquisition method of accounting prescribed by IFRS 3, we have eliminated Cott TB’s historical goodwill. (d) We have adjusted cash and cash equivalents to reflect a decrease of $50 million in the amount of cash and cash equivalents held by Cott TB on the date of consummation of the Cott TB Acquisition. (e) We have performed a preliminary analysis of the Cott TB 2017 Carve-Out Balance Sheet as compared to the Refresco 2017 Balance Sheet and determined that there are no material adjustments needed to conform the accounting policies underpinning the Cott TB 2017 Carve-Out Balance Sheet under U.S. GAAP to the accounting policies underpinning the Refresco 2017 Balance Sheet under IFRS, as adopted by the European Union. (f) We have translated the Cott TB 2017 Carve-Out Balance Sheet from U.S. dollars to euros using the U.S. dollar to euro exchange rate as of December 31, 2017 of $1.198 to A1.00.

Section Title: SELECTED COMBINED CARVE-OUT FINANCIAL INFORMATION OF COTT TB
Subsubsection Text: The following tables set forth selected historical combined carve-out financial information of Cott TB as of and for the years ended January 2, 2016 (‘‘financial year ended 2015’’), December 31, 2016 (‘‘financial year ended 2016’’) and December 30, 2017 (‘‘financial year ended 2017’’). Cott TB’s financial data has been extracted from the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements, which have been derived from Cott Corporation’s historical accounting records and the historical cost basis of the assets and liabilities of the Canadian CSD business and the following legal entities comprising the Cott Traditional Business: Cott Beverages Inc., Cliffstar LLC, Cott Vending Inc., Cott IP Holdings Corp., Pri-Pak Inc. (for the financial year ended 2017), Interim BCB, LLC, Northeast Retailer Brands LLC, Cott Beverages Limited, Cott Developments Limited, Cooke Bros Holdings Limited, Cooke Bros (Tattenhall) Limited, Mr. Freeze (Europe) Limited, Calypso Soft Drinks Limited, Tip Top Soft Drinks Limited, Cott Ventures Limited, TT Calco Limited, Jay Juice Limited, Cott Nelson (Holdings) Limited, Cott (Nelson) Limited, Cott Private Label Limited, Mexico Bottling Services, S.A. de C.V., Servicios Gerenciales de Mexico, S.A. de C.V., Cott Embotelladores de Mexico, S.A. de C.V., Cott Maquinaria y Equipo, S.A. de C.V. and Cott Retail Brands Netherlands B.V. The Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP and have been audited by Cott Corporation’s independent auditors, PwC, as set forth in its audit report included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. These historical results are not necessarily indicative of future results. Certain of these entities have been renamed following the Cott TB Acquisition. Prospective investors should read the summary financial information and other data below in conjunction with, and the summary financial information and other data below is qualified in its entirety by reference to, ‘‘Presentation of Financial Information,’’ ‘‘Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition _and Results of Operation of Cott TB’’ and the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements, including the notes_ thereto, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Text: Refresco is an independent bottler of soft drinks and fruit juices for retailers and A-brands in Europe and North America. Refresco has long-standing relationships with leading discounters and full-service retailers across Europe with a broad and sophisticated range of retailer brand offerings. Refresco is also a contract manufacturing partner for national and international branded beverage companies who can rely on Refresco’s efficient multi-user production platform and additional services. Refresco also manufactures and sells specialty soft drink products on a small scale under its own brands, which are included under the retailer brands segment for reporting purposes. Since 1999, Refresco has expanded its operations through a ‘‘buy-and-build’’ strategy, completing over 20 acquisitions that achieved synergies averaging 3.5% to 5.0% of target revenue. For the year ended December 31, 2017, Refresco’s segments were divided into Europe and North America. Refresco’s European segment is divided into the following business units: Benelux (including the Netherlands and Belgium), Germany, France, Italy, the UK, Iberia (including Spain and Portugal), Finland and Poland. Refresco sold 7,104 million liters of soft drinks and had a gross profit margin per liter of 14.0 euro cents for the year ended December 31, 2017. Refresco’s consolidated revenue was A2,268.8 million and Refresco’s Adjusted EBITDA was A213.9 million, in each case, for the year ended December 31, 2017. As of December 31, 2017, Refresco had 5,635 employees.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Refresco’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Retailer Brands and Contract Manufacturing Growth
Subsubsection Text: Refresco’s revenue is derived from manufacturing soft drinks for retail chains under their own retailer brands and from contract manufacturing, the manufacturing of soft drinks for brand owners that have 92 ----- outsourced production to Refresco. In the year ended December 31, 2017, retailer brands accounted for approximately 70% of Refresco’s consolidated revenue and contract manufacturing accounted for the remaining 30%. Retailer brands has historically performed relatively well during economic downturns as end-consumers look to value-for-money alternatives. Retailer brands growth is also driven by consolidation of retail chains (in countries such as Italy and Poland), while in more mature markets such as the UK, the Netherlands and Germany, retailers continue to develop their retailer brands strategies to support growth. Further, the global financial downturn and the weakening of consumer sentiment thereafter helped discount retailers such as Aldi and Lidl to gain a strong foothold in the UK market. Revenue derived from contract manufacturing is mainly driven by the outsourcing of production by brand owners. Reasons for outsourcing include: (i) increased focus on ‘‘asset-light’’ strategies; (ii) higher operational efficiency of specialist manufacturing players like us as a result of more management focus and greater ability to optimize line utilization; (iii) a need for backup capacity covering peak demand or breakdowns of their own production lines; and (iv) smaller branded players and new entrants looking for manufacturing capacity throughout the footprint.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Refresco’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Refresco’s revenue is determined by volume and pricing. Volume (expressed in liters) is the most important driver of revenue. Because changes in revenue are largely driven by fluctuations in input prices that are passed on to customers, volume as well as gross profit margin per liter, Adjusted EBITDA and cash flow may be more meaningful indicators of business performance than revenue. Refresco strives to increase sales volume in order to maximize utilization of its production lines and obtain more competitive input pricing. Volumes are affected by the overall performance of the European and North American economies. Weaker market conditions in Western Europe during 2017 put pressure on retailer brand volumes during the second half of the year due to unusually low temperatures and high levels of precipitation during the summer in almost all markets. In 2017, however, contract manufacturing showed solid growth across most of Refresco’s geographies. Pricing also has a significant impact on Refresco’s revenue and profitability. Refresco’s sales prices for retailer brands are affected by a variety of factors, in particular the cost of raw materials and packaging materials, manufacturing and distributing products and the availability and price of competing products. Refresco invoices the customer for all of these inputs. In contract manufacturing, Refresco operates as a tolling manufacturer and as such the customer provides the raw materials and packaging materials and Refresco bases its pricing on a filling fee. As a result, larger packaged products generate less revenue per liter. The trend over the past years towards smaller sized products has caused revenue to grow at a higher rate than liter volumes. The soft drinks market is fragmented, causing Refresco to adopt different pricing policies per product category. Some of Refresco’s retailer brands products, such as RTD teas, energy drinks and water, compete directly with comparable retailer brands and A-brand products, which constrains Refresco’s ability to set prices. In less competitive categories such as NFC juices and A-PET, Refresco has greater flexibility to adopt pricing strategies that maximize revenue. In newer product categories such as energy drinks packaged in PET and cans, there is also usually greater scope to use new packaging types and sizes to effect price changes. In addition, higher prices can be charged in more remote regions, reflecting the higher transport costs involved in manufacturing and distributing products. _Gross profit margin_ Refresco balances execution of its strategy around gross profit margin and volume growth in order to improve profitability. Refresco’s management tracks the development of price movements relative to volume by the key performance indicator of gross profit margin per liter, calculated as revenue and other income minus raw materials and consumables used, expressed per liter of volume. In general, Refresco considers a higher gross profit margin per liter more important than volume growth, and may therefore decide not to tender for certain low margin customer contracts, move production to other plants or even shut down production at one location altogether in order to protect or increase its gross profit margin per liter. In 2017, gross profit margins were better than expected in spite of the lower volumes in Western Europe, due largely to Refresco’s decision to decrease low margin retailer brand contracts in Germany and Iberia. 93 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Refresco’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Since 1999, Refresco has completed over 20 acquisitions, bringing annual revenue from approximately A84.5 million in 1999 to A2,268.8 million in 2017 and historically has achieved synergies averaging 3.5% to 5.0% of targeted revenues. In addition to increasing volume and revenue, Refresco incurs certain one-off costs and expenses in connection with any potential acquisition. Refresco has adjusted for certain of these one-off costs in its Adjusted EBITDA for the period. See ‘‘—Non-GAAP Financial Measures’’ for further information on these adjustments. Refresco completed four acquisitions in 2016 and 2017. Refresco acquired the PepsiCo bottling facility in Germany in February 2016, the Dutch contract manufacturing business DIS in March 2016, Whitlock Packaging (a large-scale bottler focused on contract manufacturing in the U.S.) in July 2016 and San Pellegrino’s bottling facility in Recoaro, Italy in March 2017. Refresco also completed the transformative Cott TB Acquisition on January 30, 2018 nearly doubling the size of its business, gaining 29 manufacturing facilities in North America and the United Kingdom. It is Refresco’s ambition to achieve run-rate synergies relating to procurement, operations and overhead in a total amount of approximately A62.8 million in the first three years following the Cott TB Acquisition. See ‘‘Summary— _Recent Developments—The Cott TB Acquisition.’’_ As a general matter, following an acquisition, Refresco’s results of operations are impacted by the results of the newly acquired business, the purchase accounting for the acquisition, any debt incurred to acquire the business and expenditures made to integrate the newly acquired business. When intending to integrate and improve a newly acquired business, Refresco will: (i) review current sales prices and product engineering to achieve increased margins on products sold; (ii) evaluate ways to further enhance purchasing power towards suppliers to benefit from economies of scale; (iii) reduce duplicated overhead; (iv) move production to the most efficient locations, subject to geography and logistics; (v) share knowledge and experience; (vi) create synergies with and benefits to the existing businesses; and (vii) improve management of working capital. Many of these integration measures require investment in the form of operating costs and capital expenditures.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Refresco’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Prices of Raw Materials and Packaging Materials
Subsubsection Text: Raw materials and packaging materials are Refresco’s largest cost component, accounting for over two-thirds of the total cost base. In 2017, Refresco spent A1,277.2 million on raw materials and consumables costs. Raw materials constituted 57.7% of this amount, with packing materials and product tax constituting the remaining 41.1% and 1.2%, respectively. Refresco’s exposure to price fluctuations of raw materials and packaging materials mainly impacts its retailer brands business. In contract manufacturing, this price risk is typically borne by the customer, as Refresco operates as a tolling manufacturer. Raw materials include primarily orange juice, apple juice and sugar. Packaging materials are mainly aluminum cans, liquid paperboard and PET. Where feasible, Refresco has a policy of forward purchasing raw materials and packaging materials to cover sales positions with customers. Refresco hedges the raw material aluminum through derivatives. The fair value of this raw material derivative is recognized in profit and loss. The fair value for the year ended December 31, 2017 is A1.0 million debit as compared to A0.8 million debit for the year ended December 31, 2016. Some of Refresco’s raw materials are priced only in U.S. dollars, and Refresco mitigates the effect of exchange rate fluctuations by using U.S. dollars purchase options and forward contracts. Historically, prices for raw materials and packaging materials have fluctuated considerably. In 2017, prices for raw materials generally increased, with the exception of sugar as Europe’s sugar crop was better than anticipated leading to improved availability. The sugar market experienced important changes in October 2017, with the abolition of the quota system for food-use sugar. This resulted in competitive prices from suppliers and caused the European market to shift from an import to an export market. Key packaging material prices were affected by the more favorable economic circumstances and the increasing oil price, resulting in higher overall prices. In addition, the supplier base is highly concentrated, with only a few suppliers available for each category of products sourced. Again, this dependency mainly impacts the retailer brands business, which is more reliant on Refresco’s sourcing than contract manufacturing, where customers largely source the raw materials used. Refresco focuses on creating alternative supply chains to mitigate this dependency by sourcing from smaller suppliers or replacing certain supplies with alternative products. An increase in the prices of raw materials and packaging materials generally leads to an increase in the sales prices of Refresco’s products as these increases can typically be passed on to customers when contracts are renewed because most of the costs, such as sugar and packaging costs, generally affect the 94 ----- entire industry. Refresco attempts to ensure that it always has sufficient raw materials and packaging materials in stock. Refresco has adopted a policy to enter into forward purchase contracts—up to 12 months in advance—for most raw materials and packaging materials to ensure that it can cover sales positions with Refresco’s customers. This allows Refresco to limit its exposure to sales are under- or over-covered by corresponding forward purchase contracts. This matching policy does not extend to all materials (for instance, PET is only partly covered as there is no market and it must be physically stored) or to all situations (for instance, small contracts). A small portion of materials costs experience approximately a half-year delay in passing through the commodity price changes to the agreed sales pricing, resulting in a small upside or downside deviation of gross profit margin per liter over time. In some cases, Refresco may decide not to fully increase the prices of its products in order to sell a greater volume of products.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Refresco’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Sales of soft drinks are affected by weather, with sales generally being higher in the hot, dry months from April to September and lower during the colder and wetter months of October to March. Higher sales of water and CSDs are also achieved around the Christmas/New Year holiday period in late December. Fruit juice sales are generally evenly spread across the year. Seasonal changes are almost entirely sales relating to the retailer brands business, as Refresco can produce for its contract manufacturing customers upfront. While these end-consumer buying patterns lead to a natural seasonality in sales, unseasonable weather could significantly affect sales and profitability. For example, retailer brand volumes were adversely impacted in 2017 due to unusually low temperatures and high levels of precipitation during the summer in almost all of Refresco’s markets. The geographical diversity and diverse product mix mitigates part of the effect of seasonality.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Refresco’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: _Transactional_ As a result of the geographic spread of operations, Refresco generates a portion of its revenue, and incurs a significant portion of its expenses, in currencies other than the euro, including the U.S. dollar, the British pound and the Polish zloty. Typically, Refresco aims to align costs with revenue denominated in the same currency, but Refresco is not always able to do so, and results of operations are consequently impacted by currency exchange rate fluctuations. Some raw materials, such as frozen concentrated orange juice, are only available for sale in U.S. dollars. As with raw materials prices, Refresco hedges its currency exposures back-to-back. During the periods under review, Refresco hedged 80% to 100% of its foreign currency exposure on contracted forecasted purchases. Refresco uses currency option contracts and forward exchange contracts to hedge its currency risks, most of which have a maturity date of less than one year from the reporting date. When necessary, foreign currency contracts are rolled over on maturity. Further, annual changes to raw material costs driven by exchange rates can generally be passed on to the customers with a slight time lag, in the same way as fluctuations in raw materials prices, at the time a customer’s contract is renewed. In respect of other monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies, Refresco aims to ensure that its net exposure is kept to an acceptable level by buying or selling foreign currencies at spot rates. The fair value of foreign currency instruments as at December 31, 2017 was A2.6 million as compared to A9.7 million debit as at December 31, 2016. Additionally, Refresco entered into deal contingent hedges of a total amount of $750.0 million to hedge the cash out flow for the acquisition of Cott TB. The contracts were valued as at December 31, 2017 at a fair value of A2.8 million debit. The deal contingent hedges settled on January 29, 2018 in line with management’s estimate. For further information, please refer to note 6.5 of the Refresco Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2017. The amounts deferred in equity at year-end are expected to occur and to affect profit or loss for majority in 2017. See footnote 3 to the Refresco Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2017 for further information. _Translational_ Refresco reports its consolidated financial statements in its functional currency which is the euro. As a result, the assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses of all of its operations with a currency other than the euro are translated into euro at then applicable exchange rates. Consequently, increases or decreases in the value of the euro affect the value of these items with respect to the non-euro-denominated businesses in the consolidated financial statements, even if their value has not changed in their original currency. For example, a stronger euro will reduce the reported results of operations of non-euro businesses and 95 ----- conversely a weaker euro will increase the reported results of operations of non-euro businesses. These translations could significantly affect the comparability of Refresco’s results between financial periods and/or result in significant changes to the carrying value of Refresco’s assets, liabilities and shareholders’ equity. The effects of these translations are recorded in the consolidated income statement as exchange differences on retranslation of foreign operations.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Refresco’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Refresco’s operations, the key operating measures discussed below and its results of operations were affected during the periods under review, and may continue to be affected, by certain key factors including, in particular, the growth of retailer brands and contract manufacturing, volume and pricing, growth through acquisitions, prices of raw materials and packaging, seasonality and exchange rates. Each of these factors is discussed in more detail below.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Title: Impact of the Cott TB Acquisition and the Transactions
Subsubsection Text: On January 30, 2018, Refresco acquired Cott TB for a purchase price of $1,259.9 million. The Issuer through Sunshine Investments B.V., its wholly owned subsidiary, acquired 97.4% of the Refresco Shares and acquired a further 2.1% of the Refresco Shares on April 9, 2018 for combined cash consideration of A1,613 million and expects to acquire the remaining Refresco Shares for cash consideration of A10 million pursuant to the Squeeze-Out as described in ‘‘The Transactions—The Acquisition—The Squeeze-Out.’’ The Cott TB Acquisition and the Acquisition will ultimately be accounted for by the Issuer under IFRS using the acquisition method as defined by IFRS 3. Pending the completion of the purchase price accounting, pro _forma goodwill in an amount of A2,390.1 million is presented in the pro forma financial information of the_ Issuer presented under the heading ‘‘Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information.’’ The consolidated financial information reported by Refresco following the Cott TB Acquisition and the Transactions is not comparable with the consolidated financial information reported by Refresco prior to the Cott TB Acquisition and the Transactions due to (i) the application of purchase accounting as of January 30, 2018 in connection with the Cott TB Acquisition and the application of purchase accounting as of March 29, 2018 in connection with the Acquisition, (ii) changes to depreciation and amortization expenses, among other things, that may result from the purchase accounting of the Cott TB Acquisition and the Acquisition, (iii) additional interest expense associated with the financing of the Acquisition and the Refinancing and (iv) Sunshine Top B.V. being the reporting entity for the consolidated group.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Text: Following the adoption of IFRS 15, Refresco will recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which Refresco expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services. Refresco has reviewed customer contracts, identified the separate performance obligations, determined the transaction price, allocated the transaction price and determined when a performance obligation has been satisfied. Contracts are reviewed for presence of variable considerations such as discounts, rebates, refunds, credits, price concessions, incentives, performance bonuses, penalties and/or any other compensations received from clients. Refresco will apply the modified retrospective approach and expects some small adjustments in capital expense contributions and storage contributions, but did not yet finalize the assessment of the quantitative impact on the financial statements. However, based on the analysis performed so far, Refresco expects no significant impact.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Text: Refresco leases office buildings, warehouses, machinery and equipment and cars. For the year 2017, Refresco recognized an expense in the income statement of A40.0 million and reported a contingent liability relating to these assets of A156.7 as of December 31, 2017. Under IFRS 16, which will become effective on January 1, 2019, most of these contracts classify as leases because Refresco has the right to control the assets. Under IFRS 16 the asset value of these assets will be recorded as Property, plant and equipment and the corresponding lease liability will be recorded as a liability. The lease expenses will be transferred from the Other operating expenses to Depreciation, Amortization and impairments and Finance expenses. Refresco will apply the modified retrospective transition method and is reviewing the lease contracts and identifying proper measurements. As of the date of this offering memorandum, Refresco cannot quantify the impact of the new standard.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Text: Refresco’s operating segments engage in business activities from which they earn revenues and incur expenses. In 2016, Refresco divided into its operating segments into Europe and the U.S. to reflect its entry into North America following the acquisition of Whitlock Packaging. The U.S. segment was subsequently renamed North America to reflect Canadian and Mexican operations acquired as part of the 96 ----- Cott TB Acquisition. In 2017, Refresco separated the corporate activities from the European segment in anticipation of its future growth. Because the corporate activities do not generate external revenues, Refresco has not defined these activities as a separate segment. See note 4.1 to the Refresco Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2017 for further information.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: Revenue consists of sales of retailer brands and own brands, which is measured at fair value of the consideration received or receivable, net of returns, trade discounts and volume rebates, and contract manufacturing, which consists of the provision of manufacturing services and sale of the resultant product. Revenue development is effectively a net result of the developments of volume, gross profit margin per liter and raw materials price movements. Refresco aims to pass on raw materials price movements to Refresco’s customers when they renew their contracts. Refresco’s pricing model targets certain negotiated gross profit margins per liter by customer, and revenue may vary from year to year as input costs change. As such, year-on-year variations in revenue may not be indicative of performance.

Subsubsection Text: Finance income comprises interest income on bank deposits and fair value gains on interest hedging instruments that are recognized in profit or loss. Interest income is recognized in profit or loss as it accrues, using the effective interest method.

Revenue increased by A161.4 million, or 7.7%, to A2,268.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2017 from A2,107.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2016. Changes in revenue are mostly driven by the full year effect of acquisitions completed in prior periods and fluctuations in input prices that are typically passed on to customers, and, as such, revenue is not many not be a meaningful indicator of the development of Refresco’s business. Volume increased by 641.9 million liters, or 9.9%, to 7,104.2 million liters in the year ended December 31, 2017 from 6,462.3 million liters in the year ended December 31, 2016. In the Benelux, volume growth of 10.8% was mainly driven by the full year effect of the Dutch contract manufacturing business DIS acquisition in May 2016. In Italy, the acquisition of San Pellegrino’s bottling facility in Recoaro in March 2017 and strong growth in retailer brands contributed to the 7.8% volume growth in the year ended December 31, 2017 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2016. The volume increase in the U.S. was fully attributable to the full year effect of the acquisition of Whitlock Packaging in September 2016. Volumes in the U.S. and the UK will also significantly increase in 2018 as a result of the Cott TB Acquisition. 99 ----- The following tables set forth Refresco’s revenues and volume, split between retailer brands and contract manufacturing for the periods indicated.

Raw materials, consumables and product tax accounted for 58.9% of the total spend in 2017 as compared to 68.5% in 2016 and packaging materials accounted for 41.1% of the total spend in 2017 as compared to 31.5% in 2016. Prices for Refresco’s key raw materials increased in 2017 with the exception of sugar, which experienced improved availability due to a better-than-expected sugar crop in Europe. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Text: Contract manufacturing volume amounted to 1,730.8 million liters in the year ended December 31, 2016, an increase of 49.0% compared to 1,164.2 million liters in the year ended December 31, 2015, and 8.3% on a like-for-like basis. As a percentage of total volume contract manufacturing comprised 26.8% of total volume in the year ended December 31, 2016 as compared to 19.1% in the year ended December 31, 2015. 104 ----- Retailer brands volume amounted to 4,731.5 million liters in the year ended December 31, 2016, a decrease of 4.1% compared to 4,931.3 million liters in the year ended December 31, 2016. As a percentage of total volume retailer brands volume comprised 73.2% of total volume in the year ended December 31, 2016 as compared to 80.9% in the year ended December 31, 2015. The retailer brands market faces competition from A-brand products as the price gap has decreased, which is directly linked to raw material price movements. A smaller price difference between A-brand and retailer brands products makes it easier for consumers to choose A-brand products. In particular, retailer brands had a challenging start of the year in 2016 as a result of Refresco’s commercial decision to discontinue low margin-large volume contracts for water and CSD products in Poland and Germany, which impacted its volumes, but did not impact its profitability. Towards the end of 2016, Refresco started to regain part of those contracts, which had a positive impact on its volumes. _Raw materials and consumables_ The following table sets forth Refresco’s raw materials and consumables used for the periods indicated.

Furthermore, the effective tax rate is impacted by the rate change in Italy and Germany, and other taxes to be paid in France and Italy. Subsubsection Title: Net cash generated from operating activities
Subsubsection Text: In the year ended December 31, 2017, Refresco’s net cash generated from operating activities amounted to A146.5 million consisting of (i) A201.1 million of cash flows from operating activities before changes in working capital (of which A96.3 million was related to depreciation, amortization and impairments), (ii) a A0.8 million increase in working capital, which was offset by A21.0 million net amount of interest paid and (iii) A34.7 million income taxes paid. The decrease in net cash flow from operating activities in 2017 as compared to 2016 is almost entirely due to lower EBITDA for the year and higher interest costs partly offset by improved working capital management particularly by managing inventory levels and focusing on improving payables and receivables. Accruals for the Cott TB Acquisition and the closing of the German PepsiCo plant in Hamburg also improved working capital. In the year ended December 31, 2016, Refresco’s net cash generated from operating activities amounted to A156.5 million consisting of (i) A213.6 million of cash flows from operating activities before changes in working capital (of which A87.6 million was related to depreciation, amortization and impairments), (ii) a A18.3 million decrease in working capital, which was offset by A16.8 million net amount of interest paid and (iii) A22.1 million income taxes paid. In the year ended December 31, 2015, Refresco’s net cash generated from operating activities amounted to A129.9 million consisting of (i) A188.0 million of cash flows from operating activities before changes in working capital (of which A84.5 million was related to depreciation, amortization and impairments), (ii) a A12.1 million increase in working capital, which was offset by A34.3 million net amount of interest paid and (iii) A23.0 million income taxes paid.
