Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Text: In 2017, capital expenditures spending was A84.6 million, as Refresco continued to optimize its footprint across Europe. It started up the commercial production of a second A-PET line in the Benelux, enabling the production of more natural, preservative free drinks. Refresco also invested in a third autoclave in the Benelux, a production technology that enables it to produce cold coffee drinks and protein drinks in can format. In France, Refresco installed new A-PET lines and invested in a new Elopak carton line to match the growing demand for organic and premium juices in more sustainable carton packaging. A new low-acid line became operational in 2017 in the UK and Refresco additionally invested in a new A-PET line to meet the demand for low- and high-acid drinks, which is expected to become operational in 2018. Refresco’s investments in a high-speed water line in Poland during 2016 also came on line this year. In Germany, Refresco decided to transfer A-PET bottling activities from its Hamburg manufacturing site to Calv¨orde because this site runs more modern facilities for the bottling of ice tea, juice drinks, juices and flavored water and provides sufficient opportunities for capacity expansions and growth initiatives going forward. Refresco also expanded capabilities at its Recoaro site to further optimize its footprint in Italy and acquired land and building in Keighley, UK, including a water well to tap into this growing category. In the U.S., Refresco invested in a new high-speed carton line. In addition to normal maintenance investments, Refresco invested in further efficiencies by replacing fillers and other production line components across its businesses. Furthermore, Refresco continued to roll-out its continuous improvement program PEX focused on helping to drive leadership development 110 ----- and to advance standardized activities and processes across Refresco. As a result UK and Poland received their first PEX certificates, Benelux was re-certified and Refresco started to roll-out the PEX program in the U.S. In 2016, capital expenditures spending was A87.7 million, comprising of investments in the installation of two A-PET lines, one low-acid line and three PET filling lines in the Benelux, UK, Poland, Spain and Italy, respectively. In 2015, capital expenditure spending was A80.8 million, primarily attributable to investments in a new warehouse facility in Gr¨unsfeld, Germany and new A-PET bottling lines in France and invested in additional A-PET capacity in the UK, Italy and Poland.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Text: _Goodwill_ Goodwill is initially measured at cost (being the excess of the aggregate of the consideration transferred and the amount recognized for non-controlling interests and any previous interest held over the net identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed). If the fair value of the net assets acquired is in excess of the aggregate consideration transferred, Refresco re-assesses whether it has correctly identified all of the assets acquired and all of the liabilities assumed and reviews the procedures used to measure the amounts to be recognized at the acquisition date. If the reassessment still results in an excess of the fair value of net assets acquired over the aggregate consideration transferred, then the gain is recognized in profit or loss. After initial recognition, goodwill is measured at cost less any accumulated impairment losses. For the purpose of impairment testing, goodwill acquired in a business combination is, from the acquisition date, allocated to each of Refresco’s cash-generating units that are expected to benefit from the combination, irrespective of whether other assets or liabilities of the acquiree are assigned to those units. Where goodwill has been allocated to a cash-generating unit (‘‘CGU’’) and part of the operation within that unit is disposed of, the goodwill associated with the disposed operation is included in the carrying amount of the operation when determining the gain or loss on disposal. Goodwill disposed in these circumstances is measured based on the relative values of the disposed operation and the portion of the cash-generating unit retained. Refresco assesses, at each reporting date, whether there is an indication that an asset may be impaired. If any indication exists, or when annual impairment testing for an asset is required, Refresco estimates the asset’s recoverable amount. An asset’s recoverable amount is the higher of an asset’s or CGU’s fair value less costs of disposal and its value in use. The recoverable amount is determined for an individual asset, unless the asset does not generate cash inflows that are largely independent of those from other assets or groups of assets. When the carrying amount of an asset or CGU exceeds its recoverable amount, the asset is considered impaired and is written down to its recoverable amount. Impairment losses of continuing operations are recognized in the income statement in expense categories consistent with the function of the impaired asset, except for properties previously revalued with the 111 ----- revaluation taken to OCI. For such properties, the impairment is recognized in OCI up to the amount of any previous revaluation. _Other Intangibles_ Software acquired by Refresco is measured at cost less accumulated amortization and accumulated impairment losses. Subsequent expenditure is capitalized only to the extent that it increases the future economic benefits embodied in the specific asset to which it relates. All other expenditure, including expenditure on internally generated goodwill and brands, is recognized in profit or loss as incurred. Amortization is recognized in the income statement on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives, generally 3 years. Brands acquired, separately or as part of a business combination, are capitalized if they meet the definition of an intangible asset and the recognition criteria are satisfied. Brands acquired as part of a business combination are valued at fair value based on the relief from royalty method. Brands are amortized on an individual basis over the estimated useful life of the brand. Customer and sales channel-related and contract-based intangibles are capitalized if they meet the definition of an intangible asset and the recognition criteria are satisfied. The relationship between brands and customer and sales channel-related intangibles is carefully considered so that brands and customer and sales channel-related intangibles are not both recognized on the basis of the same cash flows. Customer and sales channel-related and contract-based intangibles acquired as part of a business combination are valued at fair value and amortized over the period of the contractual arrangements or the remaining useful life of the customer relationships.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Text: _Transactions and Balances in Foreign Currency_ Transactions in foreign currencies are translated into the respective functional currencies of group entities at the exchange rates at the dates of the transactions. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are translated at the functional currency spot rates of exchange at the reporting date. Differences arising on settlement or translation of monetary items are recognized in profit or loss with the exception of monetary items that are designated as part of the hedge of the Refresco’s net investment of a foreign operation. These are recognized in other comprehensive income (‘‘OCI’’) until the net investment is disposed of, at which time, the cumulative amount is reclassified to profit or loss. Tax charges and credits attributable to exchange differences on those monetary items are also recorded in OCI. Non-monetary items that are measured in terms of historical cost in a foreign currency are translated using the exchange rates at the dates of the initial transactions. Non-monetary items measured at fair value in a foreign currency are translated using the exchange rates at the date when the fair value is determined. The gain or loss arising on translation of non-monetary items measured at fair value is treated in line with the recognition of the gain or loss on the change in fair value of the item i.e. translation differences on items whose fair value gain or loss is recognized in OCI or profit or loss are also recognized in OCI or profit or loss, respectively. _Foreign operations_ The assets and liabilities of foreign operations, including goodwill and fair value adjustments arising on acquisition, are translated into euros at the exchange rate at the reporting date. The income and expenses of foreign operations are translated into euros at the exchange rates at the dates of the transactions (or at an average rate if this is not an unreasonable approximation). Foreign currency differences arising thereon are recognized, in OCI, in the foreign currency translation reserve. When a foreign operation is disposed of, either in part or in full, the associated cumulative amount in the foreign currency translation reserve is transferred to profit or loss as an adjustment to the profit or loss on disposal. Foreign exchange gains and losses arising on a monetary item receivable from or payable to a foreign operation, the settlement of which is neither planned nor likely in the foreseeable future, are considered to form part of the net investment in the foreign operation and are recognized in other comprehensive income in the foreign currency translation reserve. 112 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Title: Derivative financial instruments and hedging activities
Subsubsection Text: Refresco holds derivative financial instruments (interest rate swaps, commodity hedges, forward exchange contracts and currency options) to hedge its foreign currency, commodity and interest rate risk exposures. Refresco seeks to apply hedge accounting in order to minimize the effects of fluctuations of foreign currencies and interest rates in the profit or loss. Derivative financial instruments are initially recognized at fair value on the date a derivative contract is entered into and are subsequently re-measured at fair value. The method of recognizing the resulting gain or loss depends on whether the derivative financial instrument is designated as a hedging instrument, and if so, the nature of the item being hedged. Refresco applies cash flow hedge accounting. Refresco documents at the inception of the transaction the relationship between hedging instruments and hedged items, as well as its risk management objectives and strategy for undertaking various hedging transactions. Refresco also documents its assessment, both at hedge inception and on an ongoing basis, of whether the derivatives used in hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes in fair values or cash flows of hedged items. The effective portion of changes in the fair value of derivative financial instruments that are designated and qualify as cash flow hedges is recognized in other comprehensive income. The gain or loss relating to the ineffective portion is recognized in the income statement immediately. When the hedged item is a non-financial asset, the amount recognized in other comprehensive income is transferred to the carrying amount of the asset when it is recognized. In other cases the amount recognized in other comprehensive income is transferred to the same line of profit or loss in the same period that the hedged item affects profit or loss. Where the financial instruments are held to hedge foreign currency purchases of raw materials and consumables, the changes are included in raw materials and consumables used. Where the instruments are held to hedge interest rate risk exposure, the changes are included in finance income and expense. If the hedging instrument no longer meets the criteria for hedge accounting, expires or is sold, terminated or exercised, then hedge accounting is discontinued. The cumulative unrealized gain or loss previously recognized in other comprehensive income and presented in the hedging reserve in equity, is recognized in profit or loss immediately, or when a hedging instrument is terminated. If the hedged transaction is still expected to occur, the cumulative gain or loss at that point remains in other comprehensive income and is recognized in accordance with the above-mentioned policy when the transaction occurs. The fair values of various derivative instruments used for hedging purposes are disclosed in note 3.3 of the Refresco Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2017. Movements of the hedging reserve in other comprehensive income are shown in note 5.8 of the Refresco Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2017. The full fair value of a hedging derivative is classified as a non-current asset or liability when the remaining maturity of the hedged item is more than 12 months and as a current asset or liability when the remaining maturity of the hedged item is less than 12 months.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Text: _Defined contribution plans_ A defined contribution plan is a pension plan under which Refresco pays fixed contributions into a separate entity. Refresco has no legal or constructive obligations to pay further contributions if the fund does not hold sufficient assets to pay all employees the benefits relating to employee service in the current and prior periods. For defined contribution plans, Refresco pays contributions to publicly or privately administered pension insurance plans on a mandatory, contractual or voluntary basis. Refresco has no further payment obligations once the contributions have been paid. The contributions are recognized as employee benefit expense when they are due. Prepaid contributions are recognized as an asset to the extent that a cash refund or a reduction in the future payments is available. 113 ----- _Defined benefit plans_ A defined benefit plan is a pension plan that is not a defined contribution plan. Typically defined benefit plans define an amount of pension benefit that an employee will receive on retirement, usually dependent on one or more factors such as age, years of service and compensation. The liability recognized in the balance sheet in respect of defined benefit pension plans is the present value of the defined benefit obligation at the end of the reporting period less the fair value of plan assets. The defined benefit obligation is calculated annually by independent actuaries using the projected unit credit method. The present value of the defined benefit obligation is determined by discounting the estimated future cash outflows using interest rates of high-quality corporate bonds that are denominated in the currency in which the benefits will be paid, and that have terms to maturity approximating to the terms of the related pension obligation. In countries where there is no deep market in such bonds, the market rates on government bonds are used. For pension plans whereby a limit on the employer’s future contribution to the pension plans exist, Refresco will reflect this limit in its calculations. For these plans, Refresco will apply a liability cap in case the present value of the future service cost exceeds the present value of the future maximum employer contributions and the defined benefit obligation exceeds the asset value. The liability cap does not exceed the difference between the defined benefit obligation and the asset value. Actuarial gains and losses arising from experience adjustments and changes in actuarial assumptions are charged or credited in other comprehensive income in the period in which they arise. Past-service costs are recognized immediately in income. _Multi-employer plans_ Refresco also facilitates multi-employer plans, in which various employers contribute to one central pension union. In accordance with IAS 19R, as the pension union managing the plan is not able to provide Refresco with sufficient information to enable Refresco to account for the plan as a defined benefit plan, Refresco accounts for its multi-employer defined benefit plan as if it were a defined contribution plan. _Other long-term employee benefits_ The net obligation in respect of long term employee benefits other than pension plans is the amount of future benefit that employees have earned in return for their service in the current and prior years; that benefit is discounted to determine its present value, and the fair value of any related assets is deducted. The discount rate is the yield at the reporting date on AA credit-rated bonds that have maturity dates approximating the terms of the obligations of Refresco. The calculation is performed using the projected unit credit method. Actuarial gains or losses are recognized in profit or loss in the period in which they arise. _Termination benefits_ Termination benefits are employee benefits provided in exchange for the termination of an employee’s employment as a result of either an entity’s decision to terminate an employee’s employment before the normal retirement date; or an employee’s decision to accept an offer of benefits in exchange for the termination of employment. A liability is recognized at the earlier of the following dates: when the entity can no longer withdraw the offer of those benefits; and when the entity recognizes costs for a restructuring and involves the payment of termination benefits. _Short term benefits_ Short term employee benefit obligations are measured on an undiscounted basis and are expensed as the related service is provided. A liability is recognized for the amount expected to be paid under short term cash bonus or profit-sharing plans if Refresco has a legal or constructive obligation to pay this amount as a result of past service provided by the employee and the obligation can be reliably estimated. 114 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Text: Significant accounting policies are those that: (i) are relevant to the presentation of Refresco’s financial condition and results of operations; and (ii) require the management’s most difficult, subjective or complex judgments, often as a result of the need to make estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain. As the number of variables and assumptions affecting the possible future resolution of uncertainties increases, those judgments become even more subjective and complex. In order to provide an understanding of how Refresco’s management forms its judgments about future events, including the variables and assumptions underlying its estimates, and the sensitivity of those judgments to different circumstances, Refresco has identified the significant accounting policies discussed below. While Refresco believes that all aspects of its financial statements should be studied and understood in assessing its current and expected financial condition and results of operations, it believes that the following significant accounting policies warrant particular attention. For more information, see note 2 to Refresco’s audited consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2017 included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF REFRESCO
Subsubsection Text: _The following discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations for the periods indicated set forth the historical consolidated financial and other data of Refresco, as well as certain other financial and operating data of Refresco. The historical consolidated financial and other data have been derived from the Refresco Financial Statements. Unless otherwise stated or the context otherwise requires, the term ‘‘Refresco’’ refers to the Refresco Group N.V. and its subsidiaries, excluding Cott TB. The following should be read in conjunction with the Refresco Financial Statements, including the notes thereto, ‘‘Presentation of Financial Information,’’ and information set forth under ‘‘Selected Consolidated Financial Information of Refresco’’ and Refresco’s Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The following discussion includes forward-looking statements based on assumptions about Refresco’s future performance. Refresco’s actual results could differ materially from those contained in these forward-looking statements as a result of many factors, including but not limited to those described under ‘‘Forward-Looking Statements,’’ ‘‘Risk Factors’’ and elsewhere in this offering memorandum. This offering memorandum does not include any historical financial and other data related to the Issuer as the Issuer was formed under the laws of the Netherlands on October 20, 2017 for the purpose of facilitating the Transactions. The Issuer’s only material assets and liabilities are currently its interest in the issued and outstanding shares of its direct subsidiary, Sunshine Investments B.V., and its outstanding indebtedness and intercompany balances incurred in connection with the Transactions. As a consequence, no audited financial information is available for the Issuer and no financial information of the Issuer other than as the information included in ‘‘Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information’’ has been provided in this offering memorandum. Following the Offering, Sunshine Top B.V. is expected to be the reporting entity for the Group. See ‘‘Summary—Summary Corporate and Financing Structure.’’_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsubsection Text: On January 30, 2018, Refresco acquired the Cott Traditional Business for a purchase price of $1,259.9 million pursuant to an acquisition agreement dated July 25, 2017 between Refresco Group N.V. and Cott Corporation. The integration of the two companies in North America commenced after closing and the integration of the businesses in the United Kingdom began shortly after the sale of the Nelson A-PET facility, which occurred at the end of the first quarter in 2018. The Cott TB Acquisition was completed to address expected retailer brands market growth in the U.S. driven by the expansion of discounters, the expanding footprint of online retailers and macro factors. Cott TB is well established in the retailer brands segment with more than 85% of its bottling activities being for world leading retailers. Cott TB also operates in the contract manufacturing segment. Cott TB has three reporting segments: Cott TB North America, Cott TB UK and Cott TB Mexico. Cott TB sold approximately 3,938 million liters in 2017. Cott TB’s carve-out revenue was $1,637.1 million and Cott TB’s Adjusted EBITDA was $136.1 million, in each case, for the financial year ended 2017. As of December 31, 2017, Cott TB had 4,386 full-time equivalent employees.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Cott TB’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Cott TB’s revenues are determined, in part, by volumes. Industry-wide CSD sales declined during the periods under review, which had an overall impact on volumes. Cott TB experienced distinct trends in its three segments. _Cott TB North America_ Cott TB North America’s retailer brands volumes declined but were replaced by contract manufacturing volumes during the periods under review. Overall, Cott TB North America’s volumes were largely stable between 2015 and 2017, experiencing a decline of 4.6%, or 143.3 million liters, from 3,137.7 million liters in 2015 to 2,994.4 million liters in 2017. The retailer brands business was responsible for the decline, with volumes reducing by approximately 219 million liters between 2015 and 2017. The decrease in retailer brands volumes was offset by Cott TB North America’s shift towards contract manufacturing, which grew from 385.0 million liters to 427.1 million liters between 2015 and 2017, supported by new customer acquisitions (such as Monster and Campbell). Cott TB’s acquisition of Pri-Pak, which was completed in April 2017 had a positive impact on Cott TB North America’s contract manufacturing volumes in the financial year ended 2017. _Cott TB UK_ The retailer brands market in the United Kingdom experienced a general decline similar to the market in North America largely due to decreases in the Sports & Energy and CSD segments, but Cott TB UK has 115 ----- not experienced a corresponding increase in contract manufacturing volumes. Cott TB UK’s volumes experienced a 16.3% decline between 2015 and 2017, decreasing by 171.7 million from 1,054.5 million liters to 882.8 million liters, in part, because of losses of certain contracts, resulting in a loss in market share which has primarily been captured by Refresco. _Cott TB Mexico_ Cott TB Mexico’s volume declined by 38% from 97.8 million liters in 2015 to 60.7 million liters in 2017. This decrease was primarily driven by its contract manufacturing segment which saw volume decline from 77.3 million liters in 2015 to 44.8 million liters in 2017.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Cott TB’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: In addition to water, the principal raw materials required to produce Cott TB’s products are aluminum cans and ends, resin for PET, high-density polyethylene (‘‘HDPE’’) and polycarbonate bottles, caps and preforms, labels, cartons and trays, sweeteners, such as HFCS and sugar, fruit concentrates and fruit. The cost of these raw materials can fluctuate substantially over time for a variety of reasons, including based on fluctuations in demand for products and the timing of fruit-growing seasons. During the periods under review, Cott TB managed such exposures to fluctuations in ingredient and packaging costs to a limited extent by entering into fixed price commitments for a portion of its ingredient and packaging requirements and otherwise managed its exposure to such fluctuations by passing through the costs to customers through price increases. Cott TB’s contract manufacturing channel generally does not bear the risk of increases in the costs of commodities because the ingredients and packaging are provided by the branded customers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Cott TB’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: _Transactional_ As a result of the geographic spread of operations, Cott TB generates a portion of its revenue, and incurs a portion of its expenses, in currencies other than the U.S. dollar, its functional currency, including the British pound, the Canadian dollar and the Mexican peso. During the periods under review, Cott TB maintained a foreign currency cash flow hedging program to reduce the risk that its procurement activities would be adversely affected by changes in foreign currency exchange rates. Cott TB entered into forward contracts to hedge certain portions of forecasted cash flows denominated in foreign currencies. These foreign currency contracts typically have maturities of less than twelve months. Further, changes to raw material costs driven by exchange rates can generally be passed on to the customers with a slight time delay, in the same way as fluctuations in raw materials prices, at the time a customer’s contract is renewed. _Translational_ Cott TB reports its consolidated financial statements in its functional currency, which is the U.S. dollar. As a result, the assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses of all of its operations with a currency other than the U.S. dollar are translated into U.S. dollar at then applicable exchange rates. Consequently, increases or decreases in the value of the U.S. dollar affect the value of these items with respect to the non-U.S. dollardenominated businesses in the consolidated financial statements, even if their value has not changed in their original currency. For example, a stronger U.S. dollar will reduce the reported results of operations of non-U.S. dollar businesses and conversely a weaker U.S. dollar will increase the reported results of operations of non-U.S. dollar businesses. These translation effects could significantly affect the comparability of Cott TB’s results between financial periods and/or result in significant changes to the carrying value of Cott TB’s assets, liabilities and shareholders’ equity. In the periods under review, Cott TB’s reported financial performance is impacted by currency translation effects, particularly due to the depreciation of the British pound relative to the U.S. dollar. These translation effects are recorded in the consolidated income statement and balance sheet as currency translation adjustment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Cott TB’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Cott TB competes principally in the non-alcoholic beverages category, which is highly competitive in each region in which it operates. Competition for incremental retail volume is intense. The brands owned by the four major national non-alcoholic beverage companies, Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Nestl´e Waters North America and Dr. Pepper Snapple, control a majority of the total CSD and alternative beverage category within the United States. These companies have significant financial resources and spend heavily on promotional programs. Certain larger U.S. retailers also self-manufacture products for their own needs and regularly 116 ----- approach other retailers seeking additional business. Cott TB also faces competition in the juice category from juice brands such as Welch’s, Ocean Spray and Mott’s. In addition, Cott TB faces intense price competition from regional beverage manufacturers that, in many cases, also supply retailer brand products. During the periods under review, Cott TB UK lost volumes to certain competitors, including Refresco.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Cott TB’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The beverage market is subject to seasonal variations. Beverage sales are typically higher during the warmer months and can also be influenced by the timing of holidays and unseasonable weather conditions. The seasonality of sales volumes combined with the seasonal nature of fruit growing causes working capital needs to fluctuate throughout the year. Inventory levels typically increase in the first half of the year in order to meet high summer demand. In addition, accounts receivable balances typically decline in the third quarter as customers pay their higher-than-average outstanding balances from summer deliveries.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Cott TB’s Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Cott TB’s results of operations have been, and may continue to be, affected by certain key factors including, in particular, mix and volumes, ingredient and packaging supplies, currency exchange effects, competition and seasonality. Each of these factors is discussed in more detail below. See also ‘‘—Significant _Accounting Principles’’ for a description of how the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements were_ prepared, including how costs from Cott Corporation were allocated to Cott TB.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsubsection Text: Cott TB is comprised of carve-out entities that Cott Corporation sold to Refresco Group N.V. Prior to the Cott TB Acquisition, Cott TB did not report its results as a separate company and was not consolidated under one entity. Cott TB instead is comprised of three segments of companies, which include Cott TB North America, Cott TB UK and Cott TB Mexico. All intercompany balances and transactions within Cott TB have been eliminated and transactions and balances between Cott TB and Cott Corporation and its subsidiaries are reflected as related party transactions in the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements. See ‘‘—Significant Accounting Policies’’ for a description of how the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements were prepared, including how income and expenses from Cott Corporation were allocated to Cott TB. Such transactions with Cott Corporation are no longer considered related party transactions following the closing of the Cott TB Acquisition. Going forward, results for Cott TB North America and Cott TB Mexico will be included in the Group’s consolidated financial statements in the North America segment and results for Cott TB UK will be included in the UK business unit in the European segment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsubsection Text: On April 21, 2017, Cott Beverages Inc. acquired 100% of the issued and outstanding shares of Pri-Pak Inc. for an adjusted purchase price of $14.8 million. The acquisition of the Pri-Pak contributed to Cott TB’s growth in the contract manufacturing segment in North America in 2017.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: Cott TB recognizes revenue, net of sales returns, when ownership passes to customers for products manufactured in Cott TB’s own plants and/or by third-parties on its behalf, and when prices to its customers are fixed or determinable and collection is reasonably assured, which may be upon shipment of goods or upon delivery to the customer, depending on contractual terms. Shipping and handling costs paid by the customer to Cott TB are included in revenue. Although Cott TB occasionally accepts returns of products from its customers, historically returns have not been material.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: Cott TB records costs associated with the manufacturing of its products in costs of sales. Shipping and handling costs incurred to store, prepare and move products between production facilities or from production facilities to branch locations or storage facilities are recorded in cost of sales. Costs incurred in shipment of products from Cott TB’s production facilities to customer locations are also reflected in cost of sales. Finished goods inventory costs include the cost of direct labor and materials and the applicable share of overhead expense chargeable to production. Depreciation is allocated between cost of sales and SG&A expenses (as defined herein). 117 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: Cott TB records all other expenses not charged to production as selling, general and administrative (‘‘SG&A’’) expenses. Advertising costs are expensed at the commencement of an advertising campaign and are recognized as a component of SG&A expenses. Advertising costs are not significant to Cott TB.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB

Subsubsection Text: Other (income) expenses, net includes foreign exchange losses or gains, loss on extinguishment of long-term debt, proceeds from a legal settlement, gains from insurance proceeds and other income or loss.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsubsection Text: Cott TB North America Cott TB North America’s revenue decreased by $3.8 million or 0.1% to $1,273.5 million in the financial year ended 2017 from $1,277.4 million in the financial year ended 2016. This decrease was primarily due to lower intercompany sales of water to DSS Group Inc. (a subsidiary of Cott Corporation) as well as the result of higher contract manufacturing volumes, for which a tolling fee is received, and lower retailer brands volumes. Cott TB UK Cott TB UK’s revenue decreased by $15.9 million or 4.3% to $347.8 million in the financial year ended 2017 from $363.7 million in the financial year ended 2016. This decrease was primarily due to the variances between the U.S. dollar and British pound exchange rates during the period. Cott TB Mexico Cott TB Mexico’s revenue decreased by $3.2 million or 16.8% to $15.8 million in the financial year ended 2017 from $19.0 million in the financial year ended 2016. This decrease was primarily due to the loss of a significant contract but partially offset by the gain of a different contract. _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales increased by $6.3 million, or 0.4%, to $1,442.0 million in the financial year ended 2017 from $1,435.7 million in the financial year ended 2016. This increase was primarily due to increases in Cott TB UK’s cost of sales due to costs associated with extra waste, labor and repair costs due to quality issues with certain production lines, the write-off of certain inventory related to a product recall, increased quality testing costs, higher transport costs between locations due to the recall and losses of certain margins to two larger retailers in the United Kingdom. _Selling, general and administrative expenses_ Selling, general and administrative expenses decreased by $2.8 million, or 1.6%, to $171.0 million in the financial year ended 2017 from $173.8 million in the financial year ended 2016. This decrease was mainly caused by a decrease in the amount of corporate costs allocated by Cott Corporation to Cott TB in 2017. _Other (income) expense, net_ Other (income) expense, net changed to an expense of $21.0 million in the financial year ended 2017 from income of $1.7 million in the financial year ended 2016. This change was primarily due to losses related to 119 ----- the early repayment of senior notes due 2020 of Refresco Beverages U.S. Inc. (formerly Cott Beverages Inc.) in the first quarter of 2017, but was partially offset by currency exchange gains. _Interest Expense, net_ Interest expense, net decreased by $31.7 million, or 39.0%, to $49.5 million in the financial year ended 2017 from $81.2 million in the financial year ended 2016. This decrease was primarily due to the repayment of senior notes due 2020 in the first quarter of 2017. _Related party income and expense_ Related party interest income increased by $12.9 million, or 28.0%, to $58.9 million in the financial year ended 2017 from $46.0 million in the financial year ended 2016. This increase was primarily due to the assumption of a 6% note receivable with S. & D. Coffee, Inc. (a subsidiary of Cott Corporation) for $200 million in April 2017 and issuance of a new 5.75% note to DSS Group Inc. (a subsidiary of Cott Corporation) for $109.5 million by Refresco Beverages U.S. Inc. (formerly Cott Beverages Inc.). Related party interest expense increased by $37.5 million, or 139.9%, to $64.3 million in the financial year ended 2017 from $26.8 million in the financial year ended 2016. This increase was primarily due to the entry into a new 5.75% $750 million note by Refresco Beverages U.S. Inc. (formerly Cott Beverages Inc.) with its parent company in the first quarter 2017 (the proceeds of which were used to repay its senior notes due 2020 and issue the 5.75% note). Other related party income increased by $3.0 million, or 14.4%, to $23.9 million in the financial year ended 2017 from $20.9 million in the financial year ended 2016. This increase was primarily due to a lower dividend paid to Cott TB by a subsidiary of Cott Corporation. _Income Tax Expense_ Income tax expense changed to an income tax benefit of 13.0 million in the financial year ended 2017 from an income tax expense of $5.9 million in the financial year ended 2016. This change was primarily due to losses in Canada that favorably impacted tax rates. See note 5 to the Cott TB 2017 Carve-out Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. _Net income (loss)_ As a result of the factors described above, net income decreased to a loss of $28.9 million in the financial year ended 2017 from income of $5.8 million in the financial year ended 2016. _Net income attributable to non-controlling interests_ Net income attributable to non-controlling interests increased to $8.5 million in the financial year ended 2017 from $6.4 million in the financial year ended 2016. This increase was primarily due to an increase in the amount of income received as owners of Northwest Retailer Brands LLC. _Net loss attributed to Cott TB_ As a result of the factors described above, Cott TB made a loss of $37.3 million in the financial year ended 2017 as compared to a loss of $0.5 million in the financial year ended 2016. 120 -----

Subsubsection Text: Cott TB North America Cott TB North America’s revenue decreased by $42.8 million or 3.2% to $1,277.4 million in the financial year ended 2016 from $1,320.2 million in the financial year ended 2015. This decrease was primarily due to mix effect due to an increase in contract manufacturing volumes, for which a tolling fee is received, and lower retailer brands volumes and price decreases but was partially offset by an increase in added retailer brands water volumes. 121 ----- Cott TB UK Cott TB UK’s revenue decreased by $91.6 million or 20.1% to $363.7 million in the financial year ended 2016 from $455.3 million in the financial year ended 2015. The decrease was primarily due to the loss of a significant customer in the financial year ended 2016. This decrease was also attributable to variances between the U.S. dollar and British pound exchange rates during the period. Cott TB Mexico Cott TB Mexico’s revenue decreased by $6.7 million or 26.1% to $19.0 million in the financial year ended 2016 from $25.7 million in the financial year ended 2015. This decrease was primarily due to lower volumes generally and an increase in contract manufacturing volumes with lower prices. _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales decreased by $120.7 million, or 7.8%, to $1,435.7 million in the financial year ended 2016 from $1,556.4 million in the financial year ended 2015. This decrease was primarily due to loss of volumes in the UK and currency exchange rate effects. _Selling, general and administrative expenses_ Selling, general and administrative expenses decreased by $10.7 million, or 5.8%, to $173.8 million in the financial year ended 2016 from $184.5 million in the financial year ended 2015. This decrease was primarily due to lower depreciation and currency exchange rate effects. _Other (income) expense, net_ Other (income) expense, net changed to income of $1.7 million in the financial year ended 2016 from an expense of $3.3 million in the financial year ended 2015. This change was primarily due to foreign exchange gains and gains on recoveries from insurance proceeds. _Interest Expense, net_ Interest expense, net increased by $0.3 million, or 0.4%, to $81.2 million in the financial year ended 2016 from $80.9 million in the financial year ended 2015. This slight increase was due to slight increases on the amount of interest on long-term debt and other interest expense. _Related party income and expense_ Related party interest income decreased by $5.3 million, or 10.3%, to $46.0 million in the financial year ended 2016 from $51.3 million in the financial year ended 2015. This decrease was primarily due to changes in Cott TB’s financing structure. Related party interest expense increased by $2.4 million, or 9.8%, to $26.8 million in the financial year ended 2016 from $24.4 million in the financial year ended 2015. This increase was primarily due to changes in Cott TB’s financing structure. Other related party income increase by $34.0 million, or 61.9%, to $20.9 million in the financial year ended 2016 from $54.9 million in the financial year ended 2015. This increase was primarily due to income from a dividend of approximately $31 million paid to Cott Beverages Limited in 2015 following an entity reorganization. _Income Tax Expense_ Income tax expense increased by $0.2 million, or 3.5%, to $5.9 million in the financial year ended 2016 from $5.7 million in the financial year ended 2015. This increase was primarily due to increased tax rates in Canada. See note 4 to the Cott TB 2015 and 2016 Carve-out Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. _Net income_ As a result of the factors described above, net income decreased by $43.5 million, or 88.2%, to $5.8 million in the financial year ended 2016 from $49.3 million in the financial year ended 2015. 122 ----- _Net income attributable to non-controlling interests_ Net income attributable to non-controlling interests increased by $0.3 million, or 4.9%, to $6.4 million in the financial year ended 2016 from $6.1 million in the financial year ended 2015. This increase was primarily due to an increase in the amount of income received as owners of Northwest Retailer Brands LLC. _Comprehensive loss attributed to Cott TB_ As a result of the factors described above, Cott TB made a loss of $55.9 million in the financial year ended 2016 as compared with a loss of $128.0 million in the financial year ended 2015.

In the financial year ended 2015, these one-off costs were mainly comprised of (a) losses related to disposals of obsolete equipment, (b) share-based compensation expense related to the directly attributable fair value of awards held by certain employees of the Cott TB during the period and (c) corporate costs relating to stewardship costs that were allocated to Cott TB in the carve-out income statement relating to overhead and management that will not be incurred going forward.

Subsubsection Text: _Net cash provided by operating activities_ In the financial year ended 2017, Cott TB’s net cash provided by operating activities amounted to $118.3 million consisting primarily of net loss of $28.9 million, depreciation and amortization of $82.8 million, amortization of deferred financing fees of $3.4 million, shared-based compensation expense of $11.6 million, benefit for deferred income taxes of $17.5 million, loss on extinguishment of debt of $30.1 million, accounts receivable of $13.6 million, related party receivables of $41.3 million, inventories of $9.4 million, accounts payable and accrued liabilities and other long-term liabilities of $57.3 million and related party payables of $55.8 million. In the financial year ended 2016, Cott TB’s net cash provided by operating activities amounted to $115.0 million consisting of net income of $5.8 million, depreciation and amortization of $87.7 million, amortization of deferred financing fees of $5.1 million, shared-based compensation expense of $6.5 million, benefit for deferred income taxes of $1.8 million, accounts receivable of $21.7 million, related party receivables of $19.0 million, inventories of $9.7 million, accounts payable and accrued liabilities and other long-term liabilities of $4.8 million and related party payables of $5.2 million. In the financial year ended 2015, Cott TB’s net cash provided by operating activities amounted to $202.3 million consisting of net income of $49.3 million, depreciation and amortization of $96.1 million, amortization of deferred financing fees of $4.7 million, shared-based compensation expense of $6.5 million, provision for deferred income taxes of $10.2 million, loss on disposal of property, plant & equipment of $2.7 million, accounts receivable of $5.8 million, related party receivables of $14.8 million, inventories of $5.4 million, accounts payable and accrued liabilities and other long-term liabilities of $15.6 million and related party payables of $27.4 million. _Net cash used in investing activities_ In the financial year ended 2017, Cott TB’s net cash used in investing activities amounted to $44.7 million consisting of additions to property, plant & equipment of $41.4 million and additions to intangible assets of 124 ----- $5.3 million, acquisitions of $14.4 million, which was partially offset by proceeds from property, plant & equipment sale-leaseback transactions of $16.4 million. In the financial year ended 2016, Cott TB’s net cash used in investing activities amounted to $42.8 million consisting of additions to property, plant & equipment of $44.7 million and additions to intangible assets of $3.3 million, which was partially offset by proceeds from property, plant & equipment sale-leaseback transactions of $3.6 million and proceeds from insurance recoveries of $1.5 million. In the financial year ended 2015, Cott TB’s net cash used in investing activities amounted to $32.4 million consisting of additions to property, plant & equipment of $41.7 million and additions to intangible assets of $1.6 million, which was partially offset by proceeds from sale of property, plant & equipment and sale-leaseback transactions of $10.9 million. _Net cash (used in)/from financing activities_ In the financial year ended 2017, Cott TB’s net cash used in financing activities was $49.8 million consisting of payments of long-term debt of $627.4 million, payments under its asset-based lending facility (‘‘ABL Facility’’) of $2,990.6 million, dividends paid to parent and related parties of $16.9 million, distributions to non-controlling interests of $7.7 million, payment of premium and third-party costs of $21.5 million and other financing activities of $0.2 million, which were partially offset by borrowings under the ABL Facility of $3,004.0 million and amounts from parent and related-party transactions of $611.0 million. In the financial year ended 2016, Cott TB’s net cash used in financing activities was $81.7 million consisting of payments of long-term debt of $3.1 million, payments under its asset-based lending facility (‘‘ABL Facility’’) of $2,318.9 million, financing fees of $3.5 million, dividends paid to parents and related parties of $375.2 million and distributions to non-controlling interests of $7.7 million, which were partially offset by borrowings under the ABL Facility of $2,401.7 million and amounts from parent and related-party transactions of $225.0 million. In the financial year ended 2015, Cott TB’s net cash used in financing activities was $156.4 million consisting of payments of long-term debt of $3.7 million, payments under the ABL Facility of $1,101.8 million, distributions to non-controlling interests of $8.5 million, dividends paid to parents and related parties of $99.9 million, financing fees of $0.5 million and payments of deferred consideration for acquisitions of $2.5 million and other financing activities of $1.2 million, which were partially offset by borrowings under the ABL Facility of $994.4 million and amounts from parent and related-party transactions of $67.4 million. _Net (decrease) increase in cash and cash equivalents_ In the financial year ended 2017, Cott TB’s net increase in cash and cash equivalents was $26.0 million as a result of the factors described above. In the financial year ended 2016, Cott TB’s net decrease in cash and cash equivalents was $(15.3) million as a result of the factors described above. In the financial year ended 2015, Cott TB’s net increase in cash and cash equivalents was $9.9 million as a result of the factors described above.
