Subsubsection Text: Cott TB’s working capital was impacted by the seasonality of sales volume combined with the seasonal nature of fruit growing, causing needs to fluctuate throughout the year. Inventory levels typically increase in the first half of the year in order to meet high summer demand. In addition, accounts receivable balances decline in the third quarter as customers pay their higher-than-average outstanding balances from summer deliveries.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsubsection Title: Principles of Combined Carve-Out Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: The Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements include the assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses of the operations included in the Cott Traditional Business and are presented on a combined carve-out basis to include the historical results of operations, financial position, and cash flows applicable to the Cott Traditional Business. The asset, liabilities, revenues and expenses included in the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements represent only those that were sold to Refresco as well as certain allocated expenses as deemed appropriate by management of Cott Corporation as disclosed in the accompanying notes to the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements. See also ‘‘Summary—Recent Developments—The Cott TB _Acquisition.’’ The Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements may not necessarily be indicative of the_ historical results that would have been obtained if the Cott Traditional Business had been a separate company during the periods presented or the results that may be obtained in the future. All intercompany balances and transactions within the Cott Traditional Business have been eliminated and transactions and balances between the Cott Traditional Business and Cott Corporation and its subsidiaries are reflected as related party transactions in the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements. Such transactions with Cott Corporation are no longer considered related party following the closing of the Cott TB Acquisition. See ‘‘Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information.’’ Cott Corporation’s net investment in Cott TB (invested equity) includes the net assets of this business, as well as the accumulated earnings (losses) of Cott TB and transactions with Cott Corporation. The Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements include the assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses that are specifically identifiable to those sold to Refresco, as well as certain allocations as described below: _General Corporate Expenses_ Total corporate costs included in the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements, including the amounts allocated, amounted to $56.6 million for the financial year ended 2017. General corporate expenses are 126 ----- included in ‘‘Selling, general and administrative expenses’’ on the combined carve-out statement of operations. The costs associated with these general corporate costs have been allocated to the Cott TB using the most meaningful allocation methodologies, which were based primarily on time surveys (direct costs) and actual revenue (indirect costs). The general corporate expense allocations which were not directly or indirectly attributable to the Cott TB are primarily for legal, treasury, insurance, finance, internal audit, strategy and public affairs, and amounted to $7.8 million for the financial year ended 2017. The costs allocated are not necessarily indicative of the costs that would have been incurred if Cott TB had performed the functions as a stand-alone entity, nor are they indicative of costs that will be incurred in the future or as a member of the Group. _Stock-based Compensation_ For the financial year ended 2017, share-based compensation expense in the Cott TB’s combined carve-out statement of operations included Cott Corporation’s expenses related to the directly attributable fair value of awards held by certain employees of Cott TB during the periods presented. Additionally, there was an allocation for certain employees of Cott Corporation’s corporate function, calculated based on time studies and actual revenues. These expenses are not necessarily indicative of what the expenses would have been had Cott TB been a separate stand-alone company during the financial year ended 2017. _Retirement Plans_ During the financial year ended 2017, certain employees of Cott TB participated in pension plans sponsored and administered by entities included in the Cott Traditional Business. An attribution of assets and obligations, and an allocation of the related pension expenses, was reflected in the combined carve-out financial statements on the basis of historical amounts included within these reporting units. In the case of legal plan separations in the United States, the Employment Retirement Security Act of 1974 (‘‘ERISA’’) includes explicit guidance on how the plan assets must be allocated, which may differ from the preliminary allocation used in the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements. The amounts recorded in the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements and the finalized ERISA allocation could be materially different. _Interest Expense (Income) and Amortization of Debt Issuance Costs—Net_ Third-party long-term debt specific to Cott TB has been reflected in Note 13 to the Cott TB 2017 Carve-out Financial Statements. The interest expense included in the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements includes interest expense related to the long-term debt included in the balance sheet. In addition, certain legal entities of Cott Corporation outside Cott TB incurred third-party debt and provided intercompany financing to Cott TB. This financing is recognized in Cott TB’s combined carve-out balance sheet as of December 30, 2017 as amounts due to Cott Corporation within Related party notes payable and is interest-bearing as described in note 19 to the Cott TB 2017 Carve-out Financial Statements. As a result of this arrangement, the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements include related party interest expense (and interest payable) at the exchange amount, which is the amount established and agreed to by the related parties. Interest expense included in the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements is not necessarily indicative of the interest charges that would have been incurred had Cott TB functioned as a stand-alone company. In addition, historically, certain legal entities included in the Cott Traditional Business have incurred thirdparty debt and provided intercompany financing to other business units of Cott Corporation outside the Cott Traditional Business. This financing is recognized in Cott TB’s combined carve-out balance sheet as of December 30, 2017 as amounts due from Cott Corporation within Related party notes receivable and is interest-bearing as described in note 19 to the Cott TB 2017 Carve-out Financial Statements. As a result of this arrangement, the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements include related party interest income (and interest receivable) at the exchange amount. Interest income included in the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements is not necessarily indicative of the interest charges that would have been incurred had Cott TB functioned as a stand-alone company. 127 ----- _Income Taxes_ Income taxes are calculated as if all of operations of Cott TB had been a series of separate taxpaying legal entities, filing separate tax returns in their local tax jurisdiction. Accordingly, the tax provision for the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements was prepared using the separate-return method, in which taxable income or loss is calculated as if the carve-out operations represented a taxable group that is separate from the existing parent. Deferred income taxes reflect the tax attributes and related deferred taxes associated with the legal entities that the combined carve-out financial statements comprise, as well as adjustments arising from any cost allocations recorded as part of the carve-out process. Certain income tax balance sheet items included in the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements are adjusted through Net Parent Investment and thus do not necessarily reflect Cott TB as a stand-alone company. _Intangible Assets_ Cott Corporation has directly attributed historical intangible assets to Cott TB based on the historical carrying amounts attributed to Cott TB. With respect to all intangible assets, this attribution of specifically identifiable intangible assets to Cott TB is not necessarily indicative of the fair value allocated to the intangible asset by Refresco upon the completion of the Cott TB Acquisition. _Goodwill_ Cott Corporation has directly attributed historical goodwill to Cott TB based on the historical goodwill amounts attributed to Cott TB. No goodwill allocation was required as the carved-out entities already held their own historical goodwill amounts when combined to form Cott TB. This goodwill attribution is not necessarily indicative of the fair value allocated to goodwill by Refresco upon the completion of the Cott TB Acquisition. _Earnings Per Share_ Cott TB is not a separate legal entity with common shares outstanding. Therefore, historical earnings per share have not been presented in the Cott TB Carve-out Financial Statements. 128 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsubsection Text: Significant accounting policies are those that: (i) are relevant to the presentation of Cott TB’s financial condition and results of operations; and (ii) require the management’s most difficult, subjective or complex judgments, often as a result of the need to make estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain. As the number of variables and assumptions affecting the possible future resolution of uncertainties increases, those judgments become even more subjective and complex. In order to provide an understanding of how Cott TB’s has prepared its carve-out financial statements, including the variables and assumptions underlying its estimates, and the sensitivity of those judgments to different circumstances, Cott TB has identified the significant accounting policies discussed below. While Cott TB believes that all aspects of its financial statements should be studied and understood in assessing its current and expected financial condition and results of operations, it believes that the following significant accounting policies warrant particular attention. For more information, see note 1 to Cott TB’s 2017 Carve-out Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF COTT TB
Subsubsection Text: _The following should be read in conjunction with the information set forth under ‘‘Selected Combined Carve-out Financial Information of Cott TB,’’ ‘‘Presentation of Financial Information,’’ and Cott TB’s Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. Cott TB’s financial year ended (i) January 2, 2016 is referred to herein as the financial year ended 2015, (ii) December 31, 2016 is referred to herein as the financial year ended 2016 and (iii) December 30, 2017 is referred to herein as the financial year ended 2017. The following discussion includes forward-looking statements based on assumptions about Cott TB’s future performance. Cott TB’s actual results could differ materially from those contained in these forward-looking statements as a result of many factors, including but not limited to those described under ‘‘Forward-Looking Statements,’’ ‘‘Risk Factors’’ and elsewhere in this offering memorandum._

As of December 31, 2017, our _pro forma cash and cash equivalents amounted to_ A131.0 million. Our principal sources of liquidity, following the Acquisition and the Cott TB Acquisition, are net cash generated from our operating activities, our cash and cash equivalents on hand and undrawn capacity under our Revolving Credit Facility. See ‘‘Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.’’ Our liquidity needs consist of funding operating expenses, changes in working capital, capital expenditures, debt service requirements and other liquidity requirements that may arise from time to time, including, without limitation, (i) refinancing of outstanding debt, (ii) acquisitions and other investment opportunities, (iii) capital expenditures relating to our production facilities and (iv) payments in the ordinary course of business.

On January 22, 2018, we entered into a multi-currency Senior Credit Facilities Agreement with, among others, J.P. Morgan Europe Limited as agent, the Security Agent, and BNP Paribas Fortis SA/NV, Credit Suisse International, J.P. Morgan Securities plc, Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, ABN AMRO Bank N.V., Co¨operatieve Rabobank U.A., trading as Rabobank London and Mizuho Bank, Ltd., as mandated lead arrangers. The Senior Credit Facilities Agreement provides for a Revolving Credit Facility in a principal amount of A200.0 million and the Term Loan B Facility in a principal amount of A1,958.5 million (equivalent). As of March 28, 2018, the Term Loan B Facility has been fully drawn to refinance Refresco’s syndicated term loan facility and fund a portion of the purchase price of the Refresco Shares and the Revolving Credit Facility has been drawn in an amount of A90.0 million to finance a portion of the purchase price of the Refresco Shares and to fund working capital needs as we are at a low cyclically low point in our working capital cycle. Interest and certain fees are payable as further described under ‘‘Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Senior Credit Facilities Agreement—Interest and Fees.’’_

We have a mortgage loan in an aggregate principal amount of £38.5 million from HSBC Bank Plc borrowed in connection with the construction of the production site in Bridgwater, UK. The real estate of the production site in Bridgwater, UK is pledged as collateral. A fixed quarterly payment of £0.7 million consists of interest of 3 months GBP Libor plus 0.75% plus costs with the remainder allocated to repayment of principal. The final repayment date of the mortgage is 2036, but with the current forward interest rate, the mortgage is expected to be repaid in 2026. The mortgage has been valued at fair value in the opening balance on November 11, 2014 and is valued at amortized costs afterwards.
Finance lease liabilities relate mainly to production lines in Benelux.

The following table summarizes information relating to our contractual maturities of non-derivative financial liabilities, including estimated interest payments and excluding the impact of netting agreements, if applicable, as at December 31, 2017, as adjusted to give pro forma effect to the Cott Acquisition and the Transactions. Insofar as these cash flows depend on future floating interest rates, which were unknown on 129 ----- the balance sheet date, the cash flows have been estimated on the basis of rates prevailing on the balance sheet date.

Subsection Title: Less than** **More than Total** **1 year** **1-5 years** **5 years (E million)

Subsubsection Text: (1) Represents the euro-equivalent aggregate amount outstanding under the Term Loan B Facility based on an EUR/USD exchange rate of A1.00/$1.20 and a EUR/GBP exchange rate of A1.00/£0.89 as of December 31, 2017. (2) Excluding obligations under operating leases. For a description of the material terms of our existing long-term financing arrangements, see ‘‘Description _of Certain Financing Arrangements’’ and ‘‘Description of the Notes.’’_ We lease office buildings, warehouses, machinery and equipment and cars. The lease arrangements do not contain any contingent rent or any restrictions related to our other financing activities. Our purchase and investment commitments as of December 31, 2017 amounted to A396.4 million of which purchase commitments of less than a year amounted to A396.4 million.

Banks have issued guarantees to suppliers and customers on our behalf. These contingent obligations have not and are not likely to have a material effect on our results of operations, financial condition or liquidity.

We expect that our capital expenditures will be driven largely by normal maintenance activities, which amount to approximately A1 million per facility per year, along with our continuing efforts to optimize production at our facilities through investment in new technologies and production capabilities. We expect our average number of employees to increase as we progress in our buy & build strategy, which will be partly offset by ongoing optimization of our manufacturing footprint. We will incur capital expenditures in connection with implementation and investment costs to achieve synergies from our acquisition of Cott TB. We spend on average 3-4% of revenue per year on capital expenditures. We anticipate capital expenditures will increase in 2018 and 2019 compared to the level of 2017 as a result of our acquisitions and the continued upgrading of our manufacturing capabilities. In addition, we expect to spend an additional A43.6 million in 2018 in connection with the new manufacturing site at Le Quesnoy, France. See ‘‘Summary—Recent Developments—Site in Le Quesnoy, _France.’’_

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Financial Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk represents the risk that counter parties fail to meet their contractual obligations, and arises principally in the receivables from customers, cash and cash equivalents, derivative financial instruments and deposits with banks and financial institutions. We do not have any significant concentration of credit risk. In order to reduce the exposure to credit risk, we carry out ongoing credit evaluations of the financial position of customers but generally does not require collateral. Use is made of a combination of independent ratings and risk controls to assess the credit quality of the customer, taking into account its financial position, past experience and other factors. Sales are subject to payment conditions which are common practice in each country. The banks and financial institutions used as counterparty for holding cash and cash equivalents and deposits and in derivative transactions can be classified as high credit quality financial institutions (institutions that receive a minimum of an A rating from Standard & Poor’s). We have policies that limit the amount of credit exposure to individual financial institutions. Our management believes that the likelihood of losses arising from credit risk is remote particularly in the light of the diversification of activities.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Financial Risk
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that we will not be able to meet its financial obligations as they fall due. Our approach to managing liquidity risk is to ensure, as far as possible, that it always has sufficient liquidity to meet its liabilities when due, under both normal and more extreme conditions, without incurring unacceptable losses or risking damage to our reputation. We have a clear focus on financing long term growth as well as current operations. Strong cost and cash management and controls over working capital and capital expenditure proposals are in place to ensure effective and efficient allocation of financial resources.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Financial Risk
Subsubsection Text: _Foreign Currency Risk_ We are exposed to currency risk mainly on purchases denominated in U.S. dollars. At any point in time we aim to hedge 80% to 100% of its foreign currency exposure on contracted forecasted purchases. Following the Cott TB Acquisition, we are in the process of covering our exposure from taking U.S. dollars out of our North American operations. We use currency option contracts and forward exchange contracts to hedge its currency risks, most of which have a maturity date of less than one year from the reporting date. When necessary, foreign currency contracts are rolled over on maturity. In respect of other monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies, we attempt to ensure that our net exposure is kept to an acceptable level by buying or selling foreign currencies at spot rates, as necessary, to address short term imbalances. In order to minimize the impact of accounting mismatches in the profit or loss account, we apply cash flow hedge accounting. The effectiveness of the hedge relationship is measured based on changes in intrinsic value of options and fair value of forward contracts. The changes in time value of the currency options are directly recorded in the income statement, as part of raw material costs. Per year-end the cash flow hedge accounting relationships were fully effective. There are no forecasted transactions for which hedge accounting has been applied, but which are no longer expected to occur. _Interest Rate Risk_ We are exposed to the effects of variable interest rates on interest-bearing long term liabilities, which is partly offset by cash held at variable rates. On fixed interest receivables and liabilities, we are exposed to market value fluctuations. For certain variable interest rate long term liabilities, Refresco has entered into 131 ----- interest rate swap agreements through which Refresco effectively pays fixed interest rates on these liabilities. We apply cash flow hedge accounting to offset the profit or loss impact resulting of timing differences between variable interest rate liabilities and the interest rate swap. Throughout 2015, 2016 and 2017 as well as at year-end the cash flow hedge accounting relationships in respect of Refresco were effective. _Price Risk_ We are exposed to commodity price risks. To manage these risks procurement operates within the framework of centrally specified policies and guidelines and must act in conformance with the required internal control measures. Our contract positions are based on a thorough understanding of the raw material markets and in principle contracted sales are covered back-to-back. We centralize the procurement of raw materials, packaging materials and indirect spend for Europe and North America. Authority levels of local management have been shifted towards our central procurement organization which is executing and monitoring the main contracts and important purchase decisions. Commodities are only purchased locally after approval of the central purchasing department. Contracts exceeding predefined limits must be authorized by the Executive Board. Existing contract positions are closely monitored and, when necessary, corrective actions are evaluated and implemented. To enable us to stay in line with developments in the raw materials markets and maintain its gross margins, it implements pass-on clauses into sales contracts with customers. In parallel, the quality of management information has been enhanced by the development of a network enabling knowledge of markets, suppliers and conditions of raw materials to be shared at the operating group level. We hedge the raw material aluminum through derivatives. _Pension Risk_ Refresco contributes to a number of defined benefit plans that provide pension benefits to employees upon retirement in the Netherlands, Germany, Italy, Belgium and the UK. The amount of the benefits depends on age, salary and years of service. Furthermore, Refresco has an indemnity plan in France and obligations for jubilee plans in the Netherlands, Germany and France. The financial figures are affected by the market interest rates and fair value of listed bonds and equity shares included in plan assets. Cott TB also maintains three defined benefit (‘‘DB’’) plans acquired as a part of prior acquisitions. One DB plan covers certain employees at one plant in the United States under a collective bargaining agreement and is referred to as the U.S. Plan. Two of these DB plans cover certain employees of Cott TB in the UK and are referred to collectively as the UK Plans. Retirement benefits for employees covered by the U.S. Plans and UK Plans are based on years of service multiplied by a monthly benefit factor. Pension costs are funded in accordance with the provisions of the applicable law. All DB plans are closed to new participants and are frozen. Please refer to note 5.10 of the Refresco Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2017 and note 13 of the Cott TB 2017 Carve-out Financial Statements. 132 -----

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Financial Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our activities expose it to a variety of financial risks: credit risk, liquidity risk and market risk (including foreign currency risk, fair value interest rate risk, cash flow interest rate risk and price risk). Our overall risk management program focuses on the unpredictability of financial markets and seeks to minimize potential adverse effects on our financial performance. We use derivative financial instruments to hedge certain risk exposures. The Executive Board has the responsibility for the establishment and oversight of our risk management framework. Our risk management policies are established to identify and analyze the risks faced by us, to set appropriate risk limits and controls, and to monitor risks and adherence to limits. Risk management policies and systems are reviewed regularly to reflect changes in market conditions and in our activities. 130 ----- Through its training program and its management standards and procedures, we aim to develop a disciplined and constructive control environment in which all employees understand their roles and responsibilities. The Supervisory Board oversees management’s monitoring of compliance with our risk management policies and procedures and it reviews the adequacy of the risk management framework in relation to the risks faced by us.

_Unless otherwise stated or the context otherwise requires, in this section the terms ‘‘we,’’ ‘‘us,’’ and ‘‘our’’ refer to the Issuer and its subsidiaries after giving effect to the Transactions and the Cott TB Acquisition. See ‘‘The Transactions’’ and ‘‘Summary—Recent Developments—The Cott TB Acquisition.’’_

Subsection Title: The Off-Trade European Soft Drinks Market and North American Soft Drinks Market
Subsubsection Text: We are active in Belgium, France, Finland, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Spain and the UK (the ‘‘European Soft Drinks Market’’) and the United States and Canada, but excluding Mexico because of its relative size in relation to our operations in North America (the ‘‘North American Soft Drinks Market’’). Soft drinks are sold to end-consumers through two main channels: on-trade and off-trade. On-trade consists of sales through restaurants, bars, cafes, hotels and catering businesses. The on-trade channel sells primarily branded products. Off-trade consists of sales through retail outlets such as supermarkets, discounters, small grocers and other retail formats. Our products are primarily sold through off-trade channels. Although some of the products we produce for contract manufacturing customers may be sold through on-trade channels, given the significantly larger size of the off-trade market compared to the on-trade market and our strong focus on customers in the off-trade channel, only off-trade data will be referenced in this section. In 2016, the total European Soft Drinks Market and the North American Soft Drinks Market volume was approximately 225 billion liters in off-trade (branded products and retailer brands) sales and that market volume is expected to grow to approximately 237 billion liters by 2021, representing a CAGR of 1.1% which is an increase of 0.6% from 2011 to 2016 according to GlobalData, 2017.

Subsection Title: The Off-Trade European Soft Drinks Market and North American Soft Drinks Market
Subsubsection Text: The soft drinks market can be divided into five main product categories. _CSDs_ Carbonated soft drinks (‘‘CSDs’’), are soft drinks into which carbon dioxide gas has been dissolved. CSDs exclude carbonated bottled water, still drinks and RTD tea. _Fruit and Vegetable Juice_ Fruit and vegetable juice comprises juice not from concentrate (‘‘NFC’’) and juice reconstituted from frozen concentrate, and nectars. Nectars are produced using a base of concentrated juice or a pasteurized pur´ee of fruit pulp, to which sugar and water can be added, and contain 10% to 99% juice. _Bottled Water_ Bottled water comprises still and sparkling water, including flavored and functional water. Flavored water typically contains a very limited quantity (amount to approximately one gram per liter) of fruit juice or essence. Functional water is water which has been fortified or enhanced with nutrients, vitamins, oxygen or herbs. _Sports and Energy Drinks_ Sports drinks (including isotonic, hypotonic and hypertonic sports drinks) usually depend on the provision of fluids, carbohydrates or both. Energy drinks are designed to boost energy levels and usually contain high levels of caffeine and taurine. 133 ----- _Dilutables_ Dilutables comprise concentrates, syrups and squashes. They must be diluted with water before consumption. The largest category is bottled water, which accounted for approximately 50% of the total retail sales volume in the European Soft Drinks Market in 2016, followed by CSDs and fruit and vegetable juice, with 27% and 5%, respectively. Dairy is generally not considered a category of the soft drinks market according to GlobalData, 2017. In the North American Soft Drinks Market, a slightly different distribution is visible in 2016, with CSDs accounting for approximately 37%, followed by bottled water and juice with 33% and 6%, respectively.

Subsection Title: The Off-Trade European Soft Drinks Market and North American Soft Drinks Market
Subsubsection Text: _Health and Nutrition Awareness_ Consumers are increasingly reducing the intake of sugar-sweetened beverages, which has created a shift in demand towards healthier alternatives. This recent trend is a consequence of a growing concern around lifestyle-related diseases, such as obesity, diabetes, cholesterol as well as a growing number of programs in place to raise consumers’ awareness. Spurred by recommendations from the World Health Organization (WHO), the EU member states have agreed by 2020 to reduce the volume of so-called added sugar in the overall marketed volume of food by 10% as compared to 2015, which would imply higher sugar taxes. In the U.S., sugar taxes have been introduced in several cities, which has required certain consumer packaged goods companies (‘‘CPGs’’) like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo to shift portfolio to lower sugar content (e.g. Light, Zero). At the same time, the threat of import tariffs has grown since the beginning of the Trump presidency. Higher import taxes could potentially lead to lower imports of soft drink products. Any changes in regulations or imposed taxes could soften consumer demand for products or lead companies to raise prices. In Europe, taxes on sugar-sweetened beverages (‘‘SSBs’’) are likely to decrease volume growth. Thirteen European countries have already introduced SSBs taxes and more are considering them. Approximately 25% to 30% of a person’s daily sugar intake comes from soft drinks and juices. As such, governments have concluded that SSBs are an ideal place to target with taxes. The UK, Ireland, and Portugal announced they would introduce taxes on SSBs between 2017 and 2018, following the path set by Mexico, France, Finland, Hungary, and several cities in California. As a consequence to the overall increase in health awareness, consumers are moving towards healthier options such as waters, teas and alternative still beverages while reducing their consumption of SSBs. We also believe that consumers perceive that ‘‘what is natural is healthy,’’ which causes artificial ingredients to come under attack, thus forcing the continuous label changes (clean labels). A company’s ability to quickly respond to market trends allows it to innovate their recipes formulas and continue to meet consumer needs. For example, manufacturers have responded to the health conscientiousness trend by using sucralose instead of sugar or CSDs that are preservative free and with no added sugar. Companies are also increasing their innovation capabilities and making their facilities as flexible as possible in order to adapt their products to customer needs in a quick time to market. High-growth pockets remain within the soft drinks category, with sports/energy drinks, RTD tea and bottled water projected to have faster growth than the broader market. _Time Compression_ Increasing time constraints are having an important impact on consumer behavior and segment shift. This is due to changes in consumer lifestyles leading to a reduction of time spent at home. Another factor is the increase in proportion of households where both spouses are employed, thus reducing meal preparation time. The increasing household fragmentations are also impacting the market demand. As a consequence, there is an increasing demand for convenient and portable products. Consumers want to have access to on the go packaging with single-serve portions. Furthermore, consumers are also seeking to reduce the preparation time required for a meal and focusing on buying their groceries online and at discounters. Frequent and smaller top up shopping trips are also becoming more prevalent. 134 ----- _Budget Constraints_ There is a polarization among consumers within the sector as some of them trade down to less expensive product categories while some of them trade up to exclusive products with perceived benefits. Some consumers switched over to lower product categories to save money, including reducing soft drink consumption due to budget constraints. Consumer confidence, however, has been improving with the rise of real incomes. Premiumization is also a growing trend as some consumers are more selective, choosing exclusive products with perceived benefits, such as health or energy drinks. Deluxe waters and tonics are increasingly available on the high-street and there is an increasing willingness to pay higher prices for better quality or functionality. For example, there is a niche but growing interest in ‘‘craft’’ sodas, reflecting a transition into mainstream. Finally, the demand for functional beverages is driving specialty and premium drinks as the functional drinks segment is forecast to grow over the next five years. _Sustainability_ Environmental concerns are a major factor impacting consumer behavior as a growing number of consumers are becoming aware of the environmental challenges faced by the global community. Consumer awareness of issues such as food and packaging waste and global warming is spreading and has been impacting consumer purchasing behavior. Customers are increasingly aware of avoiding food and packaging waste when making shopping decisions. In comparison, increasingly stringent rules for businesses are forcing companies to take into account the overall environmental impact of their activity and adapt their sourcing and packaging items for example. This means that soft drinks producers need to be innovative and efficient in their approach to bottling the products in order to comply with the highest environmental standards.

Soft drinks can be categorized as either retailer brands or branded products. Retailer brands products are products which are sold by a retailer under its own brand name, such as ‘‘Aldi’s River Cola’’ sold by Aldi. Branded products are products sold under a brand name not related to the distribution channel, such as ‘‘Coca-Cola.’’ Unlike retailer brands products, branded products are typically promoted through advertising and promotional campaigns to raise brand awareness and loyalty. Branded products are, on average, positioned at a higher price point than retailer brands products and capture a larger share of the off-trade market volume, accounting for 79%, or 178 billion liters, of off-trade retail sales in the Addressable Soft Drinks Market in 2016 according to GlobalData, 2017. The soft drinks market structure comprises suppliers, manufacturers and customers.

Suppliers provide the raw materials and packaging materials required to produce soft drinks products. The principal raw materials include water, fruit juices, fruit concentrates, aromas, sugar and sweeteners. The principal packaging materials include PET bottles, PET caps and pre-forms, aluminum and steel cans and tops, labels, cartons, glass, films, trays and pallets. The supplier base for various raw materials and packaging materials (such as FCOJ and carton packaging) is relatively consolidated. 135 -----

Manufacturers of branded products produce soft drinks under their own brands and/or outsource production to third-party bottlers. Manufacturers of retailer brands products produce soft drinks for retailers but can also produce branded products under contract manufacturing agreements with A-brand owners.

Supermarkets represent the largest retail format for the off-trade soft drinks market, followed by discounters and small grocery retailers. Large pan-European supermarkets tend to look for larger retailer brands manufacturers that can supply a variety of products in a number of European countries and scale their production depending on demand. This has been driven by industry consolidation and geographic expansion among supermarkets that are increasingly requiring their suppliers to have similar geographic span and production capabilities. Regional supermarkets tend to look for independent retailer brands manufacturers with local production capacity and ability to meet their product requirements. While brand owners manufacture the majority of branded products themselves, some brand owners outsource the production of their branded products to contract manufacturers. There are various reasons for this, such as outsourcing by larger groups of low volume brands that are too small to produce in-house, outsourcing by small brand owners that lack scale to produce in-house, and outsourcing of peak or contingency volumes. See ‘‘—Contract Manufacturing.’’

With an annual consumption of 102 billion liters, the European Soft Drinks Market is the second largest market globally following the North American Soft Drinks Market, which as has an annual consumption of approximately 123 billion liters. Growth is expected to increase at a rate of 0.7% per year in Europe between 2016 and 2021 as compared to 1.4% per year in North America in terms of volumes. In comparison, between 2011 and 2016, these rates were 0.2% and 1.0%, respectively, according to GlobalData, 2017. In Europe, bottled water continues to be the main sub-sector, representing 50% of the European Soft Drinks Market in 2016 followed by CSDs which make up 27% of the total annual consumption. In line with the health awareness trend, the bottled water sub-segment reflects that consumers have a growing interest in healthier alternatives due to its strong historical growth (CAGR 2011-2016A of 1.8%) and projections that it will achieve a 1.9% CAGR between 2016 and 2021, as compared to 0.7% for the whole European Soft Drinks Market. Energy drinks continue to drive total performance (CAGR 2011-2016A of 7.3%) with growth expected to continue (CAGR 2016-2021E of 4.1%). Comparatively, CSD and juice sub-categories are the categories with the lowest growth (CAGR 2011-2016A of �1.4% and �3.1% respectively) and are expected to continue this trend in the upcoming years (CAGR 2016-2021E of �1.1% and �0.8%) respectively) according to GlobalData, 2017. In Europe, soft drinks market growth is expected to accelerate. Refresco’s key markets are Germany, France, UK and Benelux, which respectively represented 28%, 15%, 13% and 6% of total annual consumption in Europe in 2016. Within those markets, France and Benelux exhibit the highest historical growth rates (CAGR 2011-2016A of 0.9% and 1.0%, respectively) and are expected to continue growing (CAGR 2016-2021E of 2.2% and 0.5%, respectively). Comparatively, Germany is a larger and more mature market with a stable but slightly declining, historical and forecasted growth on the same observed period (CAGR 2011-2016A and CAGR 2016-2021E of �0.1% and �0.4%, respectively) according to GlobalData, 2017.

With annual consumption of approximately 123 billion liters, the North American soft drinks market (comprising the United States and Canada) is the largest single market globally, of which we estimate approximately a quarter is outsourced by retailers and brands to third-party bottlers. Approximately 17 billion liters are produced for the retailer brands market and we estimate a similar amount is produced in the contract manufacturing market. 136 ----- |Col1|Col2| |---|---| |2|| |Col1|Col2| |---|---| |22|| 20APR201820401729 The North American Soft Drinks Market is expected to increase by 1.4% per year from 2016 to 2021 as compared to 1.0% per year between 2011 to 2016 in terms of volumes. Outsourced bottling (excluding water) has grown steadily and is expected to continue on the same growth trajectory, with contract manufacturing being the key growth driver in the short-term. Energy drinks, RTD coffee & teas and sports drinks are the winning categories, with growth mainly being spurred by innovation and consumer health awareness. Juices may benefit from a repositioning as a cold-pressed, fresh product, while nectars are also adding volume. Of the North American Soft Drinks Market, the U.S. market is highly fragmented with Cott TB as the established scalable player and over 250 small players generally focused on one region or category. Discounters are also aggressively expanding in the U.S. Aldi is investing in expanding its store network and Lidl opened its first stores in 2017, with 100 planned over the course of its first full year of presence in the U.S.

Raw materials suppliers: Brand Owners Supermarkets Orange Retailer Brands Discounters Apple Manufacturers Other Retailers Carbohydrates Other Packaging Suppliers: Contract Brand Owners PET Manufacturers LPB Cans Other

The retailer brands market benefits from structurally favorable dynamics. It is a resilient category that attracts consumers during a downturn but is also able to generate loyalty due to product quality. Fundamental growth is present because customers perceive retailer brands as high quality viable alternatives with better value for money. Consumer demand drives the retailer brands assortment and the expansion of advertising has a positive impact on growth. In addition, A-brand promotions are forecasted to reduce in intensity. Another positive dynamic is the increasing number of discounters with the launch of new store formats and innovation in drinks or packaging types. Discounters are still gaining share from traditional retailers in a number of geographies. Lastly, overall diversification and increased presence of retailer brands in higher growth categories offsets the short-term decline of segments such as juice with historically high share of retailer brands. While Aldi has been present for some time, discount stores are still under-represented in the U.S., creating an opportunity for Lidl and for existing operators, including Aldi, to expand. Going forward, the growing presence of discounters is expected to have a positive effect on retailer brands penetration. Aldi is currently investing in expanding its store network and Lidl opened its first stores in 2017 and aims to open 100 stores over the course of its first full year of presence in the U.S. Additionally, Aldi’s growth and Lidl’s market entrance is encouraging other retailers to embrace retailer brands as part of their strategy.

Retailer brands contribute approximately 30 billion liters of volume in the European Soft Drinks Market and grow at a premium to the overall soft drinks market and branded players. Retailer brands penetration (excluding Poland and Finland) is approximately 20-40% and is more developed than the U.S. and the other regions, with juices, dilutables, RTD coffee and RTD iced tea showing the highest levels of penetration. CSD, sport drinks and water are the categories that show the lowest penetration in the European Soft Drinks Market. However, retailer brands penetration is well below other Food & Beverage categories, suggesting meaningful upside and further growth with retailers continuing expansion plans or market entry. Customers perceive retailer brands as a high quality viable alternative. The demand drives assortment and advertising expansion, impacting the future growth and penetration. Retailer brands penetration in the European Soft Drinks Market stabilized from 2011 to 2016, reaching 29% in 2016. Some 137 ----- regions like Germany and Benelux (excluding Luxembourg) have higher levels than the rest of the region with 41% and 40% respectively.

Subsection Title: Retailer brands soft drinks market growth per country (2011-16A)[(1)]
Subsubsection Text: _Volume (mm lt)_

Subsubsection Title: North American Retailer Brands Market Evolution
Subsubsection Text: Retailer brands in the North American Soft Drinks Market contribute approximately 17 billion liters of the outsourced bottling market. Retailer brands penetration of 14% shows potential for growth in the long run, especially in juice and still drinks. Such change would be driven by innovation resulting in a change in the retailer brands offerings. The North American retailer brands penetration growth shows mixed performance across segments, with lower growth in sports drinks due to strong brands, and decreased volumes in juices due to lack of innovation.

As the key trends in the retailer brands business differ for each of our key countries/regions, those key trends are discussed separately below. _Benelux_ - Discounters are expected to continue to grow their market share with the launch of new store formats and innovation in soft drinks categories and packaging types. However, the growth rate is expected to be lower than in the last few years. 138 ----- - Supermarkets are expanding and re-launching their retailer brands product lines. Supermarkets in the Netherlands look to the Albert Heijn group’s retailer brands penetration as a benchmark and aim to grow their respective market shares accordingly. In addition, retailers have launched re-vamped lines, such as Albert Heijn’s ‘Basics’ range, Superunie’s OKA range and Colruyt’s Bon Selection line. - Brand promotions are expected to reduce in intensity. _Germany_ - Discounters are expected to grow their market share with the launch of new store formats. - We expect that product categories with high retailer brands penetration, such as juice, will continue to decline. However, the rate of decline is expected to be lower than in the past few years. Bottled water, which has a low retailer brands penetration, is expected to grow. - Supermarkets are expected to continue to strive to increase sales of their retailer brands products by increasing their retailer brands assortment and increasing advertising for retailer brands products. _France_ - It is expected that there will be a further increase of large supermarkets at the expense of discounters. This will have a negative impact on the retailer brands market as discounters have higher retailer brands penetrations. - Discounters increased their market share until 2010, but have since suffered from an end-consumer trend towards higher-quality products. In addition, retailers have responded to end-consumer preferences and successfully parried the discounters’ business model. One strategy has been to lower the prices of high quality branded products. - Like-for-like retailer brands penetration is expected to continue to be negatively affected, mainly driven by a decrease of retailer brands penetration at discounters. However, this is partly offset by large retailers which are expected to have a slight increase in retailer brands penetration due to the launch of new premium retailer brands products and the decline of brand promotions. _Iberia_ - The retailer mix is expected to shift away from supermarkets towards discounters, (including full service retail chains with high retailer brands shares such as Mercadona), convenience stores and smaller retailers. - After 2008, retailer brands’ market share grew as a result of the economic recession. This was because retailer brands provided an attractive option for end-consumers with tight household budgets and this trend has not reversed during the economic recovery. In addition, retailers and discounters are expected to continue to address end-consumer preferences by expanding retailer brands product ranges and improving the quality of their retailer brands products. _Italy_ - Discounters are expected to continue to grow their market share to the detriment of traditional retailers and convenience stores. However, the growth rate is expected to be slightly lower than in the last few years. - The bottled water category (which has a low retailer brands penetration compared to other soft drinks categories) is growing at a faster pace than other soft drinks categories. After 2008, retailer brands market share grew due to as a result of the economic recession because retailer brands provided a cheaper option for end-consumers with tight household budgets. End-consumers now perceive retailer brands as a high quality viable option, thus raising expected future growth. In addition, supermarkets and discounters are expected to continue to address end-consumer preferences by expanding retailer brands product ranges and improving the quality of the existing retailer brands products. _UK_ - Discounters are expected to continue to gain market share and supermarkets are expected to lose market share. 139 ----- - After declining since 2011, the highly penetrated category of juice has begun to stabilize, and the negative volume effect on retailer brands product lines is expected to slow. - Like-for-like retailer brands penetration is expected to slow its historic decline. The decline reflects the stagnation of retailer brands product offerings. However, with all players engaged in a price war, retailer brands products offer a chance for increased margins and differentiation and are expected to regain priority status. _Poland_ - Retailer brand market declined (�3.0%) CAGR in 2011-16A, despite overall soft drinks market growing at 2.3% CAGR during that period. - Decline led by fall in CSD, Packaged Water and Dilutables consumption (�10.5%, �3.5% and �10.3% CAGRs, respectively), somewhat offset by growth in Juice (17.4% CAGR). _Finland_ - Retailer brand market flat (�0.0%) CAGR in 2011-16A, despite overall soft drinks market declining at �1.8% CAGR during that period. - Fall in Juice consumption (�11.0% CAGR), offset by growth in Energy Drinks and Packaged Water (32.2% and 8.8% CAGRs, respectively). _North America_ - Penetration of retailer brands is expected to grow, driven by expansion of Aldi and Lidl in the U.S., the ongoing consolidation of the food retail landscape, and the large retailers improving their retailer brand offering, in response to renewed pressure from discounters. - Water, the most penetrated category for retailer brands, is expected to continue to lead retailer brand growth, due to the overall shift in consumption and relatively limited pressure from branded players, both of which negatively affect categories such as CSDs and juice. 140 -----

60% North America Europe 50% 40% 30% 20% 10% 0% CSD Water Juices Sport Drinks Energy Drinks RTD Tea Dilutables 20APR201820401288 Discounters also plan to aggressively expand or enter the U.S. For example, Aldi and Lidl are investing in new stores which are expected to contribute to the growth of the retailer brands market. The market is, however, expected continue to have flat growth due to consumer health trends. Indeed, consumers are shifting from CSD and juice to water. Overall the retailer brand market in the North American Soft Drinks Market has been growing at a slower pace from 2014 to 2016 (4.0% CAGR) than from 2011 to 2014 (5.4% CAGR).

The contract manufacturing market is split between various groups of branded players and is increasingly commonplace among the three main categories or product types of A-brand owners: large groups players, large new entrants and local players. Ongoing structural market trends are also leading to an increase in the contract manufacturing market: - limited branded growth, product fragmentation and pressure on branded margins and increased focus on returns. The flat branded market in Europe is partly explained by the market share gain of retailer brands putting pressure on efficiency gains and focusing on growth in faster-growing niche categories; - consumers are looking for more differentiated offerings resulting in more product and packaging innovations; and - pressure on branded margins and increased focus on returns on branded margins and overall profitability of A-brand owners led to increased attention to more value creating activities, such as marketing. Increased investor scrutiny on capital allocation also continues to drive brand owners’ focus on returns. 141 ----- The outsourcing decision is mainly triggered by an asset-light strategy, brand-focus, operational efficiency and risk volatility and management: - **Asset-light strategy: Established A-Brands and newer market entrants both in the United States and in Europe are increasingly implementing an asset-light strategy whereby they outsource a majority of their production and distribution while focusing on more profitable businesses and branding. These trends are leading to the outsourcing of additional volumes. - Established A-brands are increasingly focused on an ‘‘asset-light’’ strategy given the lower returns on manufacturing investment than in core marketing activities. Larger brands and products may still be effectively produced in-house through lean manufacturing. Increasingly, A-brands are pursuing even more asset-light strategies. For instance, Coca-Cola sold its manufacturing and distribution assets in the United States to focus on its more profitable concentrate-making business. Other established A-brands have announced similar strategies. The majority of volumes from A-brands are represented by the lower volume brands and products in their portfolio (e.g. Innocent, Tropicana), which are too small to be produced in-house. - Newer market entrants, on the other hand, are not spending on building out manufacturing or production facilities. Instead, they focus on investing in sales and marketing to create popular brands and outsource the production and distribution functions. - The proliferation of multiple brands and growth in packaging varieties, such as 250ml cans, has encouraged large bottlers to outsource to bottlers with greater production flexibility instead of investing in in-house production. - **Operational efficiency and operating expenditure: Specialist manufacturing businesses have greater opportunities and capabilities to utilize lines. Thus, branded players are increasingly looking for manufacturing players able to serve them throughout the footprint. These are typically large new entrants and local brand owners with low volume brands and products. There are also brands which lack the scale to produce in-house, with Monster, Ferrero and Arizona being prominent examples. - **Risk volatility and management: A-brands experience uncertainty and variability of volumes experienced by A-brands, requiring flexibility and the necessity of back-up capacity for either peak demand or breakdowns. When a contract is gained with larger brands or products, such as Coca Cola or PepsiCo, additional contracts usually follow. For example, the Innocent contracts came through as a result of a proven relationship with Coca-Cola and Naked contracts came through as a result of a proven relationship with PepsiCo. This was also the case for Tropicana and 7-up, which were products of the PepsiCo relationship.

The ongoing structural dynamics of the contract manufacturing market underpin some important strategic relevance. Consumers are looking for more differentiated offerings resulting in more product and packaging innovations. Moreover, branded margins and overall profitability of A-brands are under pressure leading to increased attention to relatively more value creating activities. These structural dynamics are expected to translate into significant growth in the next years for third party bottling.

Subsubsection Title: North American Contract Manufacturing Market Evolution
Subsubsection Text: Contract manufacturing volumes are growing due to some A-brand players in-sourcing less than expected, the increasing complexity of beverage offerings and small brands having been the growth winners. This trend is expected to continue going forward. The key drivers for contract manufacturing growth are described above. Water, energy drinks, RTD coffee & teas and sports drinks are the winning categories, with growth mainly driven by innovation and consumer health awareness. Juices may benefit from a repositioning as a cold-pressed fresh product, while nectars also continue to add volume. Going forward, contract manufacturing is expected to grow at a rate slightly above the beverage market growth, as companies are optimizing their platform and following an asset-light strategy by divesting more of their plants. This represents an important opportunity for global players to win this additional business. 142 -----

Manufacturers of branded soft drinks have increasingly outsourced the production of some of their products. The reasons for outsourcing vary from providing for contingency volumes to enabling brand owners to focus resources on product development and advertising. This trend continues to accelerate. The branded product range is growing increasingly fragmented, as end-consumers look for more differentiated offerings, resulting in more product and packaging innovations and a growing share of lower volume brands and product lines. As a result of increasing cost pressures (such as increasing costs in raw materials, packaging materials and energy), the manufacturers of branded soft drinks must manage their cost base proactively. In addition, demand for branded soft drinks is flat, partly due to the share gain of retailer brands products, thus putting additional pressure on efficiency gains. As a result, manufacturers of branded soft drinks are expected to increasingly outsource part of their production to third-party bottlers in order to ensure manufacturing efficiency and enable capital allocation towards marketing and sales activities. When outsourcing, brand owners typically look for manufacturers with high quality standards, sufficient scale and geographic scope. Manufacturers must be able to provide both production flexibility and reliability and also meet their requirements in a multitude of markets. It is expected that the volume of contract manufacturing as part of European soft drinks off-trade volumes (excluding water) will continue to increase. This increase is expected to be mainly driven by outsourcing of lower volume brands that are part of large groups.

We compete directly with other manufacturers of retailer brands products and contract manufacturing for branded products. We also face competition from small regional manufacturers and compete indirectly with soft drinks brand owners. We are differentiated from our competitors through our pan-European footprint. In our key European markets, we have a sizeable leading market share according to management estimates. We also have a national presence in the United States. Furthermore, we are licensed by the majority of A-brands to produce their products, which gives us a key strategic advantage as compared to other contract manufacturers. 143 -----

20APR201807182811 In 2017, we sold approximately 11,042 million liters of soft drinks. On a standalone basis, Refresco sold 7,104 million liters of soft drinks and had a gross profit margin per liter of 14.0 euro cents and Cott TB sold approximately 3,938 million liters for the year ended December 31, 2017 for the year ended December 31, 2017. Our Pro Forma Synergies Adjusted EBITDA was A392.1 million. See ‘‘Summary—Summary Pro _Forma and Other Adjusted Financial Information—Pro Forma Synergies Adjusted EBITDA.’’ Our pro forma_ consolidated revenue was A3,718.9 million. Refresco’s consolidated revenue was A2,268.8 million and Cott TB’s carve-out revenue was $1,637.1 million, in each case, for the year ended December 31, 2017. Revenue, however, may not be a meaningful indicator of the development of our business as changes in revenue are largely driven by fluctuations in input prices that are passed on to customers. 144

We are the world’s largest independent bottler of retailer brands soft drinks by volume and a leading contract manufacturer of soft drinks by volume for A-brands with leadership positions across all of our activities and geographies. Approximately 70% of our business is retailer brands and approximately 30% is contract manufacturing. We also manufacture and sell specialty soft drink products on a small scale under our own brands. We have operations in Europe and North America, with a manufacturing network of 59 production facilities operating 270 production lines across 12 countries. Our European operations are in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany, France, Italy, the UK, Spain, Finland and Poland. Our North American operations are in the United States, Canada and Mexico. We manufacture a broad portfolio of products for our retailer brands and contract manufacturing customers. Our portfolio comprises carbonated soft drinks (‘‘CSDs’’), bottled water, fruit and vegetable juices, sports and energy drinks, still drinks, including ready-to-drink tea (‘‘RTD tea’’), and dilutables. We offer our products in a wide range of packaging sizes and types. Given our position as a leading bottler of soft drinks in key markets, we believe we have a large impact not only on our customers but also on our employees and the environment. As such, we have a group-wide approach to corporate social responsibility and quality management which we implement across our business units. Our three-pillar approach focuses on workplace safety, sustainability and maintaining the highest food quality standards while creating healthier products. Our sustainability initiatives include creating sustainable packaging solutions, reduction of water use and energy consumption, improving the sustainability of our supply chain and maximizing our use of green transport. Since 1999, we have expanded our operations through a ‘‘buy-and-build’’ strategy, completing over 20 acquisitions that achieved synergies averaging 3.5% to 5.0% of target revenue. On January 30, 2018, we completed the acquisition of the Cott Traditional Business, which further expanded our operations in North America and the UK, allowing us to become the go-to supplier of soft drinks for retailers and brand owners in both Europe and North America. On March 29, 2018, PAI and BCI indirectly through Sunshine Investments B.V. settled the Tender Offer (as defined below) to acquire 97.4% of the Refresco Shares. As of the date of this offering memorandum, Sunshine Investments B.V. owns 99.4% of the Refresco Shares. See ‘‘The Transactions.’’

Subsubsection Title: Clear scale benefits from being the world’s largest independent bottler
Subsubsection Text: We are the world’s largest independent bottler of retailer brands soft drinks by volume and a leading contract manufacturer for A-brands by volume in Europe and North America with leadership positions across all of our activities and geographies. Approximately 70% of our business is retailer brands and 30% is contract manufacturing. We are approximately 4.1 times larger than our next largest competitor (excluding pureplay water players) in the Addressable Soft Drinks Market based on our reported volume for 2017 and competitors’ volume according to GlobalData, 2017. Our manufacturing network comprises 59 production facilities operating 270 production lines across 12 countries through which we are well-positioned to serve local markets. As such, we benefit from significant economies of scale. We sustain competitive margins through managing both procurement and operating expenses, including the optimization of our plants and streamlining of overhead costs. We are also able to leverage our platform and scale in negotiations with customers and suppliers, which we believe gives us clear scale benefits that our smaller competitors cannot match. Our global platform gives us an advantage because we can service our customers across all key product categories in Europe and North America. We are differentiated from our competitors through our pan-European footprint. In our key European markets, we have a sizeable leading market share according to management estimates. We also have a national presence in the United States. Furthermore, we are licensed by a majority of A-brands to produce their products, which gives us a key strategic advantage as compared to other contract manufacturers. Our global manufacturing footprint provides co-proximity to our customers, enabling us to minimize distribution expenses while also reducing the impact of our business activities on the environment. This proximity and flexibility differentiates us from our competitors and enables us to develop exclusive and long-lasting relationships with our customers. Our size contributes to economies of scale in production costs and distribution, and our production platform and mix of retailer brands and contract manufacturing volumes enable us to continuously optimize our efficiency and capacity utilization. Our size also affords us greater market intelligence capabilities that lead to improved service levels, innovation and flexibility. As a result of our scale, we also benefit from a distinct purchasing edge as compared to our competitors. We believe that this gives us a crucial advantage in an industry where purchasing costs account for a large proportion of sales. Given the highly consolidated supplier base for key raw materials, we benefit from competitive input pricing and preferential supply and payment terms, particularly in comparison with our smaller competitors. This scale benefit is further amplified by our coordinated approach to procurement. Additionally, to ensure we have alternatives when needed, we are continuously looking to broaden our supplier base for the most important raw and packaging materials, such as through sourcing from smaller suppliers or replacing with alternative products. In addition, we have dedicated experts with extensive market knowledge for each key raw materials category.

Subsubsection Title: Leadership positions in attractive and growing markets
Subsubsection Text: We have leadership positions in Europe and North America. In Europe, we are the number one player by volume in retailer brands with approximately 18% market share of the European Soft Drinks Market, were approximately 2.8 times larger than our next largest competitor (excluding pureplay water players) based on our reported volume for 2017 and competitors’ volume according to GlobalData, 2017. In addition, we also have a leading market position in European contract manufacturing. In the U.S., the market is highly fragmented and we are the only player with operations across the country among more than 250 smaller players that are generally focused on limited regions or categories. Approximately one-third of our volume is sold in North America, with the U.S. being the largest single market globally with an annual consumption of approximately 114 billion liters and the highest consumption per capita in the world as of December 31, 2016. In the U.S., consumption per capita is approximately 381 liters per year on average, whereas consumption per capita is approximately 206 liters per year in Western Europe, approximately 169 liters per year in Latin America, approximately 70 liters per year in China and approximately 42 liters per year in the rest of Asia. 145 ----- From 2016 to 2021, volume in the North American Soft Drinks Market, is expected to increase at a rate of 1.4% per year. Between 2011 and 2016, volume grew at approximately 1.0% per year according to GlobalData, 2017. The European Soft Drinks Market is the second largest market globally with an annual consumption of 102 billion liters. Volumes are expected to increase by 0.7% per year from 2016 to 2021, compared to 0.2% per year from 2011 to 2016. Our largest market within Europe in terms of volume is the UK, where volume growth has been relatively flat between 2011 and 2016 but is expected to grow at a forecasted CAGR of 0.8% from 2016 to 2021 according to GlobalData, 2017. Furthermore, the UK is expected to contribute 13% to the European Soft Drinks Market’s volume by 2021 according to GlobalData, 2017. We expect that contract manufacturing will be the key growth driver for us in the short-term with strong underlying structural drivers supporting long-term growth. We are the largest contract manufacturing player in both the European Soft Drinks Market and the North American Soft Drinks Market, with our contract manufacturing operations generating approximately 30% of our combined volume in 2017. We have also entered into contract manufacturing of water and mineral water, which we believe provides us with an additional opportunity for growth. Historically, contract manufacturing volumes have grown slightly faster than expected due to increased outsourcing. A-brands have increasingly focused on asset-light strategies and look to outsource non-core bottling processes. Further, the market has evolved to a point where a large number of small brands and independent manufacturers are creating successful brands (e.g. Arizona, Monster), which generally lack bottling capabilities and outsource the bottling and fill function. The proliferation of multiple brands and packaging varieties, such as 250ml cans, has encouraged large bottlers to outsource, especially for small volume, to bottlers with greater production flexibility. The industry has also seen a trend of volume shifting away from CSD to juices and still drinks, which are typically lower volume products and are therefore more likely to be outsourced. Additionally, high-growth functional beverages, such as enhanced waters and iced teas, that require greater sophistication in the beverages production process. The production process for these categories chiefly uses aseptic PET (‘‘A-PET’’) filling technology in Europe and hot-fill technology in the U.S., requiring high capital investment and expertise to properly operate, and as a result are often outsourced. We expect these trends to continue driving growth going forward.

Subsubsection Title: Unique business model, focusing on leadership in retailer brands and contract manufacturing, providing structural competitive advantages
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have a unique business model as the result of the combination of our retailer brands business, where we manufacture for European and North American retailers and discounters, our contract manufacturing business, where we manufacture for brand owners, and our geographic reach and scale. This combination provides us with several structural competitive advantages. Our business model positions us to take advantage of growth trends in the European Soft Drinks Market and North American Soft Drinks Market as both the retailer brands and contract manufacturing segments are expected to grow between 2017 and 2021. In addition, our focus on retailer brands and contract manufacturing means that, other than for specialty regional drink products, we have limited competition with A-brands, which provides us with an advantage when competing for outsourced branded volumes as compared to the manufacturing and bottling subsidiaries of large A-brand owners that are direct competitors. This is beneficial because the long-term nature of contract manufacturing contracts adds resilience, stability and predictability to our business. A-brand owners are outsourcing the manufacturing of their new and lower volume products because of the increased production complexity as a result of product and packaging diversification. We are able to manufacture these volumes using our optimized plant/line specialization, and reduce overall complexity and switch-over costs as these volumes are relatively large in comparison to our retailer brands product portfolio. Our global platform gives us an advantage because we can service our customers across all key product categories in Europe and North America and are differentiated from our competitors through our pan-European footprint and our national presence in the United States.

Subsubsection Title: Well-balanced and diversified portfolio across products, geographies and categories
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have a well-balanced portfolio with exposure across a range of geographies across the spectrum of product and packaging materials. Our extensive and flexible manufacturing network allows us to manufacture a wide array of products in a variety of packaging in the geographies where we are active. 146 ----- The chart below shows our 2017 volumes by geography and by product type:
We believe that the following strengths characterize our business and will help us realize our strategic goals and reinforce our competitive position:
