Subsubsection Title: Diversified customer base with long-standing relationships in both Europe and the United States
Subsubsection Text: We have a broad portfolio of ‘‘must-have’’ retail customers and A-brands (including Walmart, Lidl, Aldi, Monster, PepsiCo and Arizona), which has been further strengthened by tapping into the rapid expansion 147 ----- strategy of discounters in the U.S. and growing our contract manufacturing exposure. The Cott TB Acquisition provides meaningful diversification to our customer base, reducing dependency on single accounts as well as consolidating A-brand customers. In 2017, on a standalone basis Refresco’s top 10 customers accounted for 58% of its volumes and Cott TB’s top 10 customers accounted for 66% of its volumes. Together, our top 10 customers accounted for 49% of our total combined volumes in 2017. We have longstanding relationships with our customers. Refresco has maintained relationships with 19 of its top 20 customers for over 15 years, which we believe is a testament to the high quality of our products and service. Further, Cott TB has maintained a strong relationship with Walmart for more than 20 years and, following the Cott TB Acquisition, it is now one of our largest customers. We build and maintain these relationships through customer integration, coordinating with our customers in areas such as supply chain (to minimize freight costs and reduce working capital requirements), new product development and packaging designs, market expertize (trends and opportunities) and customer service. The high level of customer integration coupled with our ability to provide a full range of soft drinks products and packaging increases our current and future customers’ dependence on our services, thus leading to long-lasting relationships. We believe that the complementary geographic locations of Cott TB will allow us to consolidate our customer relationships internationally, thus reinforcing partnerships and increasing customer reliance on our business, and thereby reducing the likelihood of potential account losses. Moreover, we will now be able to offer access to a global network, combining Refresco’s strong European capabilities and Cott TB’s strength in North America and the UK. We also believe that this combination will afford us the opportunity to grow alongside our existing European customers, Aldi and Lidl, as they expand in the U.S. We therefore believe that we are well-positioned to strengthen our relationships with our current customers, from both a geographic and product perspective and also to develop relationships with new customers, thus achieving additional utilization from our existing footprint.

Subsubsection Title: Track record of synergy realization from acquisitions is evidence of the success of the continuing consolidation strategy
Subsubsection Text: Following a series of over 20 acquisitions since 1999, we have transformed from a small, local juice bottler into a leading soft drinks manufacturer in Europe and North America. We are currently the number one retailer brands bottler and a leading contract manufacturer across Europe and North America by volume. As we evolved in scale, we gained greater awareness of achievable procurement and footprint optimization synergy opportunities throughout our business. One example is our combination with Gerber Emig, which demonstrated our extremely successful approach to consolidation. We were able to realize synergies from the transaction well ahead of our plan, mainly as a result of faster and higher than expected realization of procurement synergies. Our acquisition of Cott TB similarly offers a substantial synergy potential, particularly through scale benefits. Based on our strong track record of integrating acquisitions and realizing synergies, we expect to generate A34 million of savings through price harmonization and volume bundling, which we believe can be realized relatively quickly. We also believe we can achieve A22 million of operational synergies by optimizing footprint and operational efficiencies through the transfer of lines and manufacturing footprint rationalization. Lastly, we have targeted A6.8 million of achievable overhead synergies through headcount and office space lease reductions as we integrate and streamline our combined operation. Altogether, we anticipate total run-rate synergies of A62.8 million in the first three years following our consolidation, representing 4.3% of Cott TB’s 2017 revenue. See ‘‘Risks Relating to our Business, Strategy and Operations— _We may fail to realize the business growth opportunities, margin benefits and other synergies anticipated from, or may incur unanticipated costs or be exposed to unexpected liabilities associated with or resulting from the Cott TB Acquisition.’’_ We have a strong track record in delivering or exceeding our synergies expectation, and on average have historically achieved synergies of approximately 3.5% to 5.0%. We believe we have the capability to replicate our previous successes and intend to continue taking a proactive approach towards consolidation, with Cott TB and any future acquisitions.

Subsubsection Title: Differentiated innovation capabilities support uniqueness of customer proposition and cost leadership
Subsubsection Text: We believe we are able to differentiate ourselves from our competitors by focusing on innovation as we closely follow industry trends that shape end-consumer demand. For instance, we are currently leading the development of A-PET lines in Europe, which we believe will replace more traditional packaging types in 148 ----- the near future, as growth of complex functional beverages continues. A-PET technology is ideal for complex functional beverages because it improves shelf-life and allows for non-refrigerated transportation and storage, while still providing superior taste and vitamin content. We are also continually looking to optimize our product and packaging offerings in collaboration with our customers. In addition, our broad manufacturing platform enables us to respond and quickly adapt to changing customer needs. We also believe our innovation capabilities provide a competitive advantage in tenders as we are able to proactively propose alternative specifications to improve recipes and minimize costs, such as, for instance, through alternative sourcing or packaging solutions. Our track record and abilities in this respect are widely recognized by our customers, which we believe further allows us to continue to strengthen our customers’ confidence in our capabilities. Finally, unlike our smaller competitors, we believe the combination of our scale and industrial expertize permits sizeable investments when required, thus developing quick routes to market and increasing volumes across our platform.

Subsubsection Title: Committed and experienced management team widely recognized in the industry supported by committed Sponsors
Subsubsection Text: We have a decentralized organization consisting of empowered business units that ensure quality service for local customers. These business units report into two divisions: Refresco Europe and Refresco North America. A relatively small central team manages strategy, procurement, finance, M&A, legal and communication. The central team achieves economies of scale and provides the local organizations with the framework and tools to run our business as optimally as possible. The local organizations are close to their customers and responsive to customer needs while maintaining Group standards and deploying our best practices. These business units are led by highly experienced and professional management teams that meet regularly to ensure operating consistency across the Group. The Executive Board is supported by a best-in-class management team including CEO Hans Roelofs, CFO Aart Duijzer and COO Europe Vincent Delozi`ere with the addition of, following his expected appointment in May 2018, COO North America Brad Goist. Hans joined Refresco in 2007 as CEO and prior to this was CEO of Dumeco, a private label meat producer and processor. Hans is a graduate of Wageningen University and started his career at Nutreco, rising to Managing Director of the Agri-Food Business. Aart joined Refresco in 2000 as CFO and is one of the founders of the company. He previously worked as Finance Director of the Continental European division of Hazlewood Foods Plc and started his career at KPMG and is a graduate of Erasmus University in Rotterdam. He is also a postgraduate chartered accountant. Vincent joined Refresco in 2002 when Refresco acquired D´elifruits. Vincent has fulfilled several managerial and commercial positions within the Group including his latest position as Group Managing Director reporting into the Executive Board. He is a graduate of Institut Sup´erieur d’Agriculture, Lille and holds a MBA from EMLYON business school. Brad joined Refresco in 2018 when Refresco acquired Cott TB. Brad held the position of President of North America at Cott TB at time of the acquisition. Prior roles include roles at the Kellogg Company of which he was a Senior Vice President prior joining Cott TB. He graduated for his MBA at the Ohio State University. PAI and BCI have worked actively together on acquiring Refresco since 2014 and have developed deep insight into our business and our key markets. They submitted a firm bid for the acquisition of Refresco in 2015, before we chose to publicly list our shares. In addition, PAI is a committed sponsor with strong expertise and an outstanding track record in the Food & Consumer sector with 19 standout buyouts in the sector since 2000, including the investments in Froneri, Labeyrie, Panzani and Yoplait. We believe that the market knowledge and leadership capabilities of our management team, combined with our Equity Investors’ track records of accomplishments, will enable us to continue to successfully implement our strategy.

21APR201820314551 We are particularly strong in the juice category and in the Benelux region and also have identified growth opportunities in water, a category in which we are currently underrepresented by market share. We believe that our focus on balancing our product portfolio has helped us to limit our exposure to CSD and juice categories in 2017 to 32% and 20%, respectively. Simultaneously, we are enhancing our presence in fast growing categories, such as energy drinks (7% of our volume as of December 31, 2017), RTD Tea (11% of our volume as of December 31, 2017) and water (19% of our volume as of December 31, 2017) through better access to technologies and scale advantages. Our broad array of product and packaging offerings, geographic diversification and the combination of retailer brands and contract manufacturing, add stability and sustainability to our business and allows us to adapt to potential future changes in the industry and the markets in which we operate. We also expect to be able to leverage our new platform to expand our product offering and access new clients. A-brand owners often look for contract manufacturers that have sufficient scale and geographic scope and to provide the production flexibility to meet their requirements in multiple markets. Retailer brands customers stand to gain by reducing sourcing complexity and costs by working with the same manufacturer across various regions and packaging types.

Subsubsection Title: Capture organic growth in both retailer brands and contract manufacturing
Subsubsection Text: Above-market organic growth in retailer brands:_ We aim to consolidate our leadership positions by achieving growth rates that are slightly higher than the retailer brands soft drinks market volume growth. 149 ----- In order to achieve this, we have identified three key focus areas. First, we will seek to drive growth by completing our portfolio across products and packaging types. Second, we aim to further grow the market share of our retailer brands business, with a particular focus on discounters. Third, we expect a high level of innovation and new product development to contribute to retailer brands volume growth. Growth in sports and energy drinks and RTD tea is also a priority. Contract manufacturing expansion with existing and new customers:_ We aim to increase our contract manufacturing business both in the near- and long-term. The contract manufacturing segment is large, resilient and growing, with significant contract opportunities available to scale players. Branded players are increasingly focused on an ‘‘asset-light’’ strategy given lower returns on manufacturing investment than in core marketing activities, leading them to increasingly favor outsourcing of additional volume. We have a well-developed contract manufacturing business with an unmatched track record with A-brands, while Cott TB offers a platform to further develop the contract manufacturing opportunity in the U.S. Branded players are increasingly looking for manufacturing players able to serve them throughout the footprint and we believe we are uniquely positioned to service customers across multiple categories and geographies.

We plan to continue to execute our ‘‘buy-and-build’’ strategy by making selective investments and acquisitions. Our management believes in the added value of acquisitive growth and maintains a clear framework in order to evaluate the attractiveness of individual opportunities, both in existing and adjacent markets. We have a strong track record of consolidating the industry across Europe and the U.S., as evidenced by the acquisitions of DIS and Whitlock in 2016 and Cott TB in 2018. Over the last 17 years, we have acquired over 20 companies and have demonstrated excellent capabilities to extract synergies. We believe there are a number of tangible value-creating opportunities to further consolidate existing markets, in both Europe and North America, and expand into new adjacent markets. However, we maintain a prudent approach in assessing any investment decision using the following criteria to assess potential targets: (i) the possibility to exploit operational synergy potential; (ii) the extent to which the target’s business complements our product and packaging offering; and (iii) whether acquiring the target would reinforce our leading local position. Our framework sets out specific factors to consider when evaluating a potential acquisition, such as synergy potential and reinforcement of leading local positions, and priority areas for acquisitions in terms of region, product, packaging and channel that align with our overall strategic objectives.

We continually strive for operational excellence in order to improve our cost base. Examples of this include investments in fully automated and higher-speed production lines, and specific targets for reducing energy, waste and water usage with increased recycling rates. Further, additional operational improvement opportunities have been identified in procurement, plant network optimization and Overall Equipment Effectiveness (‘‘OEE’’). The identified procurement categories are grouped in three main areas: raw materials (e.g. orange, carbohydrates, apple), packaging (e.g. cans, liquid paper board, PET) and indirect spend (e.g. transport and warehousing, technical goods and services, utilities and waste). Furthermore, while we have a solid industrial network, we continue to see optimization potential in our asset base which is somewhat fragmented. We expect that optimizing our network and improving its effectiveness could lead to substantial annual savings, consisting primarily of network restructuring, OEE improvements, footprint rationalization and operational synergies.

Subsubsection Title: Focus on full synergy extraction resulting from our acquisition of Cott TB
Subsubsection Text: Our acquisition of Cott TB provides significant and tangible value creation opportunities. Our ambition is to achieve run-rate synergies of A62.8 million in the first three years after the transaction, which represents 4.3% of Cott TB’s 2017 revenue. These synergies were identified by management with assistance from third-party due diligence providers. There are three categories of synergies: procurement, operations and overhead, each respectively representing 2.3%, 1.5% and 0.5% of Cott TB’s 2017 revenue. Procurement synergies are expected to amount to 54% of the total synergies, or A34.0 million, and are anticipated to be generated through price harmonization and volume bundling, which we expect to realize relatively quickly. Operational synergies are estimated to account for 35% of the total synergies, representing A22.0 million, and are expected to come principally from transfer of lines and plant closures. Finally, the remaining 11% of synergies are 150 ----- anticipated to come from overhead synergies, reaching A6.8 million and are anticipated to be achieved through headcount and office space lease reductions. We expect the phasing of synergies to have a ramp-up schedule of 30/60/95/100% from 2018 until 2021, and will require the incurrence of implementation and investment costs to achieve. No commercial (dis)-synergies are anticipated. Implementation and investment costs are assumed to be approximately 94% of run-rate synergies, split over three years as follows:

We have built a scalable platform through the successful integration of multiple acquisitions. Together with our historical focus on profitable growth, we believe this has resulted in a competitive position combining scale and profitability above other players. We aim to continue to leverage our platform, drive profitable growth and improve our operational excellence.

Refresco was formed in 1999 through a management buyout of Menken Drinks B.V. (the Netherlands) and Refrescos de Sur Europa S.A. (Spain). Prior to the buyout, the businesses were part of Menken Holding B.V., a company jointly owned by the Menken family and Campina Nederland B.V., a Dutch dairy company. Since 1999, we have expanded our operations through a ‘‘buy-and-build’’ strategy, completing over 20 acquisitions.

Hardthof Through the acquisition of Hardthof, Refresco extended its footprint to the east in Germany, thereby increasing its market share, especially in the discount channel. 2002 . . . . D´elifruits Through the acquisition of D´elifruits, Refresco gained access to A-PET production capacity and expertise and entry into France. 2003 . . . . Ifv The acquisition of Interfruit Vital in Spain reinforced Refresco’s position in juices in Spain and Portugal as well as in the discount channel. 2004 . . . . Vip Through the acquisition of Vip-Juicemaker in Finland, Refresco expanded its product offering into Finland with ciders and soft drinks. 2007 . . . . Kentpol Through the acquisition of Kentpol, Refresco gained entry into Poland. 151 ----- 2007 . . . . Histogram Through the acquisition of Histogram, Refresco gained entry into the UK. 2007 . . . . Sun Beverage Company Refresco acquired soft drinks producer Sun Beverage Company (SBC), thereby expanding its operations in Benelux and France. 2007 . . . . Nuits St. Georges Refresco acquired Nuits St. Georges in France, thereby strengthening its customer service in the French market. 2009 . . . . Schiffers Through the acquisition of Schiffers Food, Refresco consolidated its position in the Benelux retailer brands soft drinks market. 2010 . . . . SDI Through its acquisition of SDI, Refresco gained entry into the CSDs market in Germany. 2011 . . . . Spumador Refresco acquired Spumador (Italy), which was the largest retailer brands producer of CSDs and mineral water in Italy. 2011 . . . . Sulmona Through the acquisition of the Sulmona facility from A-brand manufacturer Campari, Refresco secured a long-term contract manufacturing contract. 2012 . . . . Taja Refresco acquired Taja, a retailer brands manufacturer of CSDs and bottled water in Poland. 2013 . . . . Gerber EMIG Refresco combined its business with the business of Gerber by way of an issuance of new shares against contribution in kind of Pride Foods Limited, which strengthened its market position in Western Europe. 2016 . . . . DIS Refresco acquired Dutch contract manufacturing business DIS. 2016 . . . . Hamburg PepsiCo bottling facility Refresco acquired the PepsiCo bottling facility in Germany. 2016 . . . . Whitlock Packaging Refresco acquired Whitlock Packaging, a large scale bottler focused on contract manufacturing in the U.S. 2017 . . . . San Pellegrino bottling facility Refresco acquired San Pellegrino’s bottling facility in Recoaro, Italy from Nestl´e. 2018 . . . . Cott TB Refresco acquired Cott TB, which expanded its operations in the UK and North America. On March 27, 2015, Refresco was listed on Euronext Amsterdam. Since its listing, Refresco has completed a number of acquisitions, including the acquisitions of a PepsiCo bottling facility in Germany in February 2016, the Dutch contract manufacturing business DIS in March 2016, Whitlock Packaging in July 2016 and a San Pellegrino bottling facility in Italy in March 2017. The acquisition of Whitlock Packaging was Refresco’s first step into North America and created a second geographic platform for it to grow alongside existing customers and further expand through add-ons. The acquisition was in Refresco’s target growth area of contract manufacturing, with over 80% of Whitlock Packaging’s customer volumes overlapping with its then-existing customer base. Refresco’s recent acquisition of Cott TB in January 2018 expanded Refresco’s footprint in North America. As of the date of this offering memorandum, Sunshine Investments B.V. has acquired 99.4% of the Refresco Shares and expects to own 100% of the Refresco Shares following the Squeeze-Out at which time Refresco will de-list from Euronext Amsterdam and convert into a private company. See ‘‘The _Transactions.’’ We are now the world’s largest independent bottler of retailer brands soft drinks by volume_ and a leading contract manufacturer by volume of soft drinks for A-brands. Going forward, we will be able to provide our customers access to a broader portfolio of soft drinks and fruit juices in key markets. 152 -----

In Europe, our business units are Benelux, France, Germany, Iberia, Italy, Poland, Finland and the UK. Each of the business units is headed by a Managing Director. The Managing Director and local management teams are responsible for managing the manufacturing and sales operations in their respective countries. The Managing Directors report into the COO Europe. _Benelux_ In the Benelux region, we have operations in Maarheeze, Bodegraven, Hoensbroek and Sittard in the Netherlands and Ninove in Belgium. Our Benelux business unit produced 12.7% of our total volumes in 2017. _Germany_ In Germany, we have operations in Calv¨orde, Erftstadt, Gr¨unsfeld, Hamburg and Herrath. We are in the process of selling the real estate that formerly housed the plant we purchased in Hamburg following our transfer of the assets and expect to complete the sale by the end of the second quarter of 2018. Our Germany business unit produced 11.9% of our total volumes in 2017. _France_ In France, we have operations in St. Donat, St. Alban, Nuits St. Georges and Le Quesnoy. Our France business unit produced 8.3% of our total volumes in 2017. _Iberia_ In Iberia, we have operations in Oliva, Alcolea and Marcilla in Spain. Our Iberia business unit produced 4.2% of our total volumes in 2017. We do not have any production facilities in Portugal but Iberia volumes include sales to Portugal. _Italy_ In Italy, we have operations in Caslino al Piano, Spinone al Lago, Recoaro, Sulmona and Quarona Sesia. Our Italy business unit produced 8.2% of our total volumes in 2017. _UK_ In the United Kingdom, we have operations in Bondgate, Bridgwater, Kegworth, Macduff, Nelson and Wrexham. Our UK business unit produced 14.5% of our total volumes in 2017. 153 |Iberia 4% 5%|Col2| |---|---| |4% taly 8%|| ||| ----- _Poland_ In Poland, we have operations in Kety, Kozietuly and Slemien. Our Poland business unit produced 3.9% of our total volumes in 2017. _Finland_ In Finland, we have operations in Kuopio. Our Finland business unit produced 0.9% of our total volumes in 2017.

Our North American operations are centralized in one business unit. The COO North America reports directly to the Executive Board on the operational and sales matters in the United States, Canada and Mexico. In the U.S., we have operations in Blairsville, GA, Brocton, NY, Dunkirk, NY, Concordville, PA, East Freetown, MA, Fontana, CA, Fort Gibson, OK, Fort Worth, TX, Fredonia, NY, Greer, SC, Joplin, MO, Lakeland, FL, North East, PA, San Antonio, TX, San Bernadino, CA, Sikeston, MO, Springville, UT, St. Louis, MO, Tampa, FL, Walla Walla, WA, Wharton, NJ and Wilson, NC. In Canada, we have operations in Calgary, AB, Mississauga, ON, Pointe-Claire, QC and Surrey, BC. In Mexico, we have operations in Puebla. Our North America operations produced 35.4% of our total volumes in 2017.

We are headquartered in Rotterdam and are centrally organized to maximize operational efficiencies, synergies and funding. Our headquarters houses various functions such as our corporate head office and our finance, business development, procurement, ICT and human resources management. Following the acquisition of Whitlock Packaging in 2016, we split our organization at the operational level into Europe and North America. We maintain eight regionally focused business units that focus on local sales and production in order to reduce production and transportation costs and to engage with local customers. The below chart shows our volume by business unit in 2017. Other Iberia 5% 4% Italy 8% France 8% Germany 12% North America 36% Benelux UK 13% 19APR20181728581014%

Our product portfolio includes a wide a range of soft drinks consisting of CSDs, fruit juices, RTD tea, water, still drinks, energy and sports drinks and alcohol drinks. Our products are divided into the following categories: CSD, Juice, Water, RTD Tea, Still Drinks, Sports and Energy Drinks and Other Drinks. CSDs are soft drinks into which carbon dioxide gas has been dissolved. Juice comprises of juice NFC and juice reconstituted from frozen concentrate and nectars and contains 10% to 99% juice content. Water consists of still and sparkling water, including flavored and functional water (e.g. fortified water). RTD teas are tea based or tea flavored beverages in a ready-to-drink format. Still drinks are still juice or juice flavored drinks that do not exceed a 10% juice content. Sports and energy drinks are designed to boost energy levels and usually contain high levels of taurine. The remainder of our products fall into the Other Drinks category, and these include seasonal and specialty drinks such as local beers and mulled wines. With the exception of water, we manufacture this broad portfolio for our retailer brands and contract manufacturing customers. We mainly manufacture bottled water for retailer brands customers. The graphic below shows the percentage of our total volume generated by each product category in 2017. Still drinks 8% Water 19% Juice and Juice drinks 20% Other 3% Carbonated soft drinks (CSD) 32% Sports & Energy 7% Ready to drink (RTD) tea 11% |8% uice and|Sp| |---|---|

Subsection Title: Total volume: 11.0bn litres19APR201818270596 Our Business Model
Subsubsection Text: Our business model combines retailer brands manufacturing for retailers and our own brands with contract manufacturing, for branded beverage companies. Our combination of retailer brands and contract manufacturing businesses enables us to combine flexibility, quality and high standards under one roof and allows us to run our production facilities efficiently as we manufacture a larger number of products for a wide array of customers. This combination also enables line specialization and the reduction of complexity and switchover costs for our plants. For example, retailer brands products vary in quality and price. As such, our retailer brands business provides us with high volume, allowing high capacity utilization of our 154 ----- production facilities. Similarly, our contract manufacturing business increases plant utilization rates and allows us to bridge seasonal fluctuations and to respond to demand shifts by the end consumer.

Our retailer brands channel contains both our retailer brands and own brands, including for reporting purposes. _Retailer brands_ Our main retailer brands customers include Walmart/Asda, Aldi, Lidl, Rewe, Tesco, Eurospin, JMD Biedronka, LeClerc and SuperUnie. We provide a full range of soft drinks products and services to our retailer brands customers and focus on delivering high quality customer service as well as core innovations, such as through the introduction of new packaging materials and flavors and by offering a wide variety of beverages. We also provide customer support for supply chain planning and execution. We believe that this collaborative approach helps us to strengthen our retailer brands customer relationships. Retailer brands contracts are typically one-year fixed price agreements based on volume estimates. Generally, no fixed volume is agreed but we base the pricing on historic data or, in some instances, forecasts. We have a high contract renewal rate with our retailer brands customers. We have had relationships of 15 years or longer with approximately 90% of our retailer brands customers. In many cases, we also act as the exclusive supplier for certain products in particular regions. _Own Brands_ We also manufacture and sell products under our own country-specific value brands, including San Antonio in Italy and Sunpride and Um Bongo in the UK. These products are included under our retailer brands segment for reporting purposes. Unlike global and pan-European branded products, we use local value brands to capitalize on variations in end-consumer taste from region to region. We differentiate our own brands by the unique characteristics of the products manufactured and sold under that brand. For example, the Stars & Stripes and Vintage soft drinks brands in the United States and the Um Bongo brand, which is a children’s drink that is a household name in the UK. We avoid manufacturing value brand products that directly compete with its primary customers’ products and do not plan to expand this product category at present.

We are also a contract manufacturing partner for national and international branded beverage companies who can rely on our high quality production platform. We have long-standing relationships with several of the leading A-brand owners, many of which have granted us exclusive contracts to manufacture certain products in particular countries. We manufacture products for brand names, such as PepsiCo, Coca-Cola, Arizona, Ocean Spray and Monster. We provide our A-brand customers with production flexibility that enables them to expand their packaging mix and lower their production costs. Our contract manufacturing 155 ----- agreements are multi-year contracts typically lasting for three to five years, but can span up to ten years when we are required to make specific investments. Contract manufacturing customers also pay a fixed fee per unit and agree to purchase a minimum volume of units. If the customer purchases less than the agreed minimum volume, a penalty applies. We strive to expand our contract manufacturing business by developing and manufacturing new, high-quality products for our A-brand customers with production flexibility that enables them to utilize their assets better, expand their packaging mix and lower their production costs, which in some instances may mean acquiring their production facilities. We also strive to obtain contracts to exclusively supply branded beverage companies with production technologies they do not have, or products they do not offer in a particular region. For our contract manufacturing business, our customers do not require us to assume the cost and risk of sourcing inputs for their products, whereas we are required to do so for our retailer brands customers. Our larger contract manufacturing customers generally provide the required raw materials and packaging materials themselves, though we source the required raw materials ‘‘back-to-back’’ for those contract manufacturing customers unable to source for themselves. Additionally, some contract manufacturing customers direct us to purchase raw materials and packaging materials in accordance with their specifications, including vendor selection and pricing terms. In such cases, we pass the purchasing costs directly to the contract manufacturing customers and does not record the expense on its income statement.

We have long-standing customer relationships with a diverse customer base that includes full service retailers and discounters as well A-brands in our contract manufacturing business. We enter into multiple contracts with both our retailer brands customers and our contract manufacturing customers, rather than having a single contract with each customer. These contracts are country and product-specific, which reduces the risk of losing a customer’s entire business at the same time. Through our acquisitions of Whitlock Packaging in July 2016 and Cott TB in January 2018, we believe we are positioned to increase our exposure to contract manufacturing and to replicate our European business model in the U.S. Contract manufacturing ~30% Retailer brands 19APR201818270353~70%

Our three primary raw materials are orange juice, apple juice and sugar. Supply and demand of orange juice, apple juice and sugar are driven by standard commodity market dynamics. We negotiate contracts for a fixed amount of these raw materials annually. _Orange Juice_ Our raw material supply of orange juice consists of FCOJ and NFCOJ. We are able to buy both at slightly below market price due to the size of our business. We purchase FCOJ and NFCOJ mainly from Cutrale, Citrosuco and Louis Dreyfus. _Apple Juice_ Our raw material supply of apple juice consists of AJC and NFCAJ. There are two types of AJC: sour and sweet. We purchase both sweet and sour AJC from various suppliers. Our main supplier for NFCAJ is D¨ohler and our main supplier for FCAJ is TB in Poland. In addition to these two suppliers, we purchase AJC in Poland, Ukraine, Germany, France, Italy, Spain, Chile, Argentina, Turkey and China. _Sugar_ We purchase raw sugar from suppliers throughout Europe, but mainly from Pfeiffer en Langen, Polski Cukier, S¨udzucker and Suikerunie. 156 -----

Our primary packaging offerings are PET, A-PET, liquid paper board (‘‘LPB’’) or cartons and cans. Supply and demand of these packaging materials is driven by standard commodity market dynamics. We offer packaging in PET, A-PET in Europe or hot-fill in the U.S., carton, cans and glass. A-PET filling involves flash heating the liquid, cooling it and filling it in a sterile container at room temperature. With hot-filling, the beverage is heated and then filled into a non-sterile container, thus sterilizing it, after which the container is immediately cooled. The graphic below shows the percentage of our total volume generated by each type of packaging in 2017. Cans 15% Other 2% PET 35% Carton 20% A-PET 28%19APR201817290185 _PET_ PET products are made from PET resin. We negotiate contracts for a fixed amount of PET resin quarterly or semi-annually. Our primary suppliers of PET resin are Plastipak and Alpa. _LPB_ LPB is used to make beverage cartons, which are filled with juice products and iced teas. We negotiate contracts for LPB annually for a fixed price per pack. Our primary suppliers of LBP are SIG, Tetra Pak, Elopak, Alternapak and Greatview. _Cans_ Cans are typically made from aluminum. We negotiate contracts for cans annually or for a longer fixed period. The price of cans is to a large extent fixed, but partially fluctuates with the price of aluminum based on the LME index. Our primary suppliers of cans are Ardagh, Canpack, Crown and Ball.

Raw Materials and packing materials represent the main categories of our procurement spend. The vast majority of raw materials and packaging materials are purchased on a centralized basis. We employ a group director of procurement who heads a central team of procurement managers who are each responsible for the procurement of one or more product groups of raw materials or packaging materials. The consolidation of the supply market has resulted in a smaller number of key raw materials and packaging materials suppliers. We have strong relationships with the majority of these suppliers. Due to our scale and independence, we believe we are able to agree more competitive prices and conditions with our suppliers as compared to smaller competitors. Further, since we purchase nearly all raw materials from the raw material suppliers, we have access to market to information that is valuable in negotiations. In the retailer brands business, we protect against commodity price fluctuations by conducting ‘‘back-to-back’’ input hedges where we purchase raw materials and packaging materials at the same time we sign contracts with retailers. We purchase almost all of our raw materials and packaging materials from suppliers at a fixed price based on the market price at the time of negotiation. Only a limited percentage of our raw materials are purchased at the spot price on the market.

Our scale and footprint offers extensive European and North American coverage with presence in 12 countries including the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany, France, the UK, Spain, Italy, Poland, Finland, the United States, Canada and Mexico. Our manufacturing footprint consists of 59 modern production facilities operating 270 production lines with the capabilities to produce a wide range of products and packaging types in a variety of pack sizes and formats. We have a capacity of approximately 16,000 million liters. In Europe, we own all of our production facilities other than our plant in Errftstadt, Germany and our plant in Wrexham, UK. In North America, we own all of our production facilities other than our plants in Surrey, BC, Springville, UT, Fort Worth, TX, Tampa, FL, Wilson, NC, Fontana, CA, Greer, SC and Joplin, MO. All of our leases for these non-owned production facilities are long-term. 157 ----- Our flexibility in production capabilities allows us to create diverse products, thus making the business stable and sustainable. We are also able to leverage our platform and scale in negotiations with customers and suppliers. The below graphic shows our production facilities in Europe and North America.

Subsection Title: North America 27 EUROPE 32 Canada United States Mexico
Subsubsection Text: 20APR201807182034 Each production site consists of one or more production lines that are generally dedicated to a particular package format and size and to specific products. Manufacturing consists of retailer brands product production and contract manufacturing. The actual volumes produced are affected by the size of package produced or the ‘‘pack-type,’’ the number of times the line is switched over to a different package or product and the amount of scheduled and unscheduled downtime for maintenance and repairs. The production process typically consists of five phases: preparation, mixing, filling, packaging and warehousing. Our production lines are fully automated from the preparation phase to loading finished products on to pallets at the end. We maintain our equipment using a computerized system that is designed to schedule regular preventative maintenance and parts replacement ahead of failure. We use several on-site and off-site warehouses. We own a majority of the on-site warehouses whereas the off-site warehouses are leased from third parties in order to maintain capacity flexibility. Filled containers are stacked on pallets and stored in these warehouses for transport. We also rent our headquarters of approximately 2,600 square meters in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Our headquarters houses various functions such as our corporate head office and our finance, business development, procurement, ICT and human resources management.

We fully outsource distribution of our products to external transport and logistics companies, which provides us with the flexibility to customize our transportation arrangements to meet our customers’ needs. Arrangements range from our warehouses being part of its customer’s distribution network to delivery from our warehouses to the retailers directly. Some of our warehouse and distribution facilities are used by its customers as a logistical hub. All transaction costs are passed on to the customers.

We engage in a variety of research and development activities, which principally involve the development of new products, the improvement in the quality of existing products, improvement and modernization of production processes and the development and implementation of new technologies to enhance the quality and value of both current and proposed product lines. We also collaborate with our customers on product development, which allows us to expose them to new products and technologies. As part of our innovation process, we closely follow market trends. 158 ----- Given the necessary market and end-consumer oriented approach, our innovation process is managed locally with regular coordination of new product launches on a centralized level. Our larger business units employ a dedicated research and development team while our smaller business units have research and development employees as part of quality management. Research and development teams and employees are responsible for, among other things, performing quality testing on the products, developing new technologies and processes, and introducing energy-friendly technology. An example of this approach is in the rapidly growing market for so-called ‘‘Water+’’ products. These are premium waters with additional flavorings, vitamins or other functional ingredients. Our research and development project team began by identifying flavors known to appeal to different markets while carrying out extensive market research and competitor analyses. They then developed 40 new recipes, accounting for every kind of taste. From here, our business units selected the concepts or ingredients that best fitted their local markets and honed them accordingly. Another particular area of focus is value engineering for the purpose of cost reduction. We constantly change our recipes, quality specifications used for raw and packaging materials and indirect spend in an attempt to change specifications which result in lower production costs while maintaining the quality of the product within the agreed limits. Examples of value engineering include sugar reduction or sugar substitution by sucralose, and weight reduction of cans resulting in less packaging material, less resources used, less waste and lower costs.

Subsubsection Title: Food and Drinks Health and Safety Rules
Subsubsection Text: Food safety involves actions aimed at ensuring that food is fit for consumption by the end-user. All our manufacturing sites in Europe are certified to a recognized Global Food Safety Initiative Standard (GFSI), which, depending on the country, is Global Food Standard (BRC), FSSC 22000 or the International Features Standard Food (IFS Food). To ensure food safety and quality, every manufacturing site has its own quality system tailored to the critical control and quality aspects applicable to its manufacturing processes. Quality control forms part of each production line. Furthermore, the majority of our manufacturing sites in Europe were ISO14001 certified at the end of 2017. We are also subject to EU regulations on food and drinks health and safety. Such regulations include the so called ‘‘hygiene package’’ which comprises several EU regulations. Regulation (EC) 178/2002 is the core regulation of the hygiene package. In the US, our manufacturing sites are regulated through the US Food & Drug Administration (FDA). Six of our sites certified under Safe Quality Food (SQF) Program, and 15 more sites are currently on track to be certified. Our sites are also regularly audited by our retail and A-brand customers.

We are subject to certain regulations concerning the labeling of its products, in particular, Directive 2000/13/EC on labelling, presentation and advertising of foods and Regulation (EU) 1169/2011 on the provision of food information to end-consumers.

We are subject to certain regulations concerning the quality standard applicable to materials used in the package, authorized substances used for the manufacture of materials, traceability of food contact materials and labelling, in particular Regulation (EC) 1935/2004 on materials and articles intended to come into contact with food. Regarding environmental rules applicable to food packaging, we are subject to certain regulations concerning packaging design and packaging waste management, including Directive 94/62/EC on packaging and packaging waste. 159 -----

Our quality control and assurance programs are designed to enable it to maintain compliance with all applicable regulations regarding food and drinks production and safety. Quality control policies and procedures are strictly monitored and enforced at all of the production facilities. Every production facility has implemented its own quality control system pursuant to EU food hygiene regulations, which are based on the principles of Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (‘‘HACCP’’). HACCP-based food safety and quality control systems involve monitoring, verifying and validating of our production processes to ensure they are compliant with regulatory requirements at all times. All of our production facilities in Europe are either IFS certified or, in the UK, BRC certified.
We believe that quality and safety are paramount and, therefore, we maintain strict compliance with the regulations on food and drinks production and safety.
As of the date of December 31, 2017, after giving effect to the Cott TB Acquisition, we had 10,021 full-time equivalent employees.

Our buy & build strategy means that we are regularly integrating new businesses into the existing structure. To keep our company culture and values alive, we keep our employees closely informed of what Refresco stands for and what is happening across the business through annual town hall meetings, regular updates and local employee communications. In June 2016, we launched our first company-wide employee survey to hear what our employees think about our leadership style, our organizational culture, working environment and the way we manage, develop and recognize our people’s contribution. Approximately 70% of employees of Refresco participated in this survey and 51% of all respondents gave a positive answer as their rating for the ‘‘Great Place to Work’’ statements. In 2017, 77% of our employees participated in the survey and 55% of respondents provided a positive response to the ‘‘Great Place to Work’’ statements. We are committed to continuing this process and the ultimate goal is to improve the level of pride, trust and fun across the company every year. We believe that it is vital for our business to identify employees who can be promoted to wider responsibilities. In 2016, we launched our Leadership Acceleration Program (LEAP) to fast-track our people into the next generation of Refresco leaders. LEAP is designed to develop the organizational, intercultural, managerial and leadership skills of our employees with leadership potential. Now in its second year, the year-long program is split across three modules: Leading Yourself, Leading Others and Leading the Business. In addition, each participant works with a mentor from the top leadership team to learn to apply the individual learnings on a day-to-day basis. We look forward to continuing the program as part of our broader talent retention and development strategy.

We have several contracts with A-brands with terms of five to seven years on average. These contracts typically contain a minimum guaranteed volume and include agreed amounts of compensation to be paid in the event such volumes are not met. In addition, we have contracts with our retailer brand customers that typically have terms of one year. These contracts have an agreed price but do not specify minimum volumes. We re-negotiate our agreements with customers on an ongoing basis. We believe we generally have good relationships with our A-brand and retailer brand customers.

We manufacture soft drinks both under third-party brands and under our own brands. We own registrations for, or applications to register for, various trademarks that we use in our business. The Refresco trademark is registered in Europe and the U.S. and is primarily used in connection with our manufacturing operations. Occasionally, depending on national and local regulations, the Refresco trademark appears on packaging for retailer brands customers’ products as an indication of where the product was manufactured. In addition, we hold licenses to use certain trademarks such as Fairtrade and 160 ----- FSC. We do not believe that our business is materially dependent on any intellectual property or trade secrets.

We maintain insurance coverage covering each of our production facilities. Deductibles are agreed upon if we deem them to be appropriate. Our insurance coverage includes property damage (covering buildings, equipment, inventory/goods) and business interruption insurance covering consequential losses of profits that may occur as a result of material property damage, general and product liability insurance and pollution and remediation legal liability insurance. We have also taken out insurance for damages arising from business interruptions due to events such as fire, storm, explosion, storm floods, theft or burglary and malicious damage. We do not have business interruption insurance covering losses arising from business interruptions due to war risks, terrorism, nuclear reactions or malicious intent. We also provide directors’ and officers’ liability insurance. Members of the Executive Board, Supervisory Board and certain other directors and officers are insured under that directors’ and officers’ liability insurance against damages resulting from their conduct when acting in their capacities as members or officers. We believe that our insurance coverage, including the maximum coverage amounts and terms and conditions of the insurance policies, are appropriate and standard for our industry. We cannot, however, guarantee that we will not incur any losses or be the subject of claims that exceed the scope of the relevant insurance coverage.

At any given time, we may be party to litigation or be subject to non-litigated claims arising out of our normal business operations. Neither the Issuer nor any of its subsidiaries are involved in any governmental, legal or arbitration proceedings (including, to the knowledge of the Issuer, any such proceedings which are pending or threatened) that would have a material adverse effect on our financial position or profitability.

As a bottler of soft drinks and fruit juices, we have a direct impact on the environment through the sourcing and production process of the products we manufacture for our customers. In doing so, we touch the lives of people in our own organization as well as in our supply chain and the communities around us. We consider this a major responsibility as well as a big opportunity for producing increasingly sustainable products and creating a positive impact. Our sustainability framework builds on three pillars: ‘‘Happy People, Happy Planet and Happy Products.’’ The happy people pillar reflects our ambition to be one of the safest workplaces in our industry and to be actively involved in the community with clear links to business. Our happy planet goals involve more sustainable packaging through the reduction of packaging and increasing the use of recycled materials. We also strive to reduce water and energy consumption and to minimize road miles while maximizing green transport. Finally, with happy products, we aim to maintain the highest food standards while driving product innovation to develop more sustainable products that also contain fewer calories. Our group-wide sustainability approach is coordinated centrally by a cross functional and cross business unit team. The Executive Board sets the sustainability agenda and reports it to the Supervisory Board. Each business unit has a sustainability champion who coordinates the local efforts and ensures alignment with the group-wide approach. In 2017, we signed up for the sustainable juice covenant where the goal is for Refresco to use 100% verified sustainably sourced juice by the year 2030. Sustainable sourcing is key for our long-term success and the success of the juice industry as a whole. The covenant is overseen by the sustainable trade initiative IDH and is open to all parties in the juice supply chain. In signing up to the covenant, we committed to work on a series of practical actions to increase the sustainability of our supply and to meet the milestones of 15% sustainably sourced juice in 2018, 30% by 2020, 75% by 2025 and ultimately, 100% by 2030. We also committed to purchasing a significant proportion of our orange juice supply from Rainforest Alliance (RFA) certified farms. RFA is non-governmental organization focused on transforming land-use practices. As a part of our employee engagement program, we launched the Refresco Happy Awards, with the goal of involving as many employees as possible in our corporate social responsibility activities. The first edition 161 ----- of Happy Awards resulted in 32 high quality project ideas from across the business units. The winning ideas focused on giving young people a change in the labor market (Italy), producing organic fruit juices in 100% recyclable carton packaging (France) and replacing road transport of NFC and concentrate juices with a sea-going barge from mainland Europe to the UK. In 2018, we plan to further embed responsibility into our operations. Until now we have applied our approach for our business units in Europe and starting from 2018 we aim also to begin roll out also in our operations in North America. 162 -----

_Unless otherwise stated or the context otherwise requires, in this section the terms ‘‘we,’’ ‘‘us,’’ and ‘‘our’’ refer to the Issuer and its subsidiaries after giving effect to the Transactions and the Cott TB Acquisition. See ‘‘The Transactions’’ and ‘‘Summary—Recent Developments—The Cott TB Acquisition.’’_
The Executive Board is comprised of four members. Set forth below is a brief description of the business experience of the expected members of the Executive Board as of May 2018.

Refresco is a public limited liability company (naamloze vennootschap) incorporated in and existing under the laws of the Netherlands, having its official seat in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, with its registered office at Fascinatio Boulevard 270, (3065WB) Rotterdam, the Netherlands and registered with the trade register of the Dutch Chamber of Commerce under number 24395416. Refresco is managed by its Executive Board and is supervised by its Supervisory Board. The members of the Executive Board and the Supervisory Board can be contacted at Refresco’s business address.

Subsubsection Title: Mr. Hans Roelofs (1963, Dutch national) joined Refresco as CEO in March 2007. Before joining Refresco,
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Roelofs was CEO of Dumeco, a private label meat producer and processor and supervisory board member of Hoogwegt Group B.V. He started his career at Nutreco, rising to Managing Director of the Agri Food business. Mr. Roelofs is a graduate of Wageningen University, the Netherlands.

Subsubsection Title: Mr. Aart Duijzer (1963, Dutch national) is one of the founders of Refresco. Prior to joining Refresco as CFO
Subsubsection Text: in 2000, he worked as Finance Director of the Continental European division of Hazlewood Foods Plc. Mr. Duijzer started his career at KPMG and holds a Master’s degree in business economics from the Erasmus University in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. He is a Dutch Chartered Accountant.

Subsubsection Title: Mr. Vincent Delozi`ere (1972, French national) is the current COO for Europe. He joined Refresco in 2002
Subsubsection Text: when Refresco acquired D´elifruits. He has fulfilled several managerial and commercial positions within the Refresco Group including his last position as Group Managing Director reporting into the Executive Board. Mr. Delozi`ere holds a Master’s degree in Engineering from the Institut Sup´erieur d’Agriculture, Lille, France and a MBA from EMLYON Business School, Lyon, France.

Subsubsection Title: Mr. Bradley Goist (1964, American national) is the current COO for North America. He joined Refresco in
Subsubsection Text: 2018, following the acquisition of Cott TB, where he was President of Cott Beverages’ North America business unit since 2016. Before Cott, Mr. Goist held various positions at the Kellogg Company from 2009 to 2016, including Senior Vice President and General Manager, U.S. Snacks and Senior Vice President of Marketing and Innovation, U.S. Snacks. Prior to that, Mr. Goist held several positions with The Coca-Cola Company from 1996 to 2009, including Senior Vice President and General Manager, Hydration and Senior Vice President, Juices, Teas and Emerging Brands. Mr. Goist holds a Master’s in Business Administration from Ohio State University and is a graduate of University of Michigan, with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Economics. 164 -----
The Supervisory Board comprises of six members. Set forth below is a brief description of the business experience of the members of the Supervisory Board as of the date of this offering memorandum.

Subsubsection Title: Mr. Yiannis Petrides (1958, Cypriot national) has broad experience in the FMCG and soft drinks industries.
Subsubsection Text: Until 2014, Mr. Petrides also served as Vice Chairman of the board of directors of Campofrio Food Group. Mr. Petrides is additionally Chairman of the board of Largo (Wind Hellas Telecoms) and a member of the Board of Puig. Mr. Petrides worked for 23 years with PepsiCo, of which for the last 10 he was the European President for the Pepsi Bottling Group, finally retiring in 2010. Mr. Petrides obtained a Master’s degree in Economics and Political Science from Cambridge University in 1982 and a Master’s degree in Business Administration from Harvard University in 1984.

Subsubsection Title: Mr. Theo de Kool (1952, Dutch national) was a member of the supervisory board of Van Gansewinkel Groep
Subsubsection Text: until 30 June 2015. He was the vice chairman of the executive board of Blokker Holding as of November 2013 until June 2015. Subsequently, he became the Chairman and CEO of Blokker Holding until 31 December 2015. He has also served as CFO/Finance Director of Blokker Holding and as a member of Blokker Holding’s supervisory board. Furthermore, Mr. de Kool was CFO of Sara Lee Corporation based in Chicago, a member of the executive board and supervisory board of Sara Lee/DE and recently Mr. de Kool was a director and CFO and subsequently the CEO of Univeg group in Belgium. Mr. de Kool received his M.Sc. in Economics from Erasmus University Rotterdam and finished studies at Nyenrode Business University.

Subsubsection Title: Mr. Jim Pittman (1963, Canadian national) is a senior finance executive focused on private equity on behalf
Subsubsection Text: of pension funds since 2005. He has co-lead and completed over 20 private equity deals worldwide with a number of private equity partners. He has sat on 10 boards over the twelve years, providing board oversight and working with executive management to generate significant value for those companies and the respective pension funds. Mr. Pittman was the lead Director for Telesat, Haymarket Financial, Noranco, Kinetic Concepts, AmWins Insurance, and was a Director for Noodles and Company until its successful IPO in 2013. He is currently a lead director for BCI for Pilot Freight Services Inc. Prior to the pension fund industry, he was CFO of operating companies for over 14 years after receiving a CPA designation. He obtained a B.Comm (Finance) degree from Memorial University, St. John’s, Newfoundland, Canada and is a Chartered Professional Accountant.

Subsubsection Title: Mr. Julian Remedios (1970, Canadian national) is a Senior Portfolio Manager in the Private Equity Group of
Subsubsection Text: BCI. He has been involved in most aspects of BCI’s Private Equity activities over the last ten years, with particular focus on the international portfolio and direct investing activities. Among other current responsibilities, he leads BCI’s Private Equity Healthcare sector team. He obtained a B.Comm (Finance) degree from the UBC Sauder School of Business, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. He also obtained a MBA degree from Rotman School of Management, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario, Canada and is a Chartered Professional Accountant.

Subsubsection Title: Mr. Fr´ed´eric St´evenin (1966, French national) is the partner in charge of the Food & Consumer and
Subsubsection Text: Healthcare sector teams and Chief Investment Officer at PAI. He currently serves as member of several boards, including Froneri and Labeyrie. He first joined PAI in 1993 and spent five years in the Food & Beverage Sector Team. In 1998, he joined Deutsche Bank / Bankers Trust in the European Acquisition Finance Group as a Director and subsequently as Managing Director. In 2001, he returned to PAI, where he has been involved in a number of transactions including Panzani, Amora Maille, Antargaz, Yoplait, Elis, Panzani-Lustucru, Chr. Hansen, United Biscuits, Marcolin and DomusVi. He graduated from ESCP Europe (Business School). 165 -----

Subsubsection Title: Mr. Nicolas Brug`ere (1980, French national) is a partner and a member of the Consumer Goods team at PAI.
Subsubsection Text: He currently serves as member of the Boards of Marcolin and of Euro Media Group. He joined PAI in 2006. Prior to joining PAI, he worked as a consultant for the Boston Consulting Group in Paris. He graduated from Sciences Po (Institut d’Etudes Politiques de Paris) and holds a degree in Business Administration from the HEC School of Management.

Member March 2018 (1) The independent members of the Supervisory Board, Mr. Yannis Petrides and Mr. Theo de Kool, will be replaced in accordance with the terms of the Shareholder’s Agreement following the completion of the Squeeze-Out.
The Issuer is managed by a management board comprised of two members. As of the date of this offering memorandum, the Issuer’s management board was comprised of Mr. Hans Roelofs and Mr. Aart Duijzer.

The aggregate compensation paid to our executive directors in the year ended December 31, 2017, including benefits-in-kind and pension contributions, was A2.5 million (excluding Brad Goist who is expected to be appointed to the Executive Board as of May 2018). We currently have a customary directors and officers insurance policy. 166 -----

The Issuer was incorporated to facilitate the Acquisition and is a private company with limited liability (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) incorporated in and existing under the laws of the Netherlands, having its official seat in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, with its registered office at Prins Bernhardplein 200, 1097 JB Amsterdam, the Netherlands, and registered with the trade register of the Dutch Chamber of Commerce under number 69882967. The Issuer is a wholly owned direct subsidiary of Sunshine Holding B.V. and a wholly owned indirect subsidiary of Sunshine Equity B.V. 163 -----

On January 22, 2018, our Equity Investors and certain respective related parties, entered into a Shareholders’ Agreement governed by the laws of the Netherlands. The Shareholders’ Agreement sets forth, among other things: (i) the relative rights of the parties to appoint and remove members of the management board of Sunshine Equity B.V., the Refresco management board and the Refresco supervisory board (all of which will be members designated by PAI Partners and BCI); (ii) agreements relating to the governance of Refresco and its subsidiaries, specifically regarding periodic reporting and matters requiring prior supervisory board approval; (iii) a description of the lock-up period and its corresponding mechanisms; (iv) transfer restrictions, including customary drag-along and tag-along rights; and (v) other customary undertakings of PAI, BCI and such related parties. 167 -----

The Issuer is part of a corporate structure that was established to complete the Transactions. See ‘‘Summary—Summary Corporate and Financing Structure.’’ The shares in the Issuer are held indirectly by Financi`ere Scheffer S.`a r.l. (the ‘‘PAI Fund’’) and Cubalibre Investment Limited Partnership (the ‘‘BCI Fund’’). The PAI Fund has PAI Europe VI Finance S.`a r.l. as its sole shareholder, the limited partners of which are PAI Europe VI-1 FPCI, PAI Europe VI-2 FPCI and PAI Europe VI-3 FPCI. The management, operation and implementation of policy of the PAI Fund is vested in PAI Partners. The limited partners of the BCI Fund, i.e. the BCI fund that is established for the purpose of the Offer, are bcIMC PEPL 2017 WSAF Inc., bcIMC PEPL 2017 Inc. and bcIMC PEPL CULI Inc. The management, operation and implementation of policy of the BCI Fund is vested in its general partner Cubalibre Holdings Inc. (‘‘Cubalibre Holdings’’). BCI is the sole shareholder of Cubalibre Holdings. PAI Partners is a major European private equity firm and is the largest private equity investor headquartered in Paris, with additional offices in London, Madrid, Munich, Milan, Luxembourg, New York and Stockholm. PAI Partners manages and advises private equity funds representing approximately A12.3 billion. Since 1994, PAI has invested c.A10 billion in 65 buyout transactions in 11 countries, representing close to A50 billion in transaction value, and has returned A17 billion of cash proceeds, representing a 2.6x gross MoC and 30% gross IRR on realized investments. PAI has a strong and consistent investment track record and in March 2018, PAI closed its largest fund (PAI Europe VII) with commitments of A5.1 billion. PAI is a committed sponsor with strong expertise and an outstanding track record in the Food & Consumer sector with 19 standout buyouts in the sector since 2000, including the investments in Froneri, Labeyrie, Panzani and Yoplait. BCI is one of Canada’s largest institutional investors within the global capital markets with C$135.5 billion of managed net assets. BCI is based in Victoria, British Columbia and is a long-term investor that invests in all major asset classes including private equity. BCI’s clients include public sector pension plans, public trusts, and insurance funds. BCI’s Private Equity team invests globally in both fund and direct investments, with the majority of exposure in North America, Europe and Asia. Its primary focus sectors include healthcare, industrials, business services, financial services, telecommunications, media & technology and consumer retail. The team is currently comprised of 20 investment professionals and has C$7.8 billion in assets under management. Selected private equity investments of BCI include Pilot Freight Services and Hayfin.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: PAI and BCI as the Equity Investors currently (indirectly) hold 100% of the shares in the capital if Sunshine Equity B.V., and it is envisaged that Management Participants will acquire an (indirect) interest in Sunshine Equity B.V. around the end of the second quarter of 2018. The final structure of the management participation is still to be determined. See ‘‘Summary—Summary Corporate and Financing _Structure.’’_

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Minority Owner of Refresco Deutschland Holding GmbH
Subsubsection Text: On March 28, 2018, Refresco Europe B.V. (the ‘‘Seller’’) and OKIL Holding 2 B.V. (the ‘‘Purchaser’’), an entity which is indirectly held by certain Management Participants, entered into a share purchase agreement by which Refresco Europe B.V. sold a 10.0% interest of Refresco Deutschland Holding GmbH to the Purchaser for consideration of A15.6 million. The Seller has deferred the Purchaser’s obligation to pay consideration for the transaction. A call option, which is exercisable at any time, is expected to be granted to the Equity Investors by the Purchaser to allow the Equity Investors to purchase the 10.0% interest of Refresco Deutschland Holding GmbH held by the Purchaser.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Shareholder Funding from Sunshine Holding B.V.
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Acquisition, the Issuer incurred A100.0 million in the form of a shareholder loan from Sunshine Holding B.V., which is subordinated under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. Until March 26, 2028, the shareholder loan does not require any cash payments, does not permit enforcement or acceleration and must remain held by holders of the ordinary share capital of the Issuer. We expect this shareholder loan to constitute ‘‘Subordinated Shareholder Funding’’ under the Indenture. 168 -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: We enter into transactions with certain related parties or our affiliates from time to time and in the ordinary course of our business. We believe these agreements are on terms no more favorable to the related parties or our affiliates than they would expect to negotiate with independent third parties.

In connection with the financing of the Acquisition, Sunshine Investments B.V. has entered into the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement with, among others, J.P. Morgan Europe Limited as agent, the Security Agent, and BNP Paribas Fortis SA/NV, Credit Suisse International, J.P. Morgan Securities plc, Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, ABN AMRO Bank N.V., Co¨operatieve Rabobank U.A., trading as Rabobank London and Mizuho Bank, Ltd., as mandated lead arrangers (together, the ‘‘Arrangers’’). The Senior Credit Facilities Agreement provides for a Revolving Credit Facility in a principal amount of A200.0 million and the Term Loan B Facility in a principal amount of A1,958.5 million (equivalent). Term Loan B Facility is comprised of the following tranches: - a A1,217.0 million senior secured term loan B facility (‘‘Term Loan Facility B1’’); - a GBP 200.0 million senior secured term loan B facility (‘‘Term Loan Facility B2’’); and - a USD 620.0 million senior secured term loan B facility (‘‘Term Loan Facility B3’’). Term Loan B Facility may be utilized by Sunshine Investments B.V. and certain other members of the TLB Group (for the purposes of the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, the ‘‘TLB Group’’ consists of Sunshine Investments B.V. and its subsidiaries from time to time, but excluding Unrestricted Subsidiaries (under and as defined in the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement)) and may be used directly or indirectly to: (i) finance and/or refinance the Acquisition; (ii) finance and/or refinance any fees, costs and expenses related to or incurred or charged in connection with the Acquisition and the equity and debt financing to be made available in connection therewith (this would include fees, costs and expenses related to or incurred or charged in connection with, amongst other things, the Acquisition and any transaction contemplated by the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and/or the Notes); (iii) refinance any existing indebtedness of the Target Group and any associated fees, costs and expenses; and/or (iv) for any other purpose contemplated by the funds flow statement and/or the structure memorandum relating to the Acquisition. The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized by Sunshine Investments B.V., the Target and certain other members of the TLB Group who are borrowers under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement, in euros, British pounds, U.S. dollars and certain other currencies readily available in the amounts required and freely convertible into euro in the wholesale market for that currency (subject to obtaining the consent of all of the lenders under the relevant facility) by the drawing of cash advances, the issue of letters of credit and ancillary facilities. The Revolving Credit Facility may be used for the TLB Group’s working capital and general corporate purposes. In addition to the Revolving Credit Facility and the Term Loan B Facility, the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement includes the ability (without double counting against the limitation on indebtedness covenant) to incur additional indebtedness (including under one or more uncommitted additional facilities within the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and/or any additional Notes and/or other facilities or notes documented outside the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement) up to an aggregate amount not exceeding the sum of (i) A2,185.0 million and (ii) the greater of A395.0 million and 100% of Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and subject to certain customary additions including the amount of prepayments and buy-backs), plus an unlimited amount, provided that, pro forma for the incurrence of such additional facilities or permitted alternative debt: (x) if such indebtedness is secured on the Collateral, subject to the Intercreditor Agreement such that such liabilities rank _pari passu with the Senior Term Loan, the consolidated net secured leverage ratio does not exceed 4.90:1; or (y) if the indebtedness does not fall within paragraph (i), the fixed charge coverage ratio does not exceed 2.00:1, and in each case, subject to certain other conditions being met.

The Term Loan B Facility will be available on and from the date of the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement up to (and including) the earliest to occur of (i) 11:59 p.m. (London time) on the date on which the Squeeze-Out has been completed in full (and all payments relating thereto have been made); 169 ----- (ii) 11:59 p.m. (London time) on 16 November 2018; and (iii) the date on which Sunshine Investments B.V. determines and notifies the Arrangers that the Tender Offer has been irrevocably withdrawn, or otherwise lapsed, in accordance with the Merger Protocol, or, in each case, such later date agreed by the Arrangers (acting reasonably and in good faith). The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized from (and including) the date on which the first utilization of any tranche of Term Loan B Facility occurs (the ‘‘Closing Date’’) to (and including) the business day falling one month prior to the termination date of the Revolving Credit Facility.
Utilizations of the Senior Credit Facilities are subject to customary conditions precedent.

Loans under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement will initially bear interest at rates per annum equal to EURIBOR (or, for loans not denominated in euro, LIBOR), plus an applicable margin, which in each case will be subject to a margin ratchet based on the ratio of (x)(i) Consolidated Secured Leverage minus cash and Cash Equivalents as of the relevant date of determination and (ii) the Reserved Indebtedness Amount secured by a Lien on the Collateral and not contractually subordinated to obligations under the Senior Credit Facilities as of the relevant date of determination to (y) Consolidated EBITDA (each term as defined in the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement) (the ‘‘Consolidated Net Secured Leverage Ratio’’) as shown in the compliance certificate for the relevant period, to equal the rate per annum set out in the relevant table below. From the first day following six months after the Closing Date, the margin applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility will be subject to adjustment by reference to the Consolidated Net Secured Leverage Ratio as shown in the then most recent compliance certificate, to equal the rate per annum set out in the following table:

Subsection Title: Revolving Credit Facility Margin Consolidated Net Secured Leverage Ratio:** **(% p.a.)
Subsubsection Text: Greater than 4.40x . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3.00 Equal to or less than 4.40x but greater than 3.90x . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 2.75 Equal to or less than 3.90x but greater than 3.40x . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 2.50 Equal to or less than 3.40x but greater than 2.90x . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 2.25 Equal to or less than 2.90x . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 2.00 From the first day following six months after the Closing Date, the margin applicable to each tranche of the Term Loan B Facility will be subject to adjustment by reference to the Consolidated Net Secured Leverage Ratio as shown in the then most recent compliance certificate, to equal the rate per annum set out in the following tables:

Subsection Title: Term Loan Facility B1 Margin Consolidated Net Secured Leverage Ratio:** **(% p.a.)
Term Loan Facility B2 Margin Consolidated Net Secured Leverage Ratio:** **(% p.a.)
Term Loan Facility B3 Margin Consolidated Net Secured Leverage Ratio:** **(% p.a.)
Subsubsection Text: Term Loan Facility B1 and Term Loan Facility B2 will be repaid in full on the date that is seven years from the Closing Date. Term Loan Facility B3 will be repaid on each anniversary after the Closing Date in an amount equal to one per cent. of the outstanding aggregate amount of Term Loan Facility B3 loans on each such anniversary of the Closing Date. The outstanding aggregate amount of Term Loan Facility B3 loans will be repaid in full on the date that is seven years from the Closing Date. In respect of the Revolving Credit Facility, each advance will be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto, subject to an ability to roll over cash drawings. All outstanding amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility will be repaid on the date falling seventy eight months from the Closing Date. Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility may be reborrowed, subject to certain conditions.

Subsection Title: Term Loan Facility B3 Margin Consolidated Net Secured Leverage Ratio:** **(% p.a.)
